story:
A sound enjoyable by all

Some may recall the painful screech of malfunctioning speakers; some may recall the unexpected silence in the middle of a wordy scene...these are the unintended realities of unhappy sound equipment! The Kettering Children’s Theatre is in desperate need of your help to purchase and install an amp, stage speakers, some sound proofing materials, hanging microphones and monitor speakers.

We hope the excellent acting of these young performers will cause you to laugh, cry, smile and frown; not the sound equipment.

For over two decades, Kettering Children's Theatre has presented professionally produced and directed youth-oriented productions. The Kettering Children's Theatre is a non-auditioned theatrical instruction program for students in grades 5 through 9. The program allows youth of all theatrical levels an equal opportunity to perform on stage. Past productions include "Hansel and Gretel," "The Wizard of Oz," "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe," and "Alice in Wonderland." 

The Budget

$800: 2 JBL Eon speakers

$400: 2 Shure Beta 98 hanging microphones

$200: 2 JBL Control 1 monitor speakers

$300: Crown Amp

$500: Sound Proofing Materials

$1,200: Installation and Materials

$3,400 TOTAL

The Impact

Your contribution is crucial to help these young actors deliver their best performances to their Kettering community.  The sound system is a small fraction of the amount of resources the staff, crew and students put into each production; be a part of it!

Other Ways You Can Help

There are so many ways to get involved!

+Equally as powerful as contributing to this campaign is sharing it.  Let your friends, family and colleagues in on making a difference!

+Share your memories and photos of Kettering Children’s Theatre in our comments section!

+Connect us with any businesses or sponsors that are interested in investing in the performing arts in Kettering!

Acknowledgements

Thank you to everyone who has contributed to Kettering Children’s Theatre over the years, and especially Andy Dailey, Shannon Fent, Katy Kreitzer, Chris Harlow, Ayn Wood, Ian Snapp, John Rensel and the Light Fantastic, Janna Ross, Sandy and Michael Bashaw, Bruce Brown, Teresa Connair, MVCC, the staff of Rosewood Arts Centre, the City of Kettering and the Ohio Arts Council!

story:
NOMBREUX SERONT NOS ENNEMIS 

DE

GENEVIÈVE DESROSIERS


URD VOLTE 21

Groupe multidisciplinaire


Septembre 2014

Dates et lieu seront annoncés au printemps, au lancement de la saison 2014-2015


VOTRE SOLIDARITÉ = NOTRE LIBERTÉ


NOMBREUX SERONT NOS ENNEMIS

Comment on s'aime à moins 40 degrés en hiver? Quand la bouteille est vide. Quand on est ivre d'avoir bu tout le fleuve des rêves. Quand on pourrait marcher jours et nuits sur les chemins du risque en fumant tout le tabac du dépanneur. Quand on ne dort plus.

Comment on s'aime, comme on se noie dans le vide et la solitude? Comment on s'aime au Parc Laurier en 1996? En 2014? Comment on s'aime dans ce pays? Dans la crise? Dans la folie? À qui écrire? Avec qui parler? Comment se tirer 1000 balles d'amour et ne sentir plus rien du tout? Comment se lessiver le cœur, les doutes et les souffrances?

NOMBREUX SERONT NOS ENNEMIS

C'est une ode à la vie et la mort, un salut et un adieu aux êtres chers, aux paysages du pays…

C'est une œuvre de 27 poèmes et d'écritures intimes…

C'est la mutation de milliers de paroles en tableaux vivants...

C'est la maladie d'amour des corps jeunes et divins...

C'est la démesure des jeux du jour et de la nuit…

C'est une fête d'enfants pour les vieillards...

C'est le rêve des vieillards de redevenir enfants...

C'est la langue gracieuse et sale d'une génération prise entre son feu de vivre et sa léthargie désenchantée…

C'est la solitude qui disparaît dans la boucane du tabac, dans le flux de l'alcool comme une overdose dans le sang…

C'est l'histoire d'une vie prise au risque des promesses…

C'est l'ironie du destin…

NOMBREUX SERONT NOS ENNEMIS

TU VERRAS COMME NOUS SERONS HEUREUX


www.volte21.com

www.facebook.com/volte21

story:
Help Us Paint Frenetic Theater!

Our beloved theater desperately needs to be repainted. That's where you, our audience and admirers come in! The theater offers a great space for performances, classes and rehearsals and the exterior should match the amenities inside. If you've ever attended Frenetic Theater for a performance, for an event, taken a dance class or brought your child to FrenetiKids, you know the theater would look ten times better with a fresh coat of paint.

Our Mission:  Frenetic Theater promotes the creation and presentation of new work in Houston by providing an accessible, affordable venue for the exhibition of performing and visual arts; offers educational outreach programs for children and adults; and produces the annual Houston Fringe festival to promote cutting-edge theatre, dance, film, music, and visual arts in Houston.

Our History: In 2006, the FrenetiCore's directors purchased a 17,000 square foot machine shop on Houston’s east side with the aim of creating a community arts center and offering affordable theater/rehearsal space for local artists. FrenetiCore renovated the warehouse and built a new handicapped-accessible theater complete with a 1,300 square foot stage, theater seating for 100, an eighty foot long exhibit hall for immersive film and visual arts, and a lobby with spacious bathrooms and concession bar.  The theater space has hosted productions by the Houston Cinema Arts Festival, Vault Dance Company, Aurora Picture Show, Horse Head Theatre, MECA, Nameless Sound, FrenetiCore, Sol Y Luna Dance, Jhon Stronks, Houston Flamenco Festival, Unhinged Productions, Pandora Theater, 48 Hour Film Festival, Psophonia Dance, and Bobbindoctrin Puppet Theater, among many others.

What We Need & What You Get

Frenetic Theater needs some serious repainting and we need your help to produce the funds for sandblasting, labor costs and the paint itself. We know our loyal supporters want to keep coming back to a fresh looking facility and will be willing to step up and help. Our goal is to repaint the theater before our upcoming show opens mid-July and before it gets too darn hot!

We will offer donors incentives like social media thank yous, tickets to FrenetiCore's July show, the 2012 Houston Fringe Festival, Apocalypse Ball and more. 

The Impact

Our building serves as the location for a free after school dance/theater kids program, weekly adult dance classes, rehearsals, performances, festivals, workshops , fundraisers and community events. Keeping Frenetic Theater looking its best helps to ensure our patrons feel at ease and eager to return at every chance they get.

FrenetiCore rennovated the theater from the ground up so repainting will be a breeze. We just need your help to raise the funds. And we need to paint now before Houston hits record breaking temperatures!

Other Ways You Can Help

Every donation makes a difference and pushes us closer to our goal. Besides monetary donations, you can also support our campaign by sharing the link via email, blog, Facebook, Twitter and any other way you can. Thank you!

story:
What Comes Next
Written by Matt Schwartz
Directed by Erin Daley
Starring Alistair Spatz, Sarah Fink, Stephanie Giles

Appearing at The Bus Stop Theater as part of The Atlantic Fringe Festival
September 4th at 5:50pm, September 5th at 3:10pm, September 6th at 4:40pm, September 9th at 8:30pm, September 10th at 7:50pm, September 11th at 2:00pm, September 12th at 5:30pm

Where do you turn when the comforting stories, rules and convictions that gave your life order all fall away and you are faced with the overwhelming smack of reality?
In a dark, echoing place, a lone wanderer roams through whispers and glimmers of light. Words, philosophers, fish, mysterious Polaroids and beautiful yet unattainable women swirl through his consciousness. Desperate for something solid to hang on to, he slips in and out of different stories, inhabiting three different lives as he tries to find his way out of the rabbit hole.

Hey Everyone!
Thanks for visiting our site!
We are a group of friends and collaborators coming together from across the country to mount the premier of Matt Schwartz’s play What Comes Next at The Atlantic Fringe Festiva! in Halifax, Nova Scotia . We are one of the few international groups selected to be in the festival and are excited to undertake this artistic adventure. Now, this is not your standard sit down, watch, yawn, applaud and then leave type of theater. It is a refracted, kaleidoscopic view of life that engages the audience’s imagination and pulls them into the world of the play. At times funny, touching, scary or heartbreaking, What Comes Next experiments with the conventions of performance to profoundly communicate the human experience of wandering, stumbling in the dark, finding your path and then stumbling once again.

And we need your help to stumble!

We are asking for your support to help cover our travel and production expenses (such as the registration fee, posters, publicity, props and costumes). It’s a lot of work to put on a production and we will be supremely grateful for anything that you can offer. We believe that theater is a collaborative art and consider your support an essential contribution to this process. So come join us, we’d love to have you on this adventure.

Thanks. We look forward to hearing from you.

Erin, Matt, Alistair, Sarah and Stephanie

story:
“Why did it happen?”

When tragedy strikes at the local high school, the community members are left baffled. The perpetrator was a seemingly normal high school student with no prior history of violence. Everyone has their theories. But only one person knows the truth. The question is, will he talk?

Wake is a play written by Adam Beauchesne, graduate of the University of Lethbridge with a B.F.A. in Dramatic Arts (Performance). The play won second prize in the 2009 U of L Playwright Prize, and is set to have its world premiere this fall.

This will be the inaugural production for Epilogue Theatre, a new Theatre Company in Lethbridge Alberta. The show is tentatively set to run this fall, and we are currently looking for donations to help fund the success of this project.

story:
The Wizard of Oz

The Rising Stars Theatre Company is currently in rehearsals for The Wizard of Oz, to be presented April 25-May 5, 2013. We are a completely self-funded not-for-profit company and our production costs have increased dramatically over the past few years. Any help we can get in order to produce this show would be greatly appreciated. 

The Rising Stars Theatre Company

The Rising Stars Theatre Company was founded in 1979 by the late Ann Dunn, producing musical revues for the local community performed by Ann's current and former students at Portage Park School. In 1987, the company transformed itself into a community theater organization with mostly adult casts performing Broadway musicals in a theatrical venue.

Since then, the company has reliably produced two full-length musicals a year, growing into a beloved arts institution in the northwest Chicago community. Our productions include Broadway classics like "Guys and Dolls" or more contemporary fare, such as "Hairspray" presented by talented amateur performers from across Chicagoland.

A more detailed history of The Rising Stars Theatre Company, including production history, can be found at www.risingstarschicago.com.

The Show

The classic 1939 movie, "The Wizard of Oz," is re-imagined as a stage musical, including Harold Arlen and Yip Harburg's original score, and an expanded book based on the film screenplay.

This production will be performed at The Stahl Family Theatre, 5900 W. Belmont, Chicago IL. The Stahl Family Theatre is a 300-seat state-of-the-art theatre featuring stadium seating and a 3-sided stage.

The production features a cast of 30+ adults, young adults, and children.

This production is particularly challenging from a technical perspective because of the need for special effects, video projection, and other requirements to re-create scenes from the original film.

Where This Will Go

This money will help ensure we will be able to meet the technical needs of our production. It will also defray the costs for renting our rehearsal space, a cost that has increased significantly recently.

Other Ways You Can Help

We are always in need of people to help with the production aspects of our show, including set painting and construciton, props, hair, make up, backstage crew, and ushers. Please contact us at info@risingstarschicago.comor on our Facebook page if you are interested in helping with the production.

story:
Short Summary

Hi, we are Federico, Fernanda and Elizabeth, students from Universidad Iberoamericana in Mexico city, that along with a great team have been working on this play for almost three years now. This project is written, choreographed, directed and produced by students.

We're making this show for several reasons:

1. This play will help us get our bacherlor's degree and to graduate.

2. It will raise funds to help immigrants that arrive to Mexico city. (People that assist the play will help us raise food, clothes and other items that will be destined to "Casa del Migrante" where immigrants are assisted.)

3. But mainly because we are so very passionate of theatre and we believe in the story that we're tellling.

"No tengas cuidado con lo que deseas" is about fighting to reach your goals even when everyone tells you it's too late for you or that your dreams are unrealistic...and that's exactly what we're doing.  

What We Need & What You Get

By funding our project you will help us to make this dream come to life. We need this money to present the play in an actual theatre (until now it will only be featured inside our University) and also to pay for our scenery, props and sound equipment that will help us make the very better version of this play.

We're greatful for your contributions, therefore you will get some perks!

story:
Hello! My name is Heather Closson and I’m a student at Ball State University. I am choreographing/producing an original dance production- DANCE BREAK. As a dance major and a technical theatre minor with a strong interest in fundraising for the arts, I’m hoping to combine all of my interests into one capstone project that will benefit the Muncie community.  Set up as a collaborative project with the Muncie Civic Theatre, I intend on donating all funds raised towards the theatre’s general fund.  The show will feature music from nine different musicals that span across multiple time periods.

SAVE THE DATE: MARCH 15, 2013 @ 7:30 PM.

For this project, I’m looking to raise at least $500 to go towards purchasing costumes and other production needs, including compensating everyone that has worked on my show with some sort of appreciation. There are nearly 30 people participating in my show, so I have quite a few costumes and “thank you”’s to provide! But don’t worry- If you’re able to donate, there are perks designed to show my appreciation towards your generosity.

 

If you donate..

..$10, you’ll receive a special thanks in the program and a FREE Civic Deal at the concession stand

..$25, you’ll receive  an autographed copy of the poster, as well as the above mentioned items.

..$40 , you’ll receive 2 tickets with priority seating, as well as the above mentioned items.

..$50, you’ll receive a DVD of the full performance, as well as the above mentioned items.

 

I want to make a significant impact on our university and the community. A collaborator by nature, I am interested in impacting those around me the most. By utilizing my skill sets, I can continue to endorse the name of this university, as well as the Department of Theatre and Dance, in our community. This production will be raising funds and attention for an organization in the Muncie community, helping expose the arts in new light and, hopefully, for years to come.

If you’re unable to contribute financially, that’s okay! There are other ways to help. Spreading the word about this production is just as valuable as anything else. So go, get out and make some noise about DANCE BREAK!

Thank you for everything!
story_txt:
Hello! My name is Heather Closson and I’m a student at Ball State University. I am choreographing/producing an original dance production- DANCE BREAK. As a dance major and a technical theatre minor with a strong interest in fundraising for the arts, I’m hoping to combine all of my interests into one capstone project that will benefit the Muncie community.  Set up as a collaborative project with the Muncie Civic Theatre, I intend on donating all funds raised towards the theatre’s general fund.  The show will feature music from nine different musicals that span across multiple time periods.
SAVE THE DATE: MARCH 15, 2013 @ 7:30 PM.
For this project, I’m looking to raise at least $500 to go towards purchasing costumes and other production needs, including compensating everyone that has worked on my show with some sort of appreciation. There are nearly 30 people participating in my show, so I have quite a few costumes and “thank you”’s to provide! But don’t worry- If you’re able to donate, there are perks designed to show my appreciation towards your generosity.
 
If you donate..
..$10, you’ll receive a special thanks in the program and a FREE Civic Deal at the concession stand
..$25, you’ll receive  an autographed copy of the poster, as well as the above mentioned items.
..$40 , you’ll receive 2 tickets with priority seating, as well as the above mentioned items.
..$50, you’ll receive a DVD of the full performance, as well as the above mentioned items.
 
I want to make a significant impact on our university and the community. A collaborator by nature, I am interested in impacting those around me the most. By utilizing my skill sets, I can continue to endorse the name of this university, as well as the Department of Theatre and Dance, in our community. This production will be raising funds and attention for an organization in the Muncie community, helping expose the arts in new light and, hopefully, for years to come.
If you’re unable to contribute financially, that’s okay! There are other ways to help. Spreading the word about this production is just as valuable as anything else. So go, get out and make some noise about DANCE BREAK!
Thank you for everything!

story:
Short Summary

  • Sit & Spin Productions is so excited to bring this wonderful show to Northwestern University as our winter outreach project this February.  
  • Written by Naomi Iizuka, Produced by Catherine McGee, Directed by Natalie C. Houchins

The Story

A haunting tale that begins in a cave on the edge of a rural North Carolina town, where a young girl once went missing. One of nine friends is responsible for her death, yet her ghostly, echoed cries will haunt each of them forever. Her ghost story morphs into a multi-layered musing on grief, loss, guilt, and karma, and the elusive truth behind a missing girl's life and death reveals itself one piece at a time.

Sit & Spin Productions

Sit & Spin Productions is one of Northwestern University's student theatre production companies. We produce four mainstage shows per year, as well as a variety of special events.  Language of Angels is this year's winter mainstage, outreach production.

Our Mission Statement: Sit & Spin Productions exists to expand the definition of theatre at Northwestern University by giving artists opportunities to explore unconventional, risk-taking works. We promote new approaches to existing material, adapted or original work, and site-specific theatre. We are dedicated to providing administrative, artistic, and production support for all aspects of our season.

What We Need & What You Get

Northwestern's student theatre productions, Sit & Spin's included, are completely student-produced and student-funded, and therefore we rely heavily on the generous contributions of friends, family, and colleagues.  

Please check out the perks we are offering for different levels of giving!  We would appreciate any contribution you are able to make--no amount is too small in the world of student-produced theatre.  Thank you for making student theatre possible!  

The Impact

Your donation will go toward:

  • Creating the world of the play in Shanley Pavilion, Northwestern's black box theater
  • Costuming the actors in period-appropriate clothing that contributes to the impact of the show
  • Lighting the stage and creating the haunting soundscape of the play
  • Finding and building beautiful props and set pieces that bring the Appalachian mountains and their people to life
  • Bringing a Captain Awkward, a Chicago-based blogger, to campus to speak as part of the outreach program
  • Reaching out to the Northwestern community in order to share the production and speaker with students
  • Teaching students involved in the production practical theatrical, leadership, and teamwork skills 

The Cast and Production Team

  • The Cast:
    • Danielle: Alexandria Frisch
    • Kendra: Cassie Bowers
    • Allison: Anna Baryshnikov
    • Celie: Katherine Seldin
    • Seth: Rob Smierciak
    • JB: Alex Jacobs
    • Billy: Alex Christ
    • Michael: Rick Fromm
  • Producer: Catherine McGee
  • Director: Natalie C. Houchins
  • Stage Manager: Talia Weingarten
    • Assistant Stage Manager: Laura Goldring
  • Lighting Designer: Melissa Hahn
    • Assistant Lighting Designer: Charles Lucke
  • Space Designer: Daphne Kim
  • Costume Designer: Grace Gabel
    • Assistant Costume Designer: Samantha Spoll
  • Props Designer: Danielle Lauder
  • Sound Designers: Sammy Zeisel and Dylan Pickus
  • Hair and Makeup Designer: Nicola Rinow
  • Dramaturg: Russell Kahn
  • Publicity Directors: Marylynne Anderson-Cooper and Christabel Donkor
    • Publicity Team: Dylan Waickman
  • Fundraising Director: Sally Lindel
    • Fundraising Team: Frank Ungerer, Alex Wolfe
  • Graphic Designer: Juli Del Prete

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Come see the show!  Our performance dates are February 7th-9th, 2013.
    • Location: Shanley Pavilion, Northwestern University
    • $5 for NU students/$10 general admission
  • Tell your friends, family members, and colleagues about us!

Questions?  Email sallylindel2015@u.northwestern.edu or catherinemcgee2015@u.northwestern.edu.

story:
Spooking Things Up

Join Stories on Stage at our debut Zombie Show!

Stories on Stage, a local non-profit performing arts organization, has created Zombies 'R' Us for all you Zombie lovers out there!

This pre-Halloween show will be on October 24th at 8:00pm at the Mercury Cafe in Denver (2199 California Street).

The show is a fundraiser for Stories on Stage and will feature Zombie literature performed by  professional actors (who will be "dressed to kill").

Be part of the fun and come in costume!

By contributing you will be part of the exclusive Zombie experience and receive free tickets to Zombies 'R' Us (our most undead event of the year), get a Zombie finger puppet and depending on your level, get a shout-out in the program, your very own Zombie name, and even a signed copy of the script. (See more details to the right).

Here is our Artistic Director to tell you a bit about Zombies 'R' Us



    Who We Are and What We Do:

    Stories on Stage is a local non-profit performing arts organization that brings great stories to life with fantastic actors. Word on the street is that we are:

    • "Great actors performing stories that matter"
    • "Like a bookclub with way more members"
    • and our favorite, "An intimate gathering of friends"

    In addition, we stage 14-16 free shows a year in the Denver and Boulder public schools, including Cuentame un Cuentito/Tell Me a Story, a bilingual show for elementary-school students (featuring Latin-American folk tales, music and shadow play) and Voices Out of Silence, a suicide prevention program for middle and high school students.

    Watch Our Video:


    How You Fit In:

    Come to Zombies 'R' Us and have a GREAT TIME!

    Plus, your donation will assist us in paying our fabulous actors, continuing to offer LoDough (pay what you can) tickets for our season shows, and allow us to reach even more students with our school programs that we bring to the children           free of charge.


    Other Ways to Help

    • Invite your friends -- their brains are tasty too!
    • Share this IndiGoGo page on Facebook and Twitter.
    • Come see a regular season show ( visit www.storiesonstage.org to               learn more)
    • Keep reading great literature!

story:
WHERE WE STARTED

Three directors, out-of-(theatrical)-work and sitting in a coffee shop (the Aroma coffee shop, no less), are lamenting the loss of the USMNT but inspired by the patriotic (anti-Belgium) fervor sweeping the nation.  In an effort to revive American exceptionalism* (on Independence Day, July 4th, no less), they turn to... (what else?) theatre.

In all sincerity, we got together in some trying times and had this grand, delusional aim of providing a space for ourselves and our friends and fellow artists to do work and—hotheadedly enough—we hoped to, in some small but powerful way, reinvigorate the American theater. 

OUR GOAL

Aroma Theater Collaborative is a new company dedicated not to producing a particular kind of work, or espousing an aesthetic, but to empowering theater artists. Our goal is to provide artists with the context, motivation, support, even some financial resources, but above all, the opportunity to make work and put it in front of an audience. We hope to help artists develop their personal style, to create lively conversations about new and interesting work. And we hope to involve YOU in these conversations by including talkbacks as an integral component of our process, and by inviting all audience goers to a fun and flirty conversation-friendly location (read: a bar) afterwards for a big collective feedback session.

The Aroma Theater Workshop is our first step towards that goal. We’ve assembled a group of artists with diverse points-of-view to get together and put up a show (if we had a barn to put up a show in, we’d do it there like Mickey and Judy, but we live in New York and who wants to take a train to a barn just to do a play?). The showcase consists of six scenes, some devised, some with pre-existing texts, some straight plays, some musical theater, some new work, some classics. The Theater Workshop presents a variety of styles, performers, questions, ideas, explorations. We’re sharing resources, contacts, ideas, actors, designers, time, rehearsal space. We’re doing whatever we can do to get our work out there and get better at it—together. As Peter Hall says, “I don’t believe that a theatre ever changes except by being a company.”

WHERE YOU COME IN

If you think that’s a worthy cause, we’d really love your support. Whatever you offer supports not only the Theater Workshop, but Aroma’s general mission of empowering theater artists—and, you know, just as an added bonus, since we have begun our campaign on Independence Day, July 4th (or, you know, like, close to it...), you know you’ll be promoting Manifest Destiny and America and stuff you know you should love (and if you don’t, don’t worry, someone will make you love it some day). Check out our list of cool thank-you gifts to the side. Thanks for your time and your support. And Laura says to make sure to like us on facebook and follow us on twitter!

Here's how your support will contribute to the Theater Workshop:

- SPACE: In addition to raising essential funds for a space in which we can perform the Workshop, Aroma's goal is to provide its directors with difficult-to-come-by quality rehearsal space. ($280 for spaces where we'll present our work to audiences for feedback; $120 for quality space where each project can hold a productive [likely tech] rehearsal)

- DESIGN: Every show has people, yes: directors and actors, for sure, and in some cases writers and other sorts of collaborators. But, a show is not just naked people strutting around on a stage talking to one another (although we're open to seeing that show): we need clothes (costumes), props, makeup, lights, sound, and who-knows-what-else to make these people on stage look visible, dazzling, and intriguing, and to give them a host of things with which they can interact. ($300, with $50 allocated for each show to spend on these magical ingredients necessary for [almost] any theater production)

- PAPER: More specifically than mere paper, we're producing programs. How else will audiences know what the heck is going on if they don't have something on paper to tell them who these people (actually) are and what they're performing and who directed them and what the meaning of each production is (we apologize in advance if the programs of paper do not explicitly and clearly and absolutely unveil the meaning of each production and the meaning of life) and where you can find them next? ($50 for programs made out of paper)


*but in a non-racist, non-colonialist, non-sexist, non-heteronormative, cis-normative, or any other normative way, and in a manner which is fully consistent with the recognition of our institutional privilege. We promise.


insta: aroma_theatre

twitter: https://twitter.com/aroma_theatre

facebook: https://www.facebook.com/AromaTheatreCollaborative

indiegogo: https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/aroma-theatre-collaborative

story:
WHAT?

Boston Theater Company has a new take on Shakespeare's beloved comedy Much Ado about Nothing, mixing modern-day technology into the play's already existing themes of miscommunication. Your contribution will fund the production of the play and Boston Theater Company's three-fold educational programming, which brings this production to local schools, uniting students with this classic play in ways that speaks to them. 

THE PLAY

In a world where we depend on technology to communicate, are we taking it too far? Plans and personalities collide when four couples, each with their own issues, decide to plan an ill-fated wedding. Hilarity ensues as the pairs band together to fake deaths, spread rumors, and do a bit of mischievous photoshopping. The four dynamic relationships in the production illustrate the varying degrees to which technology can be helpful and harmful. Experience live original music alongside classical text in an immersive in-the-round staging of this timeless comedy where a dynamic cast of eight tackle the many characters in the play.

THE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING

In tandem with the three-week run of the production at the Calderwood Pavilion at the Boston Center for the Arts, Boston Theater Company is taking Much Ado about Nothing to students, introducing students to Shakespeare in a way that is modern and relatable. The outreach is three-fold: 

  • This cast will tour the production at local schools
  • Artists will hold in-school Shakespeare workshops
  • BTC's Teen Touring Troupe will also be exploring the play and producing their own production before touring their production to schools, libraries, parks and community centers

WHO?

Boston Theater Company is a new 501(c)(3) nonprofit dedicated to preserving the messages and historical language of classical scripts while approaching them in a contemporary way. We do this both on- and off-stage, with our contemporary productions and our educational outreach programs. BTC consists of a team of young Boston based artists who are passionate about collaboration, classical text and creating art in fresh ways.

WHY?

After a sold out, critically acclaimed run of R&J we've decided to raise the bar. This year we will be doing 3 weeks of shows, performing at the prestigious Calderwood Pavilion at the Boston Center for the Arts, and sharing our Shakespeare expertise in our new education program with young students all across Boston. 

RISKS & CHALLENGES

As a new company we have no overhead all the money we get goes directly to our artists, insurance, space rentals and physical production. 


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP!

Spread the word! Word of mouth is our best marketing. 
Like us on Facebook. 
Buy tickets to our show!
Visit our website to learn more about the cast and designers!

story:
ACADEMY OF HAWAIIAN ARTS

WE'VE SET A STRETCH GOAL OF $12,000 AND ADDED NEW PERKS!!!

WE MET OUR GOAL BECAUSE OF YOU!! We are overjoyed at the outpouring of love and support that has taken us on this ride of fundraising via crowdfunding. We set our goal at $5,000 because we wanted to be realistic — to dip our toes into the uncharted (for us) waters by creating a campaign that would be of interest both to our longtime supporters, and to people just discovering AHA. As you’ve likely read in our campaign story, the costumes alone for our Merrie Monarch trip will cost us well over $15,000. So we intend to keep going strong for our final 8 days — through midnight March 19 — and set a stretch goal of $12,000.

There are still so many reasons to reach out to contribute. Showing your love for AHA and the perpetuation of the Hawaiian culture is just the beginning. You could choose a cool, fun perk. And we decided to add some new perks to give you some different options to consider, such as:

  • $50 Video Shout Out from the Airplane AHA Dancers will shoot a video shout-out to you on the plane to the Merrie Monarch — you never know what you’re going to see with a bunch of excited dancers heading to Hawaii!
  • $60 Day of Rehearsal Stage photo We get a very short window of time to rehearse at Edith Kanaka’ole Stadium, and you will be one of the very first to receive in your inbox a digital photo from our AHA photographer, Uncle Kimo (James Doiron, Inā Hawai’i), the only non-MM photographer who will have the privilege of photographing AHA rehearsing on stage

And remember that we will still be updating the Private Blog that already exists at the $100 level. So there will be a lot of fun photos and video clips that you will be able to access while we are in Hilo. We're picturing messy dorm rooms, lots of eating of food, and maybe negotiations over the limited number of outlets in our rooms.

So go ahead - choose your perk - and let’s crush this!

Mahalo nui for your continuing support!

ABOUT US

The Academy of Hawaiian Arts (AHA) is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization and performing arts school in Oakland, California. A hula halau (dance school) led by the vision of its Kumu Hula (teacher of hula), AHA offers hula classes for dancers of all ages. AHA also offers classes in Hawaiian music ('ukulele and singing) and workshops in Hawaiian crafts.

Since its inception in 2003, the Academy of Hawaiian Arts (AHA) has been carrying forward the vision of its founder, Kumu Hula Mark Keali'i Ho'omalu. With the support of AHA's kumu hula, instructors and many volunteers, AHA is able to carry out its mission to cultivate and evolve the cultural arts of Hawai'i, including dance, music, language, poetry, and composition, as well as a venue for the enhancement of knowledge. The vision of the Academy is articulated in the opening words of our Mission Statement: We are stewards of Hawaiian heritage.

The Academy of Hawaiian Arts continues to grow and to forge new traditions of hula, chant and song. Since its inception, we have (1) established classes for children at levels from beginning to advanced; (2) created classes for adults in both performance and recreational hula at levels from beginning to advanced; as well as (3) started a music ensemble class where ‘ukulele and singing instruction combine with the study of contemporary and traditional Hawaiian songs. Throughout this time, we have continued to maintain our goal of keeping the past alive while creating the present — the legacy of the future.

AHA has a long history of being a premiere dance company. In addition to competing in the Merrie Monarch several times, we have also toured Japan, Hawai'i, Southern California, and most recently performed at the San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival. Our performance has earned us a nomination from The Isadora Duncan Dance Awards Committee for the “Izzies” for the 2013–­2014 performance season in the category "Outstanding Achievement in Performance - Company." The winners will be announced and honored in an awards ceremony to be held March 23, 2015 in San Francisco.

As a non-profit organization, we create our own avenues for fundraising on an ongoing basis. Grants, workshops, performances, food booths at festivals and many events at the halau are all part of our fundraising efforts.  

Kumu Mark & the Academy of Hawaiian Arts has been invited to compete at the prestigious 52nd Annual Merrie Monarch Festival in Hilo, Hawaii. It is an honor to be selected as one of very few participating halau outside Hawaii and the sole school from Northern California. Our team includes 45 kane (men) and wahine (women) who will go to Hilo to participate. From airfare to lodging to transportation to costumes, the journey's expense breaks out to almost $90,000. Per dancer, $2,000 is formidable to each dancer, many who are students, young adults, and parents with families. We would like your help to defray some of the costs of the costumes.

Hula costuming and adornment making is an extraordinarily intricate process requiring meticulous planning, in-depth research and knowledgeable resources. Paying homage to tradition, accurate interpretation and good mana (energy) are all part of hula costume and adornment creation. As part of the learning and training experience, every costume is hand-sewn by the dancers. Costumes not only adorn the dancers in beauty, but are representative of so much more: depicting the era the mele (song) was written; illustrating resources available during the time the story took place; demonstrating geographical location connected to the song; colors of the island from where the hula originates; vegetation of the 'aina (land) woven into adornments. As you can imagine, it takes much thought from our Kumu and dancers to find the perfect blend of aesthetics, meaning, appropriateness, and quality. 

Our goal through this project is to raise $5,000 towards costuming. While this is just a portion of the total costs, it would grant us the ability to create costuming that truly represents the hard work, dedication and sacrifice put forth by AHA to participate in this competition. Participating in the Merrie Monarch is a highly respected opportunity, one that most hula dancers can only dream of. Your contributions will help us put our best foot forward among some of the best hula halau in the world, representing our culture and making our community proud.

Costs for costuming:

The Academy of Hawaiian Arts will be presenting four performances at the Merrie Monarch; two dances each by the Wahine (women) and Kane (men) teams. Each dance requires its own costume suitable for the theme and time period of the song being performed.

Wahine:

  • $1,200 in fabric for hula skirts in the style of the late 1700s. 
  • $4,000 in fabric, boning, and zippers of two fitted tops. 
  • $3,300 in fabric for hula skirts (two per dancer) for a dance dating to the mid-20th century.
  • $225 for notions used in construction of the costumes, including thread and elastic.
Kane:
  • $800 in fabric, thread, buttons and construction costs for Aloha shirts for use in a dance dating to the modern era. 
  • $1,200 for dress shirts, pants and vests representing the Hawaiian Monarchy period of the late 1800s.
Additional costume costs:
  • $6,080 for floral materials (such as native Hawaiian ferns and flowers) and construction costs of lei (Hawaiian garlands) -- each dancer will use between 2 and 6 lei per performance.
  • $700 for pu'ili (split bamboo rattles), hand-held instruments which will be used by the dancers during two performances.

As you can see, the costume costs are estimated to exceed $17,000.

The Perks

We are so excited to be able to offer you these items as our way of saying "mahalo" (thanks) for contributing! These offerings truly represent the spirit of AHA and we know you'll enjoy receiving any one of them.

$1 Our Mahalo & Aloha

You are an AHA supporter and we appreciate you!

$10 Facebook Shout Out from AHA

AHA will personally thank you on our Facebook page, letting everyone know how much your aloha means to us!

$15 Personalized Selfie

An AHA dancer(s) will email you a fun digital photo from the voyage to Merrie Monarch, personalized just for you!

$25 Postcard from Hilo, Hawaii

A real, actual postcard sent to you from Hilo, Hawaii, personalized for you from one of our dancers!

$30 AHA T-Shirt

Have a little bit of the Academy of Hawaiian Arts wherever you are! Our famous black t-shirt with yellow graphics (the one Justin is wearing in the video) will let people know you proudly support AHA!

$50 Drop-In Class

For our local Bay Area supporters: Come to the Academy of Hawaiian Arts in Oakland, CA and take a hula class with our dancers. Learn hula basics and get support and encouragement from all of our haumana. Classes are on Saturdays throughout the year, so you may choose your date.

$50 Video Shout Out

Our dancers will record a personalized video shout-out from practice just for you - we will email it to you and you can post it anywhere you like!

Newly Added: $50 Video Shout Out from the Airplane

AHA Dancers will shoot a video shout-out to you on the plane to the Merrie Monarch — you never know what you’re going to see with a bunch of excited dancers heading to Hawaii! 

Newly Added: $60 Day of Rehearsal Stage photo

We get a very short window of time to rehearse at Edith Kanaka’ole Stadium, and you will be one of the very first to receive in your inbox a digital photo from our AHA photographer, Uncle Kimo (James Doiron, Inā Hawai’i), the only non-MM photographer who will have the privilege of photographing AHA rehearsing on stage

$75 Hawaiian Music CD - Hali'a

You will receive a copy of Hali'a - a collection of hawaiian music featuring Kumu Mark Keali'i Ho'omalu, and AHA friends Amy Hanaiali'i, Kuana Torres Kahele, Kekuhi Kealiikanakaole and more. You may choose a CD or electronic version.

$100 Access to Private Voyage Blog

Get access to our exclusive behind-the-scenes blog and view photos and short video clips as we document our progress towards Merrie Monarch. Keep up with AHA and take the voyage with us!

$300 2 VIP tickets-Brunch at Halau

For our local Bay Area supporters: You and your guest will be our special VIPs at a Sunday brunch hosted by Kumu Mark and held at the Academy of Hawaiian Arts! Great food, great company and great entertainment…AHA’s special events never disappoint! Date: March 22, 2015.

$300 Signed Team Photo & Special Tee

You will receive a framed photo of the Academy of Hawaiian Arts 2015 Merrie Monarch team, signed by Kumu Mark Keali'i Ho'omalu, along with a special AHA t-shirt specially designed to commemorate our Indiegogo Merrie Monarch supporters.

$500 Kako'o for a Day

Experience what it's like to be a frontline lead dancer! You will attend a Saturday class at the Academy of Hawaiian Arts, and be on the front line. With 1-on-1 personalized attention and instruction, you’ll leave feeling ready for the next Merrie Monarch (or at the very least, feeling thrilled and probably a little bit sore!)! There is also a Skype/virtual option for this perk, so no worries if you're not close-by!

$1,000 Photo - Merrie Monarch Costume Fitting

For our local Bay Area supporters: Come to the Academy of Hawaiian Arts and be photographed by our AHA photographer in a costume worn by an AHA dancer in the Merrie Monarch! Take a selfie, or you may choose to have an AHA dancer photographed with you!

$2,500 Private Lesson

For our local Bay Area supporters:  Get your hula on in the privacy of your own home! An Academy of Hawaiian Arts lead dancer/teacher (kako'o) will come to you to give a private lesson. Gather up your friends, find a space, and we'll be there to help you learn the art of hula….AHA-style!

$5,000 AHA Performance

Have you always wanted to have a private performance by the Academy of Hawaiian Arts? This is your opportunity! This sponsorship level is your chance to host an exclusive performance by our pro-team (expert level) dancers at your venue for your party or event. This is a RARE, never before offered opportunity as AHA performances are typically contracted and limited to only a few per year!

Date, time, & other details will need to be mutually agreed upon and coordinated around AHA’s availability.

How you can help us on this voyage:

Whatever you can donate will make a difference. Even if you're not able to contribute money, please consider showing your support by sharing this campaign with your friends and family on Facebook, Twitter, email or good old-fashioned phone calls. Every share helps spread the word about AHA, our efforts, and our voyage. From our thundering floor, through our unity of movement, to the mixing of our voices, AHA shares some of our Hawai`i with you—crafts, language, perspective, and hula. We also seek your guidance and support as we strive to cultivate and evolve the cultural arts of Hawai'i. Join Kumu Mark Keali'i Ho'omalu and the Academy of Hawaiian Arts as we entertain, educate, and inspire...Take the voyage!

ACADEMY OF HAWAIIAN ARTS


WE'VE SET A STRETCH GOAL OF $12,000 AND ADDED NEW PERKS!!!
WE MET OUR GOAL BECAUSE OF YOU!! We are overjoyed at the
outpouring of love and support that has taken us on this ride of fundraising
via crowdfunding. We set our goal at $5,000 because we wanted to be realistic —
to dip our toes into the uncharted (for us) waters by creating a campaign that
would be of interest both to our longtime supporters, and to people just
discovering AHA.
As you’ve likely read in our campaign story, the costumes alone for our
Merrie Monarch trip will cost us well over $15,000. So we intend to keep going
strong for our final 8 days — through midnight March 19 — and set a stretch
goal of $12,000.

There are still so many reasons to reach out to contribute. Showing your love
for AHA and the perpetuation of the Hawaiian culture is just the beginning. 

You could choose a cool, fun perk. And we
decided to add some new perks to give you some different options to consider,
such as:


$50 Video Shout Out from the
     Airplane AHA Dancers will shoot
     a video shout-out to you on the plane to the Merrie Monarch — you never

     on stage


And
remember that we will still be updating the Private Blog that already exists at
the $100 level. So there will be a lot of fun photos and video clips that you
will be able to access while we are in Hilo. We're picturing messy dorm rooms,
lots of eating of food, and maybe negotiations over the limited number of
outlets in our rooms.
So go ahead - choose your perk - and let’s
crush this!

Mahalo nui for your continuing support!

story:
SheworXX is an evolving community of Tucson-based theatre-makers- playwrights, directors, actors, dramaturgs, designers and others- building gender parity in theatre locally and globally through civic engagement, mentoring, peer education and the productions of works by female identified and feminist playwrights. As an emerging arts organization, sheworXX is being incubated at the YWCA of Tucson, AZ, the perfect host for a feminist theatre collective.  This means your contributions are tax-deductible!  SheworXX was initiated in response to the glaring gender parity issues in the theatre industry that restrict opportunities for female-identified theatre artists. But perhaps more importantly, the gender parity issue affects the nature of the the work that audiences consume. The stories we share in the theatre affect our experiences of ourselves, the complexities of our relationships, our work, our communities.  In short, theatre shapes our worldview. Our goal is to usher the feminist voice into the mainstream of American theatre.

The goal of our Gnawing the Bone campaign is to raise funds for our first group show- a collection of fairy tales and myths reworked from a modern, feminist perspective.  Our writers, director and designers are breaking all the rules to reveal fresh takes on the iconic female characters of our collective past. 

Short plays by seven member playwrights will be presented across the entire campus of the YWCA of Tucson, AZ.   Audiences will move through the show, taking in each of the short performances in its own unique environment.  SheworXX artists are working collaboratively and with fierce commitment to create a unique theatrical experience, both in form and content.

Out of the woods and into your mind lurks the thought of “what if...” A tale once told to you in your childhood. You wonder if that is the way the story really goes. What if the characters that you once knew had a past, or a future... a secret life you knew nothing about? Did that old tale ever really protect you from the harsh truths of your reality?

Your tax-deductable contribution will support the production of Gnawing the Bone by creating stipends for actors, designers and the production team, and supplying costumes, props and set pieces for the show.  Donations to our campaign will have an enduring impact on our arts community, as funds will be utilized to support the creation of a performance space at the YWCA.  Work has already begun to transform the YWCA's large conference room into a meeting and performance space: The Kettle Theatre.  A portion of the funds we raise will be allotted to the purchase of theatrical lighting, a sound board and mobile stage.  When completed, the Kettle Theatre will be a tremendous resource for educational and arts organizations in the Tucson environs, and a huge asset to the YWCA's role in the community.

Every donation makes a very significant impact on on our efforts toward creating a space for female-identified and feminist theatre.  Please give what you can and share this campaign with others who support equal access and representation in the dramatic arts.  Let our voices be heard.

Gnawing the Bone: A re-fleshing of classic myth and tale from a feminist perspective


Tales include 7 untold  stories from our talented playwrights:

Esther Almazan, Catfish Baruni, Shel Chapman, Kim Lowry, Milta Ortiz, Germaine Shames, Klara Wojtkowska, and Euginia Woods.

Conceived and designed by:

Eugenia Woods

Directed by :

Esther Almazan

Co-produced by :

Meagan Jones and Zoey Watson


Come and join us:


November 12, 13, 14 and 15, 7:30 pm

The YWCA of Tucson

525 Bonita Avenue, Tucson, Arizona

Tickets are available at:  https://sites.google.com/site/sheworxx/

story:
Short Summary

GEORGE. is a play about how anyone from anywhere can make their dreams happen; with your help we can bring this passion project to life:

  • This story is incredibly personal to us both. Aside from both being massive fans of his work, we both see ourselves in George: We are both new to Los Angeles, having just moved here from Iowa. We could not be more passionate about bringing George Lucas' story to life for the first time. 
  • With your contribution, we can pay for the venue, stage manager costs, costumes, props, etc. We our selves will not be taking a cut of the raised funds. It all goes into the play.
  • With the guidance  of seasoned Hollywood Fringe Festival producers, Matt Quinn & Bertha Rodriquez, we will bring George's story to life. 
  • Performance dates: June 8th, 16th, 23rd, 26th, and 28th at Stephanie Feury Studio Theatre (5636 Melrose Ave, Los Angeles, CA 90038)

What We Need & What You Get

We're on the home stretch and need some help to finish:

  • We're looking for the final 2,500 for performance, venue costs, stage manager, etc.
    • This amount is just above the $1500 we have/are putting in ourselves.
  • We have a handful of different perks and incentives for anyone who may help out!
    • These include anything from an in-program thanks to having your name on the poster with a producing credit. 
  • If you do not live in the Los Angeles area, please reach out and maybe we can find lodging so that you can see the show!

The Impact

Getting George Lucas's story out is important for a number of reasons:

  • This story has been neglected by the general public for over 40 years, despite the impact it has had not only on pop-culture, but technological advances as well. 
  • The success of this play may/can inspire people that anyone can do what they dream.
  • With a successful run in the Hollywood Fringe, we can potentially take the play to different cities around the country, including New York and San Fransisco. 

Other Ways You Can Help

You may not be able to contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please share, like, annoy on social media. That can possibly help key contributors see our campaign for the first time. 
  • Again, if you are not in the LA area, please reach out and let's see what we can do!

And that's all there is to it.
story_txt:
Short Summary
GEORGE. is a play about how anyone from anywhere can make their dreams happen; with your help we can bring this passion project to life:

This story is incredibly personal to us both. Aside from both being massive fans of his work, we both see ourselves in George: We are both new to Los Angeles, having just moved here from Iowa. We could not be more passionate about bringing George Lucas' story to life for the first time. 
With your contribution, we can pay for the venue, stage manager costs, costumes, props, etc. We our selves will not be taking a cut of the raised funds. It all goes into the play.
With the guidance  of seasoned Hollywood Fringe Festival producers, Matt Quinn & Bertha Rodriquez, we will bring George's story to life. 
Performance dates: June 8th, 16th, 23rd, 26th, and 28th at Stephanie Feury Studio Theatre (5636 Melrose Ave, Los Angeles, CA 90038)


What We Need & What You Get
We're on the home stretch and need some help to finish:

We're looking for the final 2,500 for performance, venue costs, stage manager, etc.This amount is just above the $1500 we have/are putting in ourselves.

We have a handful of different perks and incentives for anyone who may help out!These include anything from an in-program thanks to having your name on the poster with a producing credit. 

If you do not live in the Los Angeles area, please reach out and maybe we can find lodging so that you can see the show!


The Impact
Getting George Lucas's story out is important for a number of reasons:

This story has been neglected by the general public for over 40 years, despite the impact it has had not only on pop-culture, but technological advances as well. 
The success of this play may/can inspire people that anyone can do what they dream.
With a successful run in the Hollywood Fringe, we can potentially take the play to different cities around the country, including New York and San Fransisco. 


Other Ways You Can Help
You may not be able to contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

Please share, like, annoy on social media. That can possibly help key contributors see our campaign for the first time. 
Again, if you are not in the LA area, please reach out and let's see what we can do!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
We are New York Shakespeare Exchange.

Our mission is to popularize Shakespeare for new, diverse, contemporary audiences in unexpected ways. Throughout our first seven years, there are four main ways we've pursued this mission:

  • Full Productions -- Our fresh takes on Shakespeare's plays and new Shakespeare-inspired works from Resident Playwright Kevin Brewer are "proof that Shakespeare, in all his complex glory, is alive and well in New York City." (Huffington Post, 2016)

    photo: Titus Andronicus, 2015 (Kalle Westerling)

     

  • ShakesBEER, NYC's Original Shakespearean Pub Crawl
    -- These free-wheeling Shakespeare events for newbies and nerds alike are a perfect introduction to the Bard and a refreshing reminder that classical theater can be a helluva lot of fun.
     

  • The Sonnet Project -- This ambitious cinema project engages more than a thousand artists to create short films of Shakespeare's 154 sonnets at historic locations, and share them through mobile technology and online with audiences all over the world.
     
  • Educational Outreach - Our teaching artists work with high school students to bring the plays they’re studying off the page and into vibrant life. The Sonnet Project has been used by enterprising teachers around the globe, and we’re currently developing our own online Sonnet Project Education Tool and Curriculum which begins beta testing this year.
    photo: Vince Gatton teaching at Eleanor Roosevelt High School
     

So what's NEW?

We're now combining all of these initiatives to forge a new path which will, over time, grow into a Shakespearean Super Highway called INTERSECTIONS.

Here's how it'll work

PHASE ONE: NYC

Every INTERSECTIONS will be built right here on our home turf in NYC. We'll kick off the project with two performances of our renowned ShakesBEER Pub Crawls, combining the lowest of hi-jinks with Shakespeare’s most breathtaking use of language. 

A couple of weeks later, our New York audiences will see the very same ensemble perform a full production of one of Shakespeare's great plays. In 2017 it'll be Much Ado About Nothing, directed by our Artistic Director, Ross Williams. After Hamlet, Titus Andronicus, and Othello, we are excited to dive into one of the comedies!

PHASE TWO: Hit the Road, Jack​

The rubber meets the road as we then head out of NYC for one-week community immersion projects in towns across the country. We start by storming the local streets and pubs with a couple of our ShakesBEER pub crawls; we end a week later with performances of our mainstage show. But in between the two is where we can get really creative: we will work with each community to craft an tailor-made schedule of events that  harnesses the energy of each specific group. We will teach at local schools and colleges, facilitate Q&A sessions and lectures at the town library, coach young film makers in a Sonnet Project film contest, and even host Shakespeare trivia nights at the Community Center -- the possibilities are only as limited as our collective imaginations.
 

And how do we get there?

We are insanely excited about the possibilities of INTERSECTIONS. It serves our mission in such a palpable way and we know we can make an enormous impact. But it is going to take the support of our community. Our full budget for this first year is $100,000; we need to raise $35,000 of it during this campaign. YOU CAN HELP US MAKE IT HAPPEN.

Here's how our costs break down:

 

  • Producing our NYC offerings, including the sets, costumes lighting, venue rental, etc. ($25k)
  • Hiring the perfect team of actors, designers, producers and directors ($25k)
  • Getting where we are going: travel/lodging, ground transportation, shipping our scenery and costumes, a meal or two along the way ($40k)
  • Marketing and infrastructure ($10k)


 

What will all this accomplish?

In our first year, we will be testing the waters with a smaller sampling of INTERSECTIONS communities (we are aiming for a total of four week-long immersions). These audiences will all be exposed to classical theater and performance through our uniquely contemporary lens. We aim to give everyone we come in contact with a chance to personally interact with Shakespeare and find a sense of ownership; there are way too many people in the world who have either never seen Shakespeare performed, or seen it as a remote, stuffy thing and been turned off by it. We will change their minds.

As we grow into the future, we are planning to find funding sources that will allow us to go into communities that may not be able to afford this kind of exposure. In the next several years, we'd love to have multiple INTERSECTIONS teams creating art and cultivating experiences all over the country.

We know that this project will not only get people thinking about Shakespeare, theatre, and performance in new ways; we believe it will also invigorate communities and stimulate engagement between local schools, libraries, artists, and businesses after we’ve come and gone. We just have to get it up and running.
 

We Know this is BIG!

As with everything we do at NYSX, we are taking some huge risks. INTERSECTIONS is a great expansion of our business in terms of logistical complexity, and we are discovering the challenges as we go. One of the first is making contacts in our target communities: we are committed to a week in Bryan, Texas in March, and have feelers out in other Texas communities, as well as in Alabama, Arkansas, Tennessee, and upstate New York. But we know that not all of those will pan out; discovering new communities and refining our pitch process will be integral to making INTERSECTIONS have the impact it deserves. Please consider making a contribution today. Together we can share some of the artistic love that is so embedded in the New York community. We can get out into the world and make Shakespeare thrive!

story:
It starts with an idea, that turns into a conversation, that becomes a story.  A funny story, or a sad story, but a story that needs to be shared.

My uncle is a playwright in NYC, and he would call me and say, "Let's do a show!" This usually meant he'd finished writing a play, had gotten a grant, and secured a venue, off-off-Broadway.  He'd invite other playwrights, directors and a group of actors for readings at his house.  And then, we, a rag-tag ensemble group, would perform one-act plays to staging room audiences at the NuyoRican Poets Cafe in the Lower East Side (Lo-e-sida).

I want to create that excitement here in Pittsburgh.

Your donation will allow me to book rehearsal space, the performance venue, pay the actors and crew, provide ASL and audio description for patrons wanting accessibility services, cover production costs, marketing and advertising.

So Pittsburgh, let's do a show!

Why Big Green Bananas?

Big Green Bananas is a production company created by Delilah Picart. In Puerto Rico, a BGB (platano) is a food used in several dishes. It is hearty, neither sweet or sour, sometimes fried and mashed, sometimes boiled. In the USA, a BGB is a banana waiting to become ripe. It's considered "not ready", and is often left on the counter, until it is yellow.

Big Green Bananas represents the duality of actors; always waiting, always ready.

story:
WHO WE ARE & WHAT WE'RE DOING

Clear Theater Collective is a theater company in Williamsburg, Virginia, made up entirely of friends and former/current students of Naomi Marrow & Backstage Productions, a staple of Williamsburg theater and arts education since 1999. 

Last year, CTC produced its first show, The Odd Couple, and thanks to a successful Indiegogo campaign and dozens of generous donations after both performances, we were able to bring theater free of charge to Williamsburg at absolutely NO COST.

In 2017, Clear Theater Collective wants to do it again.

For our 2nd production, we are producing David Mamet's controversial landmark play, Oleanna; produced, directed, designed, and performed by members of the Collective.

CTC's Oleanna Indiegogo campaign is about one thing: Putting on a great show, completely free to our audiences!

We believe that free local theater is a necessity, not a luxury. Your donations make it possible for up to 500+ audience members from across the Peninsula to see live theater for free!  All members of the cast and crew are volunteers, so 100% of your donations go towards paying for the expenses of producing Oleanna. 

After the success of our Phase 1 fundraiser for Oleanna, we're excited to launch Phase 2!

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

Our Phase 2 fundraising goal of $400 covers the following:

- Dress rehearsal venue costs ($150) 

- Set, props, & costume costs ($200) 

- Program printing ($50)

Some of the perks of donating: You can get your name in the show program, reserved seating, shout outs before each performance and on social media, and even an Executive Producer credit! 

If you've ever wanted to be a producer, or even just a valued patron of the arts, now's your chance! 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

1) Come see the show! September 15th @ 6pm, and September 16th @ 2pm at the Williamsburg Regional Library in Williamsburg, VA. Even if you can't donate, we still need you there!

2) Bring your friends and family! 

3) Spread the word about the show and our Indiegogo campaign! Share this link and help us get the word out.

4) Visit us on Facebook and Instagram @ClearTheaterCo!

story:
Summary

Welcome to the Here Lies Joyland IndieGoGo page!

I'm Darrington Clark, and my co-producers Mitchell J. Ward and Hannah L'Abri Miller are at the head of Here Lies Joyland - a new play we are producing for the KC Fringe Fest this year. Hannah, Mitchell and I are all Kansas State University Theatre graduates; we all first met and collaborated at school. Now we are excited about the opportunity to collaborate professionally, and on a new work: Mitchell is our playwright, Hannah is directing and I am acting in our piece.

Darrington Clark

Hannah L'Abri Miller

Mitchell J. Ward

Joyland was an amusement park in Wichita, KS and was once the state's premiere attraction. Shut down in 2006, now the campus of the park is decrepit, decaying and very possibly haunted, if you believe in that sort of thing. The location inspired Mitchell (native of Colwich KS and very familiar with Joyland in its former glory and current abandonment) to write a horror-play about the deserted amusement park. Our play is a ghost story, an attempt to explore the convention of terror on live stage, and most importantly, a bold endeavor to put our own artistic voices into the Kansas City theatre community. To put it simply, we're doing a passion project, and we need help to bring it to fruition.

What We Need & What You Get

We have set a fundraising goal of $800. This is based on a budget projection that includes marketing/advertising, costumes, set and props (creating the right vibe for a haunted, abandoned amusement park), as well as rehearsals space and the cost to participate in Fringe in general.

Hannah, Mitchell and I all willingly went into the project assuming we would not make money back, and funding WILL ONLY be returned to us if we can successfully pay all our expenses and offer payment to our actors and crew. It is important to us, as producers & artists, to compensate the people we have asked to do this project with us as a favor; it is not important to us to make every cent we put into this back.

By contributing to us, you contribute to a new work in the making! Your support aids us here as well as all future endeavors and productions of this piece. From a thank-you in our show program to seeing our final product free of charge, we are offering several gifts in return for your support.

Again, any money we receive is going to pay our practical expenses first. If we don't reach our goal, all of the funding received will have gone to the expenses of producing a brand new play.

The Impact

If this project is successful for us, it is successful for our careers, our city and our development as artists and professionals. As the play develops, we wish to see it performed and produced on an even higher professional scale. We're working within Fringe limitations, so an unlimited budget and immeasurable space are not items on the table. The more we develop, the more Here Lies Joyland will resemble the way it is suppose to look and feel. We will keep all our backers updated on the progression of the piece you've helped us create!

Other Ways You Can Help

We're artists - we understand not being able to throw money any which way. You can help us with our goal in several ways

  • If you're local, come see our play!
  • The biggest marketing tool for Fringe is word-of-mouth. We think our play is pretty cool. If you think the idea is too, talk to others about it, come as a group!
  • You can share this page to make it more visible to more people - the more the merrier!

Thank you so much for sticking with us through this. We really appreciate your support. We're here because we believe arts can change the world. At this beginning point in our careers, our own work and our own voices being thrust on stage could not be more valuable. Thank you!
