story:
Die NonTutu Musical-Company ist  eine Musicalgruppe. Von Kindern.  Für Kinder.  Auf der ganz großen Bühne.   

 

Die Aufführungen sind vor allem für Schulklassen gedacht. Für sie ist es eine einzigartige Erfahrung, dass nicht Erwachsene sondern Kinder auf der Bühne tanzen, singen und schauspielern. 

 

Jedes Jahr wird ein neues Stück einstudiert, das ein echtes Original ist und nur  für die NonTuTu-Gruppe geschrieben wird. 

 

Für die Aufführungen unserer Stücke mieten wir Theatersäle an, kaufen Requisiten und suchen Kostüme zusammen. Die Ausgaben für die Aufführungen sind so hoch, dass die Eintrittskarten über 20,00 EURO kosten müssten, um alle Auslagen zu decken.  Preise, die sich viele Schulen und Eltern nicht leisten können.  

Aber wir wollen unsere Shows allen Schulkindern in Berlin ermöglichen! 

 

Im vergangenen Jahr führten wir das Stück "Du kannst auf mich zählen"  im Atze Musiktheater und in der UFA-Fabrik auf. Eltern, Lehrer, aber vor allem die Kindern waren restlos begeistert. Die Augen der Kinder strahlten, als sie den Theatersaal verließen und sie wollten selbst gern Tanz-, Gesang- und Schauspielunterricht nehmen.  

 

Ein unbezahlbares Gefühl, das erreicht zu haben!!  

 

Die Kosten aller Auftritte beliefen sich auf rund 16.270 EURO. Und leider deckten die Eintrittsgelder nicht alle Ausgaben.  

 

In diesem Jahr zeigt die NonTuTu Musical Company "Rock on!". Im Herbst begannen die Proben und im Frühling wollen wir die ersten Shows an den Start bringen.  

 

Die höchsten Kosten dieser Shows verursachen die Mieten der Theaterräume. Bis zu       1600,00 EURO pro Tag müssen wir dafür aufbringen.  

 

Bei den Aufführungen haben wir Helfer vor Ort,  die für den reibungslosen Ablauf der Shows unverzichtbar sind. Da wären die 3  Techniker pro Auftritt: Einer für die Musik, einer für die Projektionen auf der Bühne und einer für das Licht, damit unsere Talente bestmöglich ausgeleuchtet sind. 

Außerdem sind da noch acht weitere Assistenten hinter der Bühne, welche den Kindern mit den Requisiten und Kostümen helfen, bei Texthängern beispringen und die Einsätze der Kinder  koordinieren.   

Insgesamt zwölf wichtige Personen, die natürlich für ihren unermüdlichen Einsatz bezahlt werden müssen. 

Um die Stimmen der Kinder und die Tänze auch bis in die letzten Reihen sehen und hören zu können, benötigen wir zusätzliches professionelles Licht- und Soundequipment, das bei den Theatersälen nicht da ist. Diese Technik müssen wir für die Auftritte ausleihen. 

Ebenso fällt das Aufnehmen und neu komponieren unserer Songs ins Gewicht. Viel zu oft existiert keine Karaokeversion unserer Lieder, die wir dann selbst produzieren. Dafür investieren wir nicht nur viel Zeit und Schweiß, sondern auch viel  Geld. 

Für die Kostüme der Kinder durchforsten wir unsere eigenen Kleiderschränke oder die unserer Freunde, aber hier und da fehlt doch eine Strumpfhose oder ein Gürtel... Genauso machen wir es mit den Requisiten: Wir  durchstöbern Keller und Omas Garage, aber  manchmal fehlt etwas, das wir dann doch kaufen müssen.  

Dabei unterstützt uns unsere professionelle Kostümbildnerin, die monatelang für die  Outfits der kleinen Darsteller tüftelt.

 

Hinzu kommt noch das Drucken der Flyer und ein paar Plakate, das Transportauto für die  Requisiten, die wir zu den Aufführungen fahren und viele weitere Kleinigkeiten. 

 

Im letzten Jahr hatten wir Ausgaben von 16.270,00 EURO für die Shows. Wir müssen versuchen, dieses Geld über die Eintrittsgelder wieder einzunehmen. Dabei wollen wir selbst nichts daran verdienen, sondern nur am Ende unterm Strich eine Null stehen haben.  

Unsere Kalkulation ergab, dass dann eine Karte aber mindestens 20 EURO kosten müsste. 

Ein so hoher Preis schließt viele Kinder von  der Aufführung aus, deren Eltern nicht so viel Geld bezahlen können.  

 

Wir möchten aber keine teure Show für nur wenige Kindern und Eltern sein. Wir wollen für alle tanzen, singen und spielen! Wir zeigen, was Kinder alles auf dem Kasten haben und  wie viel Lebensfreude im Tanzen, im Singen und im Spielen verschiedener Rollen  steckt.  

Von Kindern. Für Kinder.  Das ist unser Motto. 

 

Wenn Du uns hilfst, können wir Schulen aus ganz Berlin zu unseren Aufführungen einladen und die Show weiterhin für 7,00 EURO die Karte anbieten und nicht für 20,00 EURO.   

 

Hilf uns dabei, Kindern eine Freude zu machen und ihnen hautnah zu beweisen, was Kinder mit viel  Spaß Großartiges erreichen können. 

Wir brauchen Euch! 

DANKE AN ALLE UNSERE UNTERSTÜTZER!

Bitte sendet uns eine Email, zu welchem Datum Ihr in welche Show kommen wollt an nontutu.company@gmail.com oder an mariaineslongo@gmail.com. Wir reservieren Eure Karten und gegebenenfalls auch Eure Plätze.  Danke!
story_txt: Die NonTutu Musical-Company ist  eine Musicalgruppe. Von Kindern.  Für Kinder.  Auf der ganz großen Bühne.    Die Aufführungen sind vor allem für Schulklassen gedacht. Für sie ist es eine einzigartige Erfahrung, dass nicht Erwachsene sondern Kinder auf der Bühne tanzen, singen und schauspielern.  Jedes Jahr wird ein neues Stück einstudiert, das ein echtes Original ist und nur  für die NonTuTu-Gruppe geschrieben wird.  Für die Aufführungen unserer Stücke mieten wir Theatersäle an, kaufen Requisiten und suchen Kostüme zusammen. Die Ausgaben für die Aufführungen sind so hoch, dass die Eintrittskarten über 20,00 EURO kosten müssten, um alle Auslagen zu decken.  Preise, die sich viele Schulen und Eltern nicht leisten können.  Aber wir wollen unsere Shows allen Schulkindern in Berlin ermöglichen!  Im vergangenen Jahr führten wir das Stück "Du kannst auf mich zählen"  im Atze Musiktheater und in der UFA-Fabrik auf. Eltern, Lehrer, aber vor allem die Kindern waren restlos begeistert. Die Augen der Kinder strahlten, als sie den Theatersaal verließen und sie wollten selbst gern Tanz-, Gesang- und Schauspielunterricht nehmen.   Ein unbezahlbares Gefühl, das erreicht zu haben!!   Die Kosten aller Auftritte beliefen sich auf rund 16.270 EURO. Und leider deckten die Eintrittsgelder nicht alle Ausgaben.   In diesem Jahr zeigt die NonTuTu Musical Company "Rock on!". Im Herbst begannen die Proben und im Frühling wollen wir die ersten Shows an den Start bringen.   Die höchsten Kosten dieser Shows verursachen die Mieten der Theaterräume. Bis zu       1600,00 EURO pro Tag müssen wir dafür aufbringen.   Bei den Aufführungen haben wir Helfer vor Ort,  die für den reibungslosen Ablauf der Shows unverzichtbar sind. Da wären die 3  Techniker pro Auftritt: Einer für die Musik, einer für die Projektionen auf der Bühne und einer für das Licht, damit unsere Talente bestmöglich ausgeleuchtet sind. Außerdem sind da noch acht weitere Assistenten hinter der Bühne, welche den Kindern mit den Requisiten und Kostümen helfen, bei Texthängern beispringen und die Einsätze der Kinder  koordinieren.   Insgesamt zwölf wichtige Personen, die natürlich für ihren unermüdlichen Einsatz bezahlt werden müssen. Um die Stimmen der Kinder und die Tänze auch bis in die letzten Reihen sehen und hören zu können, benötigen wir zusätzliches professionelles Licht- und Soundequipment, das bei den Theatersälen nicht da ist. Diese Technik müssen wir für die Auftritte ausleihen. Ebenso fällt das Aufnehmen und neu komponieren unserer Songs ins Gewicht. Viel zu oft existiert keine Karaokeversion unserer Lieder, die wir dann selbst produzieren. Dafür investieren wir nicht nur viel Zeit und Schweiß, sondern auch viel  Geld. Für die Kostüme der Kinder durchforsten wir unsere eigenen Kleiderschränke oder die unserer Freunde, aber hier und da fehlt doch eine Strumpfhose oder ein Gürtel... Genauso machen wir es mit den Requisiten: Wir  durchstöbern Keller und Omas Garage, aber  manchmal fehlt etwas, das wir dann doch kaufen müssen.  Dabei unterstützt uns unsere professionelle Kostümbildnerin, die monatelang für die  Outfits der kleinen Darsteller tüftelt. Hinzu kommt noch das Drucken der Flyer und ein paar Plakate, das Transportauto für die  Requisiten, die wir zu den Aufführungen fahren und viele weitere Kleinigkeiten.  Im letzten Jahr hatten wir Ausgaben von 16.270,00 EURO für die Shows. Wir müssen versuchen, dieses Geld über die Eintrittsgelder wieder einzunehmen. Dabei wollen wir selbst nichts daran verdienen, sondern nur am Ende unterm Strich eine Null stehen haben.  Unsere Kalkulation ergab, dass dann eine Karte aber mindestens 20 EURO kosten müsste. Ein so hoher Preis schließt viele Kinder von  der Aufführung aus, deren Eltern nicht so viel Geld bezahlen können.   Wir möchten aber keine teure Show für nur wenige Kindern und Eltern sein. Wir wollen für alle tanzen, singen und spielen! Wir zeigen, was Kinder alles auf dem Kasten haben und  wie viel Lebensfreude im Tanzen, im Singen und im Spielen verschiedener Rollen  steckt.  Von Kindern. Für Kinder.  Das ist unser Motto.  Wenn Du uns hilfst, können wir Schulen aus ganz Berlin zu unseren Aufführungen einladen und die Show weiterhin für 7,00 EURO die Karte anbieten und nicht für 20,00 EURO.    Hilf uns dabei, Kindern eine Freude zu machen und ihnen hautnah zu beweisen, was Kinder mit viel  Spaß Großartiges erreichen können. Wir brauchen Euch! DANKE AN ALLE UNSERE UNTERSTÜTZER!Bitte sendet uns eine Email, zu welchem Datum Ihr in welche Show kommen wollt an nontutu.company@gmail.com oder an mariaineslongo@gmail.com. Wir reservieren Eure Karten und gegebenenfalls auch Eure Plätze.  Danke!

story:
Short Summary

NPG is a global NYC-based theatre collective formed to create experimental, imaginative new performance works. NPG is a revolving collective of theatre artists founded by South African director Kim Kerfoot and Thai-Australian artist Anchuli Felicia King. NPG stands for North Pacific Gyre - an oceanic gyre in the Pacific ocean and the largest ecosystem on Earth. NPG represents our approach to making theater; porous, global and migratory. Like the NPG, we collect artistic "debris" through our symbiotic collaborative process. Like a gyre, we float through new spaces, cities and forms.

As an ensemble we are interested in finding new ways to tell stories, explicitly through translation and transformation onstage - using both spoken languages and multidisciplinary languages of performance. Our work is designed to be:

Portable: Returning to a model of performance that is accessible to all.

Flexible: Both form and content that adapts to any circumstances.

Multidisciplinary:  Our troupe members have experience and expertise in disciplines ranging from Norwegian Folk Music to Augmented Reality, and we will use them all to tell the best story possible.

Our Campaign

In both our process and production, NPG strives to create a communal storytelling space, a figurative hearth, long table, or bonfire. Only by returning to such a space can we can begin to explore the relationship between listener and storyteller (audience and performer) through a text that is over a thousand years old, that reaches back to the beginnings of the English language itself, and which grew out of an oral tradition of poetry and storytelling.

We are not trying to resuscitate a  thousand year-old story but rather we seek to create a new vehicle through which this story can be shared. Portable, irreverent, self-aware and yet deeply connected to and fascinated by the material, we aim to tell this story come hell or high water, with any and all means at our disposal. Praise poetry, puppetry, Norwegian choral folk music, dance, mime, physical theatre and the language of Beowulf itself.

We want to create a different kind of Communion. A place of order protected from the chaos of the outside world, to remind ourselves that though death is ever-present, some things live on.

Your Contribution

The CATWALK Art Residency is an invitation-only artist residency program in Catskill, New York. The Beowulf project was awarded a three week residency in April to develop and create the production. At the end of the residency we will have a presentation of our work so far.

Your contribution will enable us to support the team's individual living expenses while away from their jobs on residency, covering rent and minimal expenses, as well as transporting the company to the residency.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $7300 to cover the 8 person team’s individual living expenses for 3 weeks. In order to get the team out of the city and away from their survival jobs for three weeks, we need to cover their rent and minimal expenses.

Exciting perks you get for supporting our project include:

Social media shout-outs, personalized thank you letters featuring unique design elements,

Tickets to our exclusive post-residency showcase,

Digital, printed and signed copies of the conceptual design sketches,

Mp3s of original soundtrack compositions,

Practical workshops with company members including QLab and Isidora, devising theatre and puppetry, 

Executive Producer credit and

The opportunity to have a home-cooked dinner with 3 members of the creative team!

Impact

Both as a collaborative team and as individuals we have taken projects from initial workshop development phases like this through to successful productions and ongoing projects. Two early NPG projects, Anchuli Felicia King's Orientalism and Kim's Einstein's Knee are great examples of this. After a successful workshop performance,  Orientalism was accepted to Manhattan Theatre Rep's Spring New Play Festival in 2016, while Einstein's Knee was developed into a site-specific immersive play, Wrecked, at the National Theatre of Croatia Ivan pl. Zajc in Rijeka. 

For us, the Beowulf Project is about community building, and creating a space for communion through shared imagination. We want you to be a part of this process, and to help us create something unique. Our hope is that by giving our community insight into this process, from concept and design to workshops with members of our team and personal time spent with us, this project will be built from a community. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Short Summary

18th & Union is a creation of Seattle's Radial Theater Project. Since its inception in 2011, Radial Theater Project has produced new and innovative works by local and international theater artists, and created the Locally Grown performance festival. 18th & Union will be a home for Seattle's solo and other portable performers, and for exhibits of work by Seattle-based photographers and painters.

What We Need & What You Get

We've gotten started with private funding, but now need your help to establish 18th & Union as a vital community asset. Our initial costs have included:

  • Creating a new nonprofit corporation that will operate the space
  • Signing a new three-year lease and setting up utilities with all required deposits
  • Rebuilding seating risers for a wonderful audience experience
  • Adding air conditioning for audience comfort during Seattle's warmer months 
  • Redesigning the lobby

Money raised during this campaign will be used to pay back some of these expenses, and to establish a fund to pay ongoing costs (rent, utilities, and so on) as we get 18th & Union started.

The Perks

When you donate to 18th & Union, you'll know you've helped create a sustainable place for the arts in Seattle. But we also have some gifts to offer! These include:

  • Social media shoutouts
  • Tickets to shows at 18th & Union
  • Your name inscribed on the wall, and even on tech equipment
  • Your name displayed on our preshow lobby display

The Impact

Art space is harder to come by with every high rise and crane that pops up in our city's skyline. Seattle's artists need space to rehearse, perform and, most importantly, try new things and even fail. 18th & Union is dedicated to preserving this awesome art space and keeping it in the hands of the artists who need it most. We envision an artistic playground that's financially accessible to artists, letting them maximize their artistic risk without breaking the bank. 

Furthermore:

  • 18th & Union is in a neighborhood with (relatively) easy parking.
  • 18th & Union seats 48 audience members comfortably, and has a spacious lobby.
  • 18th & Union will host exhibits of visual art by Seattle-based photographers and painters.
  • and...18th & Union has air conditioning for summer-time comfort! 

Risks & Challenges

We're unquestionably hitting the ground running. In just its first three months, 18th & Union will present at least seven different productions, and will be host to many other events. And it's being done with a nearly all-volunteer staff.

The good news is that the creators of 18th & Union have a wealth of experience to draw on. David Gassner, Producing Director, was Artistic Director at Theater Schmeater from 2007-2009, and has led many other artistic organizations. Blair Feehan, Managing Director, has worked in arts administration for some of Seattle's most respected organizations, including On the Boards and Seattle Repertory Theatre. And the rest of the staff--designers, marketers, volunteer organizers--similarly bring great backgrounds to this project.

Other Ways You Can Help

There are many other ways to help get 18th & Union started. Help us get the word out: share this campaign on social media, and tell people about the project. We need volunteers for everything from ushering at shows to helping keep the space clean. But mostly, we hope you'll come to 18th & Union to see the work: solo and other portable performance, created and presented by extraordinary artists.

Want Your Donation to be Tax-Deductible?

18th & Union is already a Washington State nonprofit corporation, but it'll take us some time to achieve IRS 501(c)(3) status. In the meantime, we've partnered with Fractured Atlas, a national organization that supports folks at every level of the cultural ecosystem. Contact us for more information on making tax-deductible donations through our fiscal sponsorship with Fractured Atlas.

story:
Short Summary

 

Charleston City Ballet’s Rumpelstiltskin is a family friendly ballet that slightly updates the fairytale of Rumpelstiltskin. We have added the character of the Prince, the love interest of the Miller’s Daughter to clear up some of the plot devices in the original tale. For example, in the original story the King threatens the Miller’s daughter with her life to make the gold, yet she marries him and has a child. We see the King as a selfish dictator who does not love anything other than wealth and prestige. On the other hand, the Prince is kind and really does love the Miller’s Daughter. Rumpelstiltskin is very much a creature who is clever, mischievous, only thinks of himself and the tricks he can play. We believe this creates the right balance of characters to create a funny yet interesting story that all can enjoy. Charleston City Ballet prides itself on mixing great story telling, dance, and the theatrical arts. Our goal is to draw you in to the story and to have the rest of the world drift away.  

The leadership of the Charleston City Ballet brings the grand Russian tradition of storytelling and dance to the city of Charleston and its communities. Michael and Olga Wise both had prestigious careers with The Moscow Classical Ballet. They strive to bring the traditions, training, and quality that Russian ballets have done for centuries to every performance they create. Students and dancers from all over the world come to Charleston to work with them

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need to raise funds to support the staging of our ballet performance of Rumpelstiltskin for the Piccolo Spoleto Festival 2017 in Charleston, SC.
  • All contributions will go directly to offset the costs of staging the production.
  • For your contribution, you will get access to some unique perks and the eternal gratitude of the only classically trained ballet in Charleston, SC!

story:
Who We Are

Seadreamer is a Calgary-based theatre company focussing on telling intimate solo work. Stories that showcase the struggle between one's heart and one's mind are important, and we love it when those struggles are juxtaposed with current events and today's social dilemmas. We believe that solo work creates a dialogue between performer and audience, and we want to bring great solo shows to life for Calgary. Seadreamer will appeal to you if you:

- are interested in thought-provoking theatre.

- are interested in heart-melting theatre.

- want to engage in today's cultural conversations.

- are a friend of Caleb Gordon's.

I am Caleb Gordon, artistic director of Seadreamer, and for the last year, I've been building this company towards becoming a legitimate theatre company in the Calgary area. This coming February, we are producing The Fever, by Wallace Shawn; a seething monologue that cuts to the heart of the modern consumer. More than this show however, we want to create a fund base that allows Seadreamer to produce outstanding theatrical experiences for years to come.

 

What We Need

Theatre is expensive -- the cost of tickets is almost one quarter of expenses. We need $1500 to create a pool of funds that stays with the company to cover the costs of the following:

Rights to the show -- the playwright deserves some money for the amazing story they penned.

The venue -- whether we're in The Motel Theatre at Arts Commons, or The Birds and Stone Theatre, we need to make an advance deposit to secure the space. 

Creative crew -- the Director, Stage Manager, and Designers are all being paid a fee for getting the show up and running. While they are worth far more than we could ever hope to pay them, we'd still love to give them something worthwhile.

We need funds to get the ball rolling. The plan is to raise $1500; the bare minimum needed to function. Once we make that much, we are able to put up our production of The Fever. We'd love to go above and beyond this amount however -- any donation, large or small, gets us there!

By investing your money in our company, you invest in an artist with a message. It's a powerful thing in this day and age. You give me a metaphorical soapbox to stand on top of and shout "HEY I'VE GOT SOMETHING IMPORTANT TO SAY and it's funny and it's sad."

And in this world of technology that I love so dearly, that's an important moment, when people who can be divided so easily can instead come together and feel something. 

I will never promise the subject material will be easy to view, but I can promise that it is good, and comes from a place of hope, and not despair. 


What Happens If We Fail?

The theatre presents an interesting challenge: if we fail, nobody will notice. A different voice will be heard in our place, with a different message. And while I want all messages to be heard, I am biased towards my own message in this case. 

I'd like to think that those who saw House last year can attest to the skill and effort that I place upon my productions. Of course, with every show that we produce, we move forward towards a greater standard of excellence. There will always be mistakes, issues and failures, but the best part of theatre is that these are part of the experience -- no matter the outcome, you got to see something unique. 

I have the support of people whom I trust greatly -- my parents are more than willing to help me in my artistic pursuits, and my General Manager/Executive Director/Front of House/Roommate, Shannon Klassen, has my back in all respects. My good friend Kyle Kimmerly, previous Assistant Director of The Canadian Badlands Passion Play will be coming out to direct. I have many contacts that are interested in creating living, breathing theatre with me, and they've all been through this before. They are helping me to succeed.

But my goal is not to simply 'succeed', my goal is to converse. And while it's possible to fail at conversation, I'm going to try my darndest to avoid that.
 

We Need More Than Money

I completely understand if you're saving your hard-earned money for a ticket at the door ;)

That said, if you cannot donate, if you wouldn't mind sharing this on Facebook with that handy-dandy link down there, that'd be great. AND

Mention me to your friends! Gather them all and bring them out to see my show!

Finally, if you cannot donate monetarily, but still want to help me bring Seadreamer to life, have a chat with me! Let's grab coffee, and we can discuss volunteering, the good ol' days, ideas that you have -- literally anything. 

Thank you so much for your time and donation. I look forward to seeing you at Seadreamer's production of The Fever!

NEXT SHOW: The Fever, by Wallace Shawn


The Fever runs from February 16th until the 25th at The Motel Theatre at Arts Commons.

Street Address: 205 8 Ave SE, Calgary, AB
story_txt:
Who We AreSeadreamer is a Calgary-based theatre company focussing on telling intimate solo work. Stories that showcase the struggle between one's heart and one's mind are important, and we love it when those struggles are juxtaposed with current events and today's social dilemmas. We believe that solo work creates a dialogue between performer and audience, and we want to bring great solo shows to life for Calgary. Seadreamer will appeal to you if you:- are interested in thought-provoking theatre.- are interested in heart-melting theatre.- want to engage in today's cultural conversations.- are a friend of Caleb Gordon's.I am Caleb Gordon, artistic director of Seadreamer, and for the last year, I've been building this company towards becoming a legitimate theatre company in the Calgary area. This coming February, we are producing The Fever, by Wallace Shawn; a seething monologue that cuts to the heart of the modern consumer. More than this show however, we want to create a fund base that allows Seadreamer to produce outstanding theatrical experiences for years to come. What We NeedTheatre is expensive -- the cost of tickets is almost one quarter of expenses. We need $1500 to create a pool of funds that stays with the company to cover the costs of the following:Rights to the show -- the playwright deserves some money for the amazing story they penned.The venue -- whether we're in The Motel Theatre at Arts Commons, or The Birds and Stone Theatre, we need to make an advance deposit to secure the space. Creative crew -- the Director, Stage Manager, and Designers are all being paid a fee for getting the show up and running. While they are worth far more than we could ever hope to pay them, we'd still love to give them something worthwhile.We need funds to get the ball rolling. The plan is to raise $1500; the bare minimum needed to function. Once we make that much, we are able to put up our production of The Fever. We'd love to go above and beyond this amount however -- any donation, large or small, gets us there!By investing your money in our company, you invest in an artist with a message. It's a powerful thing in this day and age. You give me a metaphorical soapbox to stand on top of and shout "HEY I'VE GOT SOMETHING IMPORTANT TO SAY and it's funny and it's sad."And in this world of technology that I love so dearly, that's an important moment, when people who can be divided so easily can instead come together and feel something. I will never promise the subject material will be easy to view, but I can promise that it is good, and comes from a place of hope, and not despair. 
What Happens If We Fail?The theatre presents an interesting challenge: if we fail, nobody will notice. A different voice will be heard in our place, with a different message. And while I want all messages to be heard, I am biased towards my own message in this case. I'd like to think that those who saw House last year can attest to the skill and effort that I place upon my productions. Of course, with every show that we produce, we move forward towards a greater standard of excellence. There will always be mistakes, issues and failures, but the best part of theatre is that these are part of the experience -- no matter the outcome, you got to see something unique. I have the support of people whom I trust greatly -- my parents are more than willing to help me in my artistic pursuits, and my General Manager/Executive Director/Front of House/Roommate, Shannon Klassen, has my back in all respects. My good friend Kyle Kimmerly, previous Assistant Director of The Canadian Badlands Passion Play will be coming out to direct. I have many contacts that are interested in creating living, breathing theatre with me, and they've all been through this before. They are helping me to succeed.But my goal is not to simply 'succeed', my goal is to converse. And while it's possible to fail at conversation, I'm going to try my darndest to avoid that. We Need More Than MoneyI completely understand if you're saving your hard-earned money for a ticket at the door ;)That said, if you cannot donate, if you wouldn't mind sharing this on Facebook with that handy-dandy link down there, that'd be great. ANDMention me to your friends! Gather them all and bring them out to see my show!Finally, if you cannot donate monetarily, but still want to help me bring Seadreamer to life, have a chat with me! Let's grab coffee, and we can discuss volunteering, the good ol' days, ideas that you have -- literally anything. Thank you so much for your time and donation. I look forward to seeing you at Seadreamer's production of The Fever!NEXT SHOW: The Fever, by Wallace Shawn
The Fever runs from February 16th until the 25th at The Motel Theatre at Arts Commons.

story:
I am a choreographer, designer, and maker of experiences.  I have been given the opportunity to create a new work to James Stephenson's "The Devil's Tale", at the University of Colorado's College of Music this fall in collaboration with a PHD conducting student Christopher Huls.

 

This is an incredible opportunity for me to create a premiere work with a live orchestra. I have been dreaming of doing a work with live orchestra for many years, and I am really excited to bring this story to life with some wonderful performers. 

 

By contributing to this campaign, I will be able to pay the performers for their hard work, as well as develop some amazing costumes for the production, which is set in 1990's Las Vegas.  While I have received a grant to choreograph this work, it does not cover the cost of the performers or for my work in design.  Additionally, we hope to take this production to other venues.

 

This project is already under way, it just needs some funding to make sure it gets to the finish line!  The funding will be a great benefit to many in the following ways:

 

  • University of Colorado College of Music Students will have the opportunity to work with professional dancers.

  • This work will be supporting local talent, as well as building new repertoire in dance. 

  • This work will be bringing awareness towards new and continued collaborations between music and dance.

My funding goal is $3000 to pay performers as well as costume design.

story:
INTRODUCTION

In this tragic and true story, Heloise and her lover, the philosopher Abelard, hope to advance the power of reason, but they must confront a brutal medieval world.

Most historians focus on Abelard, the philosopher, but few of them focus on Heloise, his great love. Our story highlights the mind and will of Heloise—a rare female voice from the medieval world that is more modern than one might expect.

We are grateful for any help you might offer so we can produce the story of Heloise.

SYNOPSIS:

Heloise is a young woman when she meets Peter Abelard—the most famous philosopher of 12th-century France. He is shrewd, ambitious, and politically threatening to conservatives of the Church. But her family then exacts a terrible revenge. The tale of Heloise and Abelard is one of the world’s great love stories, but it is also a philosophical story, because the two lovers press a crucial question with great force against the Church: the proper relation of reason to faith.

LOCATION:

The Lion Theatre

Theatre Row, 410 W. 42nd Street, NY, NY, 10036

SHOW DATES   (Click a date for tickets)

  • Wednesday, Aug. 7 at 5 p.m. (includes talk-back with cast & director after the show)
  • Friday, Aug. 9 at 8 p.m.
  • Saturday, Aug. 10 at 2 p.m.

 

TICKETS ON SALE - $27 each

Come see the show! Tickets ($27) are now on sale! For tickets and more information, please visit  www.BroadwayBoundFestival.com.  Also visit us on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/BroadwayBoundFestival/.

 

OUR GOAL:

We hope to raise $7,000 so we can produce the play.

WHERE YOUR HELP WOULD GO:

Director, Actors, Stage Manager, Set Designer, Lighting Designer, and Costumes. Check out our perks to see what you can get for your small or big contribution. (The Broadway Bound Festival provides theater space, marketing, programs, ticket sales, public relations, and production tutorials for the playwrights. Our job is to put the play up.)

*If we do not reach our goal, all the money will continue to go into this fund for the show. 

  • Director: 30%
  • Actors: 30%
  • Costume Design 10%
  • Stage Manager 15%
  • Set Designer 10%
  • Lighting Designer 5%

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:

  • Share our campaign with your communities via word of mouth or social media.
  • Like us on Facebook.
  • Keep checking back for info on upcoming social events, new artwork, production photos and other updates.

Thank you!

Sincerely, Michael (playwright) and Heidi (co-producer)
and The HELOISE Team 

You can find us at: heloisetheplay.com

For more information, write to heloisetheplay@gmail.com

OUR CAST & TEAM:

 

Sophia Blum* as Heloise  

Originally from Rhode Island, Sophia Blum now lives in Brooklyn. Off Broadway: Vilna (Theatre at St Clement’s), understudy in Public Enemy (The Pearl Theater Co) Regional: The Bungler, Henry IV Part I, Shakespeare LIVE! (The Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey); Antony and Cleopatra (Orlando Shakespeare Theater); King Lear, CSC2’s Romeo and Juliet (Commonwealth Shakespeare Theater); Breaking Legs (Ocean State Theater Company); Look for her this fall in the film, 21 Brides starring Chadwick Boseman.

 

Director: Ezra Barnes 

Ezra Barnes is the Founder of Shakespeare on the Sound and served as its Artistic Director for thirteen seasons. He received the 2018 Connecticut Critics Circle Award for Outstanding Director for Diary of Anne Frank at Playhouse on Park. Actor with numerous Off-B’way credits (Breakfast With Mugabe, To Kill a Mockingbird, etc.).         

 

 

Playwright: Michael Shenefelt  

Michael Shenefelt teaches philosophy at Liberal Studies, New York University and is the author of The Questions of Moral Philosophy (Prometheus) and co-author of If A, Then B: How the World Discovered Logic (Columbia University Press).  An earlier version of HELOISE was a semi-finalist at the National Playwrights Conference at the Eugene O'Neill Theatre Center.

 

 

Sean Edward Evans* as Abelard  

Sean Edward Evans is a New York-based actor from Los Angeles. His recent stage work includes "Conrad" in Aaron Posner's Stupid Fucking Bird, "Camillo" in Shakespeare's The Winter's Tale and  “Cohen” in Steve Martin’s The Underpants where he was nominated for a Broadway World Regional Award for Best Actor. Studio trained, Sean has starred in many independent shorts and web series including “The Mailroom,” directed by Sarah Hamblin (The Daily Show With Trevor Noah.)

 

Michael Sean McGuinness* as Fulbert 

Michael Sean McGuinness earned a BFA in Acting from New York University's Tisch School of the Arts and also studied with famed acting teacher Stella Adler. In his career as an actor in New York and regional theatres, he played such roles as Iago in "Othello", Andrei in "The Three Sisters" and Algernon in "The Importance of Being Earnest" at such as theatres as The Classic Stage Company, The Pearl Theatre Company, The Philadelphia Drama Guild, Portland Stage Company and A Noise Within. Recent film and television appearances include Bowes Academy, The Good Fight, New Amsterdam, and The Blacklist.

 

Anthony Michael Martinez* as Alberic 

Anthony Michael Martinez is a NYC-based actor who has performed Off-Broadway, regionally, and abroad: Romeo & Juliet (Classic Stage Company) dir. Tea Alagíc);I'll Be Damned (Vineyard Theatre); Restoration Comedy (Flea Theater,dir. Ed Iskandar); Marat/Sade (New Ohio).He holds a MFA in Acting from Shakespeare Theatre Company’s Academy for Classical Acting at The George Washington University, and a BA in Theatre from Florida State University.  Anthony was recently cast in Native Gardens at Florida Repertory Theatre, playing Pablo Del Valle! This past summer, he played Will Shakespeare in Illinois Shakespeare Festival's Shakespeare In Love, directed by Marti Lyons.

 

Damani Varnado* as Bishop of Paris   

Damani Varnado is a N.Y.C based Actor, Performer and Voice over Artist. He started his training under the tutelage of James Dunn, at The College of Marin, where his focus was Shakespeare. He received scholarships from Irene Ryan and Robin Williams, to attended North Carolina School of the Art’s. Damani focused his training in Theatre, Film and Movement.

 

 

Jay William Thomas* as Bernard  

An Actor, Writer, and Producer who grew up in Kentucky, where he began acting at an early age. Jay William Thomas attended Western Kentucky University and obtained a BFA double Major in Acting and Directing. Jay has worked on stage, film, & television. Recently Jay worked with NBC Universal and PipeLine entertainment on a remake of Francis Ford Coppola's Dementia 13..

 

 

William Brenner* as William of Champeaux  

Off-Broadway: Incident at Vichy (Jewish Rep); David Edgar’s Mary Barnes (New York premiere); Visions of Kerouac; Marathon ’33 (Lion Theatre Company). Regional: Denver Center Theatre Company; Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park; Shakespeare Festival of Dallas; GeVa Theatre, Rochester, others. He is a member of the Brooklyn-based site-specific Brave New World Repertory Theatre, for whom he has played Giles Corey in The Crucible, Gonzalo in The Tempest, and Justice Shallow in The Merry Wives of Windsor (Terrace). Mr. Brenner is a baritone who sings with Grace Chorale of Brooklyn.

 

Marika Proctor* as Sister Gertrude 

Marika Proctor's credits include: As You Like It (Guthrie Theater); You Across From Me - 42nd Humana Festival, A Christmas Carol (Actors Theatre of Louisville); Ken Ludwig’s Baskerville (Park Square Theater); One Man, Two Guvnors (Yellow Tree Theatre), Twelfth Night, The Tempest, A Midsummer Night’s Dream, Julius Caesar (Classical Actors Ensemble); June (Umbrella Collective). She was a member of the Professional Training Company at the Actors Theatre of Louisville and has written and performed her original character-driven pieces: “Otto in D Major” and “Pete Presents” in New York and regionally.

 

Lauren Pisano as the Novitiate 

Lauren Pisano is an actress and model based in New York, NY. She has trained and performed internationally on stage and film. Born in Mississippi, Lauren grew up a 'military brat', living all across the US. She attended Le Moyne College in Syracuse, NY where she received a BA in Communications with a Minor in Theatre Arts. Following graduation, she uprooted to London to attend East 15 Acting School on the two year MFA Acting International course. This training included a residency at Shakespeare's Globe Theatre as well as with The Russian University of Theatre Arts (GITIS, Moscow). Lauren has since worked in Independent film, commercials, voice over, and regional theatre.

 

* These Actors are appearing courtesy of Actors' Equity Association. This is an Equity approved Showcase production.

 

Casting Director: Jessi Blue Gormezano 

Jessi Blue Gormezano has casted numerous Off-Broadway, Off-Off Broaway, Regional, and International plays. Her awards and honors include the Drama League Nomination for Best Supporting Actress in The Dingdong; NY Times Critic's Pick for Public Enemy; and  Stupid Fu**ing Bird, winner of Fringe First, Edinburgh Fringe Shortlisted for the Freedom of Expression Award 2015 by Amnesty International Trans Scripts.

 

 

 

Costume Designer: Lisa Renee Jordan 

Lisa Renee Jordan's elected design credits include: Fetes de la Nuit (Ohio Theatre); Drama Desk Nomination – Outstanding Theatrical Experience; Beloved (Scandanavian American Theatre Company); The Plantation (Brave New World– Governor’s Island); Shesh Yak (Rattlestick); Temple of the Souls, (MultiStages); Romeo & Juliet (Bryant Park Shakespeare); Witching Hour, and Triangle (Williamstown Theatre Festival);  Neglect, and Thicker than Water (EST); Lysystrata (Edinburgh Fringe);  Member of United Scenic Artists Local 829. 

 

 

Set Designer: Jennifer Varbalow 

Jen Varbalow has been a Teaching Artist, Scenic Artist and Scenic Designer in NYC for over 20 years. She is currently a teaching artist with Inside Broadway, Roundabout Theatre Company, and Town Hall. Past credits include designs for New York Deaf Theater, NYMF, MultiStages, The Workshop Theater, Bryant Park, Drilling Company/Shakespeare in the Parking Lot, Resonance Ensemble, The Artful Conspirators, Ensemble Studio Theatre, Theatre Garden, Pulse Ensemble Theatre, DR2 Theatre, Queens Theatre in the Park. Jennifer has also worked as a designer on the animated Xmas windows at Macy’s Saks, Lord and Taylor, Warner Bros and Marshall Fields. She worked as a Scenic Artist at The Public Theater, Manhattan Theater Club and various scene shops.

 

Lighting: Joyce Liao 

Joyce Liao won an Peggy Ezekiel Award for Outstanding Achievement in Lighting Design. Her lighting design helped Soul of Shaolin garner a Tony nomination in the category of Special Theatrical Event and a Drama Desk award, Unique Theatrical Experience.

 

 

Production Manager: Montgomery Mauro 

Montgomery Mauro is an Actor, Director, Producer and the Co-Founder of No2Mauro Productions. His extensive knowledge in production has enabled him to work in almost every facet of production in film, TV and Off-Broadway theater. Montgomery has successfully produced, managed, and executed a varied portfolio of live events such as Off-Broadway and Off-Off Broadway plays, and Film Festivals. 

 

 

 

Co-Producer: Heidi White                                                             

Heidi White has a doctorate in philosophy from the New School for Social Research.  She teaches philosophy and intellectual history at Liberal Studies, New York University and is co-author of If A, Then B: How the World Discovered Logic (Columbia University Press).  She serves as an NYU Faculty Senator and as chair of the Politics, Rights, and Development concentration. She is a recipient of the NYU Distinguished Teaching Award and is a former U.S. Peace Corps Volunteer.

Jen Varbalow has been a Teaching Artist, Scenic Artist and Scenic Designer in NYC for over 20 years. She is currently a teaching artist with Inside Broadway, Roundabout Theatre Company, and Town Hall. Past credits include designs for New York Deaf Theater, NYMF, MultiStages, The Workshop Theater, Bryant Park, Drilling Company/Shakespeare in the Parking Lot, Resonance Ensemble, The Artful Conspirators, Ensemble Studio Theatre, Theatre Garden, Pulse Ensemble Theatre, DR2 Theatre, Queens Theatre in the Park. Jennifer has also worked as a designer on the animated Xmas windows at Macy’s Saks, Lord and Taylor, Warner Bros and Marshall Fields. She worked as a Scenic Artist at The Public Theater, Manhattan Theater Club and various scene shops.
 
Lighting: Joyce Liao 
Joyce Liao won an Peggy Ezekiel Award for Outstanding Achievement in Lighting Design. Her lighting design helped Soul of Shaolin garner a Tony nomination in the category of Special Theatrical Event and a Drama Desk award, Unique Theatrical Experience.
 
 
Production Manager: Montgomery Mauro 
Montgomery Mauro is an Actor, Director, Producer and the Co-Founder of No2Mauro Productions. His extensive knowledge in production has enabled him to work in almost every facet of production in film, TV and Off-Broadway theater. Montgomery has successfully produced, managed, and executed a varied portfolio of live events such as Off-Broadway and Off-Off Broadway plays, and Film Festivals. 
 
 
 
Co-Producer: Heidi White                                                              
Heidi White has a doctorate in philosophy from the New School for Social Research.  She teaches philosophy and intellectual history at Liberal Studies, New York University and is co-author of If A, Then B: How the World Discovered Logic (Columbia University Press).  She serves as an NYU Faculty Senator and as chair of the Politics, Rights, and Development concentration. She is a recipient of the NYU Distinguished Teaching Award and is a former U.S. Peace Corps Volunteer.

story:
Short Summary

The Show

In the aftermath of her father’s death, a young woman revisits their past conversations to seek advice and remember his legacy. This is her true story of grief, self discovery, coming of age, and womanhood.

The Process

When I was 19 and home on Thanksgiving break from my freshmen year at college, my father was dying of colon cancer. One Monday evening, he went to the hospital, and my mother told me his time was near and that the next day he said he needed to talk with me. The next morning, I woke up and found out he had died. I never knew what he wanted to talk with me about. I never got to have a last conversation with him. This show centers on this theme of what that last conversation could have been. 

Later that summer, I was an intern with the Ojai Playwrights Conference and began to write about him, and then the inspiration for this show hit. At Kenyon College, I finished writing the first draft and performed a stage reading of the show to a fully sold out crowd and received a standing ovation. After graduation, I began to rewrite and edit, and held small readings of the play in Portland, Los Angeles, and Washington DC to receive additional feedback and notes. 

Three years after the starting to write, I am pleased to announce the show will have a run at Capital Fringe this summer. 

What We Need & What You Get

Where will your money go?

  • The artists. I have made it a priority to pay all my artists a full wage for their work to reflect the hard work they are putting into this process
  • Fringe Costs- the Fringe Participation Fee and Insurance
  • Publicity Costs
  • Rehearsal space, set costs, other production costs

Who are we?

Playwright/Actor/ Choreographer: Natasha Preston is an actress, playwright, and choreographer based in Washington DC. Her regional credits include work with TBD Immersive, Annapolis Shakespeare Company, LiveArt DC, Capital Fringe, and Maryland Ensemble Theater. Her New York credits include performing at the Brick Theater in Brooklyn with the In Scena Italian Theater Festival. She has completed internships with the Ojai Playwrights Conference, The Blank Theatre, and Skylight Theater in Los Angeles. She currently teaches playwriting with Acting for Young People and works in the administrative staff at Anacostia Playhouse. A current student at the Studio Acting Conservatory, she also has trained at the Stella Adler Studio of Acting in New York, Gately/Poole Studio of Acting in Chicago, and at her alma mater Kenyon College. Her work can be found at natashapreston.net

Director: Clancey Yovanovich

Choreographer: Ian Edwards

Stage Manager: Julia Colpitts is a D.C.-based stage manager, prop designer, and theater technician. Her favorite stage management credits include: Dead Dog’s Bone(Nu Sass), Grand Concourse(TheatreLAB, Richmond Theatre Critics Circle Awards for Best Play and Best Direction), and Dry Land(Stage Femmes). During their time at Kenyon, Julia had the honor of working with Natasha many times including her first stage management project!

Poster Design: Hannah Day Sweet

Featuring song performed by: Elizabeth Woolf

The Impact

Why is Conversations unique? Why is this show important?

  • The show is a young woman's story. It centers on themes such as grief, cancer, eating disorders, relationships, sexual assault, LGBT+ identity, and womanhood. Supporting women, trans, and non binary playwrights is integral- currently, plays written by womxn account for only 29 percent of all plays produced. 
  • The creative team is made almost entirely of womxn+ artists, and this was a priority in my hiring process.
  • After a successful run at Fringe, it is a goal of mine to bring this story to schools as part of education programs with young women to teach and inspire them to share their own stories.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to give money, we are happy to have your support in other ways! 

  • Share this campaign to your friends!
  • Like and follow Conversations on Facebook and Instagram. Share information about the show- be sure to tag #capfringe19, #conversations19 and #conversationsfringe
  • Come to the show! 
  • We are also looking for set pieces- 1) a light twin metal bed frame and mattress 2) a light desk
  • If you know of womxn owned businesses in DC that may be interested in partnering with this organization, send them our way!
  • I will be dedicating each performance to a different charity/ non-profit of my choice that has issues pertaining to the show, and will collect donations from audience members to donate to these organizations. If you know of or are part of an organization that could be of interest, please send them to me! Specific areas of interest include causes related to: Cancer research, LGBT+, sexual assault victims, eating disorder, and female, trans, and non binary artist funds. 

Thank you so much! And stay tuned- we have so many exciting announcements and gifts coming next month!

story:
Rock Theatre Co. (RTC) has teamed with Third Kid Productions (TKP) to create Gee Willikers, Space! A musical-comedy about space, as imagined the 1950s. The show will be performed at the new Renegade Studios in Vancouver from May 6th – 12th 2013.

RTC has previously produced (in Vancouver) the hit show, A Shpadoinkle Musical Tribute. This was a tribute of songs to the writers Matt Stone and Trey Parker. It was sold out beyond capacity, and patrons continue to ask us for more. We’d like to comply! Gee Willikars, Space! promises to be hilarious with amazing songs that you’ll want to take home with you.

Joining RTC is Third Kid Productions, a production company that hails from Toronto and is responsible for Missed Connections, a musical-comedy based on the want ads in newspapers. The show was honoured to win Best of the Fest in the Bad Dog Short Play Festival, and the Patrons Pick Award at the Hamilton Fringe. The show was picked up by Theatre Aquarius in Hamilton to do a week-long run to virtually sold-out houses. For more on TKP, visit www.thirdkid.weebly.com

This campaign is to help us raise money to put on an amazing, home-grown musical, that just might turn out to be the next big thing. Canadian written and produced shows are incredibly important to Canadian theatre and artists. The reason it’s relatively unheard-of is because producing a show, even an independent production, can cost upwards of $15,000.00.

We need your help in curbing some of those costs by sponsoring our company and this new musical. Even the smallest amount makes a big difference. Your support will help to remind us that everyone out there wants to keep enjoying new and exciting works in Canadian theatre and that people care about the growth and development of their fellow artists. Let’s show Broadway that they’re not the only ones who can produce great musicals!

Gee Willikers, Space! won’t stop after just one run. We plan to take this show across Canada, to both entertain and inspire other artists to create their own work, because Canadians are funny! And talented! And it’s about time the rest of the world knew it too.

Who Is Rock Theatre Co?

Katherine Stadel Artistic Director

Katherine’s recent directing projects include Mrs. Bob Cratchit’s Wild Christmas Binge by Christopher Durang with Vagabond Players New Westminster, Robinson Crusoe with White Rock Players, Glory’s Grace by KJ Allamby at Theatre Passe Muraille (Toronto), The Fever by Wallace Shawn at the Cameron House (Toronto), Lost Souls and Missing Persons by Sally Clark at the Alchemy Theatre (Toronto) and Mrs. Bob Cratchits Wild Christmas Bingeat the Diesel Playhouse (Toronto).

Katherine was the Artistic Director of EBD Productions in Toronto which later became Rock Theatre Co.  She spent four years working for The Second City and has recently moved back to Vancouver to continue a career in theatre with the Arts Club Theatre Company.

Prior to moving to Toronto, Katherine spent some time in Hollywood working for the director, McG and his company, Wonderland Sound and Vision.  At that time, The O.C. was producing its second season.  While working in film and television Katherine also directed Jacob Richmond’s award-winning play Lego Land at the MET Theatre in North Hollywood.

Toni Maggio Writer

Joining Rock Theatre Co. is writer/actor Toni Maggio of Third Kid Productions, who has written Missed Connections and Jump! A Musical From the Ledge.

Toni graduated from the University of Toronto and Sheridan College with a Specialist Degree in Theatre and Drama studies. She then went on to graduate from The Second City Conservatory of Comedy. Toni has performed works of comedy all around Toronto, and is pretty darn excited to hop on a plane and join Katherine in Vancouver!

What We Need & What You Get

We’re hoping to raise $5,000.00 to help with our costs. This money will go directly towards performance venue rental, rehearsal space rental, and marketing. Any help you provide will be rewarded with some rock star gifts of gratitude.

But hey, we get it; sometimes you just don’t have the extra bucks to spare. That’s okay! Please support us by letting your friends know about our campaign, come and see one of our shows, or let your friends know about our shows! Use the share tools indiegogo has to offer. All it takes is a click.

story:
Celestine Rae, Writer and Director, is gearing up to present the premier production of her play Velvet Rope!!!

 

Nominated for Best Production of a Staged Reading with The Planet Connections Theatre Festivity 2012, Velvet Rope was accepted into the festival this year as a full production. 

Celestine Rae is an actress whose desire to create her own work led her to explore writing. Her passion for telling stories with complex female characters lends itself to  Velvet Rope, a provocative and controversial play about a young college women's studies major whose curiosity about the world of stripping leads her to pose as an "experienced" stripper at the local club. Masking the experience as a "research project," what she finds leaves her questioning herself, her sexuality, and her understanding of this world of "fantasy."

How Your Donations Will Help

We need to raise money for:

  • Rehearsal Studio Rental (41/2 Week schedule/4 rehearsal days per week)
  • Minimal Set Pieces and Props
  • Costumes
  • Light Desgner Fee
  • Stage Manager Fee
  • Set Transportation (Zip Car Rental to transport set and props to and from theater)

 

Who we Are:

We are a small team with BIG talent, working hard to make magic happen. Turning Lemons into Lemonade... with your HELP of course!

 

Celestine Rae, writer, director of Velvet Rope

Jeminah Russell, Stage Manager

 

The Cast:

Kimberlee Monroe

Azariah Gunn

Alexis Kelley

Brynn Alexander

Samantha Strelitz

Craig Colasnti

 

 

Any Donations are Greatly Appreciated. We need to raise the full $3,500. This is our minimum budget. It's ALL or NOTHING BABY!!!

We value any financial contribution you can make.

Please feel free to spread the word!

Facebook, Twitter, word of mouth, and using the Indiegogo.com are all helpful ways to turn this play into a full production.

 

BECOME A PRODUCER TODAY of Velvet Rope

 

Much love, respect, & Gratitude

 

The Velvet Rope TEAM

story:
Having produced 5 acclaimed productions in 11 months time, the ReGroup Theatre eagerly anticipates one of their most challenging and powerful productions yet - THE HOUSE OF CONNELLY by Paul Green.

First presented as a sold out reading at the 180 seat 47th St Theatre in 2011. the response was so overwhelming, we look forward to bringing it to a full production.

Paul Green's poetic tale of the dueling South, past and present, was heraled by critics and audiences alike when it debuted in 1931. Will Connelly, the wayward heir to the once famous Connelly estate falls for the tenant farmer's daughter. Does she love him, or is she just after the family name? This epic tale of past versus the future and family secrets is as timely now as it was 80 years ago! Following Green's Pulitzer Prize Winning In Abraham's Bosom, this is another of Green's groundbreaking influence of giving African-Americans  leading roles in a Broadway show.

PLEASE, HELP US TO MAKE THIS HAPPEN!

story:
My High-Heeled Life:

Or, How I Learned to Keep Worrying and Love My Stilettos

Have you ever had an accidental orgasm in the shoe department? Or wondered when Uggs and flip-flops became acceptable dinner attire? In a world full of options, why do we opt to cope rather than celebrate? And how do we navigate our obsession with finding True Happiness? Perhaps it begins one pair of impossibly high stilettos at a time.

I’ve spent the last year developing and work-shopping a full-length version of my solo show, and am absolutely thrilled that I have a spot in the Toronto and Vancouver Fringe Festivals this summer! I’ve been gearing up for Vancouver since I got my spot in December, but just found out about Toronto 2 weeks ago (eek!)—and the festival is fast approaching. So I need your help to get me there! The next few months are going to be very busy; the Toronto Fringe runs July 3-14, then I’m back in New York for a spell and hoping to put the show up for a few nights in August, with Vancouver Fringe running September 5-15. With my production team in Toronto and me in New York, there are a lot of incidental and administrative expenses that are adding up, in addition to the big festival fees. Here are the specifics:

What We Need

You can contriubute any amount, and no amount is too small! Even $1 is a huge help, or choose one of our donation levels.

Your donation will help cover:

  • Airfare for me and my team
  • Toronto and Vancouver Fringe Festival Fees
  • Marketing/Promotional Materials
  • Rehearsal space rental
  • Theater rentals for performances in NYC
  • Director/Designer Stipends
  • Costumes/Props

What You’ll Get

In addition to my undying gratitude and fabulous karma, check out the perks we have for our various donation levels! 

Why Now? 

I started writing this show about women and cynicism and fabulous shoes over 5 years ago at the tail end of the Bush years— I wanted to write through the chaos and malaise and find a little bit of joy, a little humor, a little excuse to get together with an audience and have a good time sharing our misery. Plus—let’s be honest, I was sick of people treating me like a bimbo because I live in high heels. I’ve stepped away from the show for years at a time, but somehow keep getting drawn back. In a way, it feels we’re living at a time even more chaotic and unsettled now than we were at the end of the last decade. It’s really hard for me to turn the news on, and even harder for me to turn it off. And on top of everything, I feel I’m facing this constant battle about what it means to be a Real Woman—from Sheryl Sandberg and Hilary Clinton to the Kardashians to Beyonce to the too-many-to-name rape and assault victims being blamed and harassed even to the point of suicide—everywhere I look I see women either being  boxed in, or ripped to shreds any time they try to step outside a box. This is my little attempt to step outside.

How Else You Can Help

Come see our work! If you’re in Toronto or Vancouver or know people who are, spread the word about the show and the Fringe Festival. If you’re in New York, I’ll be sending out invites to workshop performances over the next few months and would love, love, love to see your faces there!

story:
The Project

Watch Me Productions is pleased to be remounting "Eyes of the Enemy" by Chris W. Cook.  After several successful fringe runs of the show, Watch Me Productions is partnering with Amnesty International to bring this dark, poignant, and increasingly relevent show to the Living Room Playhouse (Azimuth Theatre) June 27-29. 


By teaming up with Amnesty International, Watch Me Productions hopes to continue it's efforts to raise awareness and encourage discourse surrounding the use of and tacit approval of torture by Canada and its allies.

Watch Me Productions began preliminary work on Eyes of the Enemy in 2007.  Starting with research into the so-called “enhanced interrogation” methods used by NATO and its allies overseas.  We explored different ways to present these practices theatrically and Eyes of the Enemy soon began to take its present form. The stories of Maher Arar, Omar Kadr, and others demonstrate the brutality shown to Canadian citizens and the seeming complicity of the Canadian and American governments in these acts of torture.  We felt a calling to explore these issues on stage.  Eyes of the Enemy is a work of fiction, but is also a commentary of where we believe our country and our global society are headed. The slamming of Canada’s human rights record in 2011 by Amnesty International shows us an interesting and new era in Canadian history; one where torture is not unilaterally condemned, but under certain circumstances, condoned.  This is an alarming reality.

Eyes of the Enemy premiered at the 2011 Calgary International Fringe Festival and was produced again at the 2012 Edmonton International Fringe Festival to stellar reviews.   4.5 stars in the Edmonton Journal and several sellout performances combined with very positive community feedback from both runs led Watch Me Productions to embark on this remount of Eyes of the Enemy.

What We Need

We are asking for help in fundraising for this show for several reasons.  Firstly, Watch Me Productions has committed to donating 30% of our gross profits from this run to Amnesty International Edmonton.  We want to maximise the amount we can give Amnesty....so that's why we're asking for help.  If we can reach our campaign goal we can completely cover our production costs.  If those costs get covered, that means more money can go into the coffers of Amnesty.

 

Secondly, Watch Me is taking "Eyes of the Enemy" to the Vancouver International Fringe festival in September.  Any remaining profits we have after paying out to Amnesty will go directly towards helping us get out west.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell your friends about the show!  We only have 3 performances (and one preview if you can't make it during the run) so we need your help to put buts in seats. 

SHOW INFORMATION!

-          EYES OF THE ENEMY      -         

JUNE 27, 28, 29

8pm

LIVING ROOM PLAYHOUSE, 11315-106 ave

TICKETS: 15$ (10$ STUDENT/SENIOR)

CAST: EVAN HALL & CHRIS W. COOK

SOUND DESIGN: BRIAN BERGUM

WRITTEN BY: CHRIS W. COOK

DIRECTED BY: MATTHEW SLINGSBY

 

AMNESTY INTERNATIONAL

Amnesty International is a global movement of over 3 million people in more than 150 countries working together to protect and promote human rights.

We believe that we are at our most powerful when we stand together for human rights.  Each person, no matter who or where they are, can make change happen by acting in concert with others who share their vision of a world where everyone lives in dignity.

Members are the strength of our organization.  It is because so many people speak out for justice that Amnesty International is able to achieve remarkable things.

Amnesty International is an authoritative voice on human rights.  For over 50 years, we have provided the world with reliable and accurate information about human rights violations and international human rights laws and standards.

Amnesty International is independent of any government, political ideology, economic interest or religion.  We do not accept funding for our human rights research and campaigning work from any government.  Our work is supported by donations from individuals.

Amnesty International is impartial.  We hold all actors to the same obligations as defined in international human rights law and standards.  Our only goal is to ensure human rights are respected for everyone, everywhere

story:
Short Summary

Hi, I'm Nicola McEldowney: puppeteer, actress, playwright and onetime denizen of the Customer Service Desk at the supermarket. That last one was so far the best career move I ever made.

 Why, you ask? Because AISLE SIX, my musical based on the experience, has now made it into a fabulous pair of theatre festivals this summer! To wit:

 

SUPER DUPER STORE WORLD TOUR, 2013

San Diego Fringe Festival, San Diego, CA - July 5-7, 2013

FringeNYC - August 9-23, 2013

 

I'm beyond excited to work with two dynamite casts, and one evil puppet. But, to do so, I need funding! Currently, Aisle Six's entire capital comes from my personal pocket, which is all well and good (I love this musical more than I can possibly say) but also pretty ineffective (I have less money than I can possibly say).

Aisle Six, at this juncture, is the most important thing I have ever done. It is imperative that I be able to make it grow with new productions - new actors, sets, props and lights - and above all, new AUDIENCES. You will be helping me to bring my proudest accomplishment to life.

 

What We Need & What You Get

I am looking for a minimum of $3,600 (three thousand six hundred) USD to defray Aisle Six's combined production costs at the San Diego Fringe and FringeNYC festivals. Here is where the money will go:

- Insurance fees for FringeNYC (a few hundred dollars)

- Materials fees: these will go toward sets and props for all 3 productions, many of which are being built by actors

- If at all possible, defraying actors' gas costs

- Paying cast and crew a small stipend each for the immense trouble they've gone to for this show

- An advertisement in the NYC fringe program - the smallest of which (1/18 of a page) costs $180.

 Where do the funds go if I don't meet my entire goal? Believe me, to the exact same places. Just in smaller amounts. I am really, really hoping for larger ones. ;)

 

And now, the perks!

Oooh, this is my favorite part. OK. Here's just a small sampling of the goodies you can get if you contribute:

**Please note: if at ALL possible, I will get you TICKETS TO THE SHOW (1 ticket with a donation under $100, 2 tickets from $100-500, and 4 tickets with $500 or above) in addition to all of the perks below. But at this time, I do not know exactly how my securing tickets will work with regard to each festival. So I can't promise it. But know that I will do my best to try!**

- A show poster, signed by the author, director and cast (full disclosure: those first two people are both me)

- A personal thank-you postcard or letter from the fun folks at the Super Duper Store

- A copy of the Super Duper Store newsletter, "Gehenna, But With Sprite"

- Various Super Duper Store merchandise featuring Hondo the Evil Puppet

- Video greeting from Hondo, Melody and/or the Supermarket Fairy

- Official charter membership in the Supreme Order of the Super Duper Store (complete with certificate and other goodies), at the level of Trainee, Assistant Manager, Evil Puppet Manager, High Priest(ess) of Customer Service, District Manager, Non-Perishable Manager, Lord High Manager or Duane the Supermarket God.

- Super Duper Store paper dolls. OH YES.

- An amazing GIFT BASKET from the Super Duper Store featuring all kinds of goodies from Aisle Six

- Your very own evil puppet (or a nice one, if you're not into that kind of thing)

- Free puppet craft workshop or children's puppet performance

- And much more. Many surprises. Oh, so many surprises! (Promise. Not just gassing here.)

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute financially (and WHAT KIND OF UNFEELING MONSTER ARE YOU??!!! I SUPPOSE YOU'D HAVE ME BELIEVE YOU HAVE TO PAY "BILLS" OR SOMETHING?!?!), I humbly ask that you...

- Spread the word about Aisle Six and this campaign via social media

- Make some noise* in any other way possible!

* ...about this, I mean.

 

That's all, folks. Thank you, thank you, thank you. And remember: we're all in this together at the Super Duper Store.

Even if you can't contribute financially (and WHAT KIND OF UNFEELING MONSTER ARE YOU??!!! I SUPPOSE YOU'D HAVE ME BELIEVE YOU HAVE TO PAY "BILLS" OR SOMETHING?!?!), I humbly ask that you...

story:
Who We Are

Chris Coculuzzi and Roxanne Deans are Toronto-based artists that have worked together for twenty years. They are currently collaborating on projects that promote women as subjects rather than objects.

Piecing Together Pauline is a new herstorical drama about opera singer Pauline Garcia Viardot (1821-1910): a charismatic personality and performer who was arguably the foundation for the modern artist and career woman.

Piecing Together Pauline will premiere at the 2012 Toronto Fringe Festival, featuring Genie Award and Actra Award nominee Elva Mai Hoover and Kristen Zaza sharing the title role. The show also includes performances by Bil Antoniou, Tara Baxendale, Rob Candy, Stephen Flett, Damien Gulde, Chris Irving, Alex Karolyi, Scott McCulloch, Shannon Shura, Brenda Somers, Steve Switzman, and Blake Thorne playing notable artists of the day, including George Sand, Frederic Chopin, Charles Gounod, Hector Berlioz, Ivan Turgenev, Maria Malibran and Ary Scheffer.

What We Need

While keeping the production values simple, Piecing Together Pauline is a large cast, period play. Your donations will help defray the cost of the following:
  • Costumes, Set and Properties
  • Rehearsal space fees
  • Printing of promotional material

Why You Should Give

Perhaps the strongest moral reason for this play now is not in the particular story of Pauline Viardot, but in the universal telling of a story with a strong female protagonist as subject and not as object. It is a sad truism that women are continually objectified in media and theatre is no exception. If nothing else, Pauline Viardot is a strong female role model for men and women. The men that fell in love with Pauline did so because of her intellect and artistic abilities and definitely NOT for her features. Where are such female role models today? More importantly, where and what in the culture is promoting such concepts of womanhood?

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word and come and see the show at the Tarragon Main Space, 30 Bridgman Ave during these times:

  • Thurs, July 5 at 8:15pm
  • Sat, July 7 at 5:15pm
  • Sun, July 8 at 10:00pm
  • Tues, July 10 at 10:30pm
  • Wed, July 11 at Noon
  • Thurs, July 12 at 7:30pm
  • Sun, July 15 at 5:15pm
For more information visit: www.fireandair.ca

story:
Help an Extremely Talented Young Dancer                      Achieve her Dreams!                              

She is 15 years old and has dedicated her life to dance. She has had the support and love of her family, wonderful teachers, and the community throughout her journey. She continues to grow with each year, but has now reached the upper limits of what she can achieve here in our small town of Ashland, Oregon. Over the last 8 years she has generously received a full scholarship at her present dance studio based on need, ability, and dedication. We want to see her continue to shine, but we will need the help and support of the community to provide her with the opportunity that she needs to move forward!  

         

The next step is stepping up her training to a professional level. Along with this comes the inevitable move for our close knit family of 4 from our small Oregon town to the land of dreams and opportunity...Southern California! We are ready to move (into a small apartment if needed) in order to give Nashalah a chance to train, get into a performing arts high school, and expand her possibilities to that of a professional dancer's reality! Additionally, being in this environment she will be able to take advantage of opportunities to attend professional dance events that expose her to the dance industry on a more personal level.

Click on the following link to view a music video produced by Jacy Mairs starring Nashalah for a competition hosted by Genero for 'This Place Is A Shelter' by Olafur Arnalds:

 

Click on 'Gallery' tab at the top of the page to see additional images!

She has a gift! Help give her the opportunity to cultivate her natural given talent and become the best possible dancer she can be! This will not only create a future for her, but will also create an outpouring of goodness back into the world through the joy and emotion she gives through her performances. In addition to her dreams as a professional dancer,she hopes to one day teach non-profit dance classes to children in need, nurturing their passion for dance and artistic expression. Help give wings to pursue her lifelong journey with dance...She will soar!

                        

 With your contributions you will help provide:

-Tuition for her first year or more of professional level training at a great dance  school with over 30 specialized teachers that help students make it in their field. In this environment, she will be able to nurture her artistic expression while being surrounded by teachers and students who are just as passionate about what they are doing as she is!

-Audition/performance material and fees

-Costume fees, dance shoes, dance apparel, and other dance supplies  

-Give her the possibility to be in the professional dance industry by helping fund the necessary move to Southern California

 All of this would not be possible for us to do without the help of the community! We want you to know the need is real; we are a low-income family with lots of love, but without the financial means. Help us make this dream become a reality through the gift of showing a young girl that dreams are worth believing!  

Contribute if you can, and pass this campaign along to anyone you know who can help!

story:
Short Summary:

Importance of Touch, sites specific work by Sandra Atkinson (in collaboration with dancers). The 30 minute work explores the notion of touch in all mediums in an age of technology. Investigating whether we as a society are more comfortable with touch technology rather than the human touch. We play with reaction, intention and connection through movement and music.

Live Music by Meredith Blanchard
Dancers: Sandra Atkinson, Briana Carper, Holly Jones, Ramon Munoz, Nick Peters, Shannon Quinn, Kyle Sanders, Claire Smith

 

What We Need & What You Get

The funds your provide will go to: 

  • Rehearsal stipend for dancers and musician
  • Performance pay for dancers and musician
  • Costumes
  • Food and drinks for dancers the day of the tour
  • Transportation cost for dancers and musician the day of the tour

 

The Impact

The mission of Light Switch Dance Theatre is to perform in non-traditional spaces to provide dance to the general public. We want people to have the opportunity to view dance in a public space then have access to the performance but the choreographer, dacners and musicians to open up discussion about dance as an art. Touch is an important element to life and this piece explores that idea and we want the public to join in our discussion.  

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word about the 6 lcoation in 1 day tour
  • Come out and see it yourself 
  • Let us know your opinion about human connection and it's impact via at the performance, Twitter or Facebook.
