story:
Support and endorse the production COMPANY, the Riverdale Repertory Company and its Riverdale Rising Stars! Take out an ad or sponsorship. Please email your comments to Marilyn Raider (mraider@riverdaley.org), or post them on this Indiegogo site.

Thank you ever so much for your help to support the best performing arts department in town!!

 

Come and see "COMPANY" !!

Riverdale Repertory Company, the adult branch of the Rising Stars performing arts program at the Riverdale Y, proudly presents the Tony Award-winning musical COMPANY for a strictly limited run of four performances, from February 2 to 10, 2013 – Saturdays at 8pm, and Sundays at 3pm.

 

Performances will be held at the Riverdale YM-YWHA, located at 5625 Arlington Avenue (just off of Riverdale Avenue and West 256th Street), in Riverdale, Bronx, NY.  

 

Tickets are $20 for adults and $12 for seniors and students if purchased online, or $22 for adults and $14 for seniors and students if purchased at the door prior to showtime.  Tickets are also available by calling 718.548.8200 ext 0.  For group sales, please email performingarts@riverdaley.org.

 

ABOUT THE SHOW

On the eve of his thirty-fifth birthday, a Manhattan bachelor examines his relationships with those good and crazy people, his married friends.   Ruefully hilarious and refreshingly honest, Stephen Sondheim’s sophisticated musical masterpiece COMPANY takes a kaleidoscopic view of love and adult commitment, and asks what it really means to be alive.

Directed by Greg Kanter, choreographed by Catherine Schwartz, and with music direction by Justin Fischer, COMPANY features a cast of Riverdale Rep veterans from Riverdale, Yonkers, Upper Manhattan, and beyond, including:

  • Ronnie Becher

  • Courtney Cahen

  • Wylie Cohen

  • Jim DeBlasi

  • Eric Dinowitz

  • Patrick Dwyer

  • Elaine Helmrich

  • Sabrina Landau

  • Corrie Lebens

  • Leo Lopez

  • Luz Montez

  • Marilyn Raider

  • Catherine Schwartz

  • Sam Yaggy 

 

The design team includes:

  • David Pentz (lighting)

  • Denise Eberly (sound)
story_txt:
Support and endorse the production COMPANY, the Riverdale Repertory Company and its Riverdale Rising Stars! Take out an ad or sponsorship. Please email your comments to Marilyn Raider (mraider@riverdaley.org), or post them on this Indiegogo site.
Thank you ever so much for your help to support the best performing arts department in town!!
 
Come and see "COMPANY" !!


Riverdale Repertory Company, the adult branch of the Rising Stars performing arts program at the Riverdale Y, proudly presents the Tony Award-winning musical COMPANY for a strictly limited run of four performances, from February 2 to 10, 2013 – Saturdays at 8pm, and Sundays at 3pm. 

 
Performances will be held at the Riverdale YM-YWHA, located at 5625 Arlington Avenue (just off of Riverdale Avenue and West 256th Street), in Riverdale, Bronx, NY.  
 
Tickets are $20 for adults and $12 for seniors and students if purchased online, or $22 for adults and $14 for seniors and students if purchased at the door prior to showtime.  Tickets are also available by calling 718.548.8200 ext 0.  For group sales, please email performingarts@riverdaley.org.
 
ABOUT THE SHOW
On the eve of his thirty-fifth birthday, a Manhattan bachelor examines his relationships with those good and crazy people, his married friends.   Ruefully hilarious and refreshingly honest, Stephen Sondheim’s sophisticated musical masterpiece COMPANY takes a kaleidoscopic view of love and adult commitment, and asks what it really means to be alive.
Directed by Greg Kanter, choreographed by Catherine Schwartz, and with music direction by Justin Fischer, COMPANY features a cast of Riverdale Rep veterans from Riverdale, Yonkers, Upper Manhattan, and beyond, including:


Ronnie Becher


Courtney Cahen




Wylie Cohen


Jim DeBlasi


Eric Dinowitz


Patrick Dwyer


Elaine Helmrich


Sabrina Landau


Corrie Lebens


Leo Lopez


Luz Montez


Marilyn Raider


Catherine Schwartz 


Sam Yaggy 


 
The design team includes:



David Pentz (lighting)



Denise Eberly (sound)

story:
My Story

For those that don't know me, my name is Monica Rounds and I am a New York City based actor carving my path in this crazy business. I grew up in the t.v. generation loving all things tv & film, dreaming of being of part of it but never really knowing where to start. I am the child of a career military serviceman which, unbeknownst to me, was setting me to be able to immerse myself in different worlds. I went down the typical path of high school then headed off to college but knew I was not your typical gal. Something was missing and so began my quest! From the moment I stepped on the stage the 1st time I knew that this was what I was meant to do!Moving to New York six years ago was a big step for me. I have made some excellent strides but as we all know, life sometimes intervenes and takes you on a path you may not have expected. So at the beginning of this year I set out to achieve some lofty goals to continue in the pursuit of my passions. One of those was to apply/audition for the Williamstown Theatre Festival. The Summer Theatre Festival www.wtfestival.org (for those who may not know) is very prestegous and offers an artist the opportunity to work with some of the best in the business through stage work, classes, and production work both on and off stage!

The Impact/What I Need/What You Get

A couple of weeks ago, I received the exciting news that I had been accepted into the Aprrentice Program for Williamstown! That's 9 weeks of be immersed in all things theatre in the Bershires of Massachusettes! Then reality kicked in. The program is not cheap; $4000 to be exact but I know (and several friends have reiterated) that this is an opportunity that I've been given and should not pass up! The $4000 is for room/board, classes & training, meals, and housing. The Universe is aligning things in my favor, but I still have a long way to go. I am working extra shifts at both my jobs (yes, every actor has 12 jobs otherwise we go crazy!) to raise as much money as I possibly can to cover what I need for the tuition & extra expenses. Here's where you can help. I'm not asking for a lot; just give up one latte. ONE LATTE to help an artist pursue her dreams. Even if I don't reach my goal, I am still able to keep anything contributed. No donation is too small and every dollar raised is greatly appreciated!

Because this is such a unique opportunity, I want everyone to be a part of my experience!

For any donation up to $25 you get:

  • My heartfelt gratitude expressed through an individualized email
  • Bi-weekly updates on my progress, activities, & festival news
  • Good karma from the Universe for helping a fellow human being

$26 - $99 donations receive:

  • All of the above
  • Personalized thank you card
  • Photo updates
  • Blog recognition and links to new entries

Donations of $100 or more:

  • All of the above
  • Personal phone call from little ol' me!
  • Mention in bio for any Williamstown productions that I am a part of

I know that as much as everyone would love to help, sometimes you just can't contribute. But there are other things you can do:

  • Tell you friends! If you got this far, you probably like me so please feel to share. I need all the help I can get!
  • Send prayers, good vibes, kind words, and warm wishes. This is an exciting & scary time for me and all the good energy I can get the better.
  • Feel free to post on facebook, twitter, or your social platform of choice. Again, every dollar helps!

Thanks so much for reading and being a part of my journey!

 

With sincere gratitude,

Monica :)

story:
Our Story

The Way of Water is a play that pits the BP oil spill next to the lives of those affected by it. It's a story about four people making do as best they can, living their lives, and just trying to stay afloat in the land of many compromised dreams, as the devastation of a to-this-day mostly under-reported health crisis scandal in the Gulf is played out on a human scale. It's a play about poverty in America, rumors and truth, what is said and what gets written, and the quest for an honorable life.


NoPassport theatre alliance and press in collaboration with multiple venues across the US and abroad present free readings of the play in the month of April 2012 to mark the two year anniversary of the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico and raise awareness in regards to human health and environmental damage issues as a result of the Deepwater Horizon disaster.


Why a Reading Scheme Now?

NoPassport theatre alliance and press is committed to the advocacy, promotion, production and publication of creative expressions of diversity and difference in theatre and performance. It is also committed to interventionist actions through theatre-making in culture toward peace, healing, forgiveness, positive action, and resistance to uncivil actions.

The effect on human health on residents in the Gulf of Mexico region, as result of excessive use of toxic dispersant and toxic rain during the BP oil spill clean-up, has resulted in thousands of reported illnesses and deaths, and hundreds of lawsuits against BP that have yet been resolved.

Awareness to the effect on health, way of life and living, endangerment to livelihood of commercial fishermen, and the increased fragility of indigenous and Creole communities in the region is part of this schemeâ€™s community-action goals.

How can theatre transform and speak poetically to our lives? How can we let art live within us and see our world anew? How to continue to engage civically in the nexus between art and practice and life?

NoPassport asks these questions with any conference, reading, publication , open mic or scholars symposium it forges into action. The same is true with this scheme.



What We Need

We are attempting to raise $2,500 to cover travel expenses and production costs for the reading series.  As of now, we are relying entirely on public support for the base costs of putting together a nationwide project.  With readings in major cities all over the US, we hope to reach as many people as possible, and to do this we need your help.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please inform others about the reading series in April! We are continuing to add venues across the United States,

THE WAY OF WATER

By Caridad Svich

â€œMan canâ€™t get sick in this country.â€

 

For more information: http://www.nopassport.org/

Who We Are


Cariâ€‹dad Svich is a US Latina playwright, translator, lyricist and editor. She received the 2011 American Theatre Critics Association Primus Prize for her play The House of the Spirits, based on the novel by Isabel Allende. Her works have been presented across the US and abroad at diverse venues, including Denver Center Theatre, Mixed Blood Theatre, Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park, Repertorio Espanol, 59East59, McCarren Park Pool, 7 Stages, Salvage Vanguard Theatre, Teatro Mori (Santiago, Chile), ARTheater (Cologne), and Edinburgh Fringe Festival/UK. She has been short-listed for the PEN Award in Drama three times, including in the year 2010 for her play Instructions for Breathing. Among her key works:12 Ophelias, Alchemy of Desire/Dead-Man's Blues, Any Place But Here, Iphigenia...a rave fable, Fugitive Pieces, In the Time of the Butterflies (based on Julia Alvarezâ€™s novel), Magnificent Waste, and the multimedia collaboration The Booth Variations. She was recently profiled in American Theatre magazine. She has edited several books on theatre including Trans-Global Readings and Theatre in Crisis? (both for Manchester University Press) and Divine Fire (BackStage Books). She is alumna playwright of New Dramatists, founder of NoPassport theatre alliance & press, associate editor of Routledge/UK's Contemporary Theatre Review, Drama Editor of literary journal Asymptote(www.asymptotejournal.com) and contributing editor of TheatreForum. She holds an MFA in Theatre-Playwriting from UCSD. Website: http://www.caridadsvich.com

Dramaturg:

Heather Helinsky received her MFA in Dramaturgy from the American Repertory Theatre/MXAT Institute for Advanced Theatre Training at Harvard University. At the American Repertory Theater, she dramaturged for directors Robert Woodruff, Krystian Lupa, Scott Zigler, Marcus Stern, and Sasha Marin. In season 2008-2009, she worked as Resident Dramaturg at Pittsburgh Public Theater, where she organized events for the celebration of the final play of the August Wilson Cycle as well as the premiere of Edgerton grant play Harry's Friendly Service. In season 2009-2010, she worked with director Austin Pendleton on Terrence McNally's new play Golden Age at Philadelphia Theatre Company. Heather is dedicated to developing new American plays and reads for organizations like Sundance Theatre Lab, Great Plains Theatre Conference, PlayPenn and many others. Nationally, she has been developing new plays with Constance Congdon, Caridad Svich, Tom Gibbons, Toni Press-Coffman, Rob Zellers, Ellen Struve, and Matthew Ivan Bennett. She has been a member of LMDA since 2006. Website: www.

Assistant Dramaturg:  

R. Alex Davis graduated in 2009 from Bard College with a B.A. in Playwriting. His thesis play, Endless Carnations, was produced at Bard and directed by Claudia Zelevanksy. Alex is a founding member of Rogue Company, a division of Raleigh-based BARE Theater, dedicated to the performance of classical texts. As an actor, he has also performed the works of Shakespeare, Arthur Miller, Brecht, and others in numerous theatrical productions. In 2010, Alex co-produced a festival of plays by Jean Genet, including his own adaptation of Genet's Deathwatch, at Triskelion Arts in Brooklyn. Most recently, he worked as a production assistant on Phillip Glass and Robert Wilson's Einstein on the Beach. Other recent projects include the solo performance Schizocity, a devised-theater adaptation of Zachary Mason's Lost Books of the Odyssey, and a dance piece entitled BOYS. Alex currently lives in Brooklyn.

story:
I am so friggin excited to announce. LIKE CRAZY EXCITED!!!  (since it is now official) that I will be performing in a mounting of the one man show "THE NIGHT LARRY KRAMER KISSED ME"  by David Drake this JUNE!  This was a show performed 20 years ago, off-Broadway, by David Drake himself.   It tells the story of his call to gay pride and activism through a series of vignettes exploring thoughts and emotions shared by a whole generation of gay men and women.  In 2000 it was made into a film.  For the past year and a half, I have been working closely with two newly formed theatre companies here in Chicago called GLITTERATI PRODUCTIONS (http://glitteratiproductions.com) and PRIDE FILMS AND PLAYS (http://pridefilmsandplays.com/).  These theatre companies are still very new (2 years old) and at a very grassroots stage of development.  Through a series of staged readings, caberet fundraisers, and two full-length productions (performed in very small cabaret and bar theatres that were free or charged next to nothing), we have managed to put our company on the map.  In October, I approached a director from the company about joining forces in mounting a 20 year anniversary production of this one man show.  The theatre company members were skeptical that the piece was dated or not relevant enough for our time and our instant-gratification culture.  I invited them to hear me read/perform the play out loud for the board of directors and any ensemble members that wished to attend.  This happened on March 10th.  On that day, I heard the board say things like..."this is going to make you a star.  This could be such a big thing.  This is worth bringing back.  People need to hear this story again."  Since March 10th I have been working my ass off, double shifts, scouting out theatre venues, and just plain pounding the pavement.  The good news is we booked a theatre, but not for free. Zach (my partner) and I saved our funds and put a deposit down on a theatre before we even had the rights.  After seeing the theatre, both theatre companies realized that it is important to our development to push some of our productions into real theatres with real theatre seats and make a handful of our productions more legit.  THE NIGHT LARRY KRAMER KISSED ME is that inaugural production.  With David Drake's blessing, and a brand new ending penned by Mr. Drake my partner Zach and I have pledged that we will raise $3,000 dollars toward an over $6,000-$8,000 budget for the show.

So, yes, you guessed it, Ineed you to help.  You consist of those that have in some way inspired me to continue to be myself and chase my dreams.  You can help in many ways.  You can help by buying a ticket to the show which is the best way.  And then tell your friend to buy a ticket, or better yet, buy a ticket for you and a friend and then come again or tell other friends.  You can also help by donating money to help us pay for the theatre, the advertising, the stage management, the rights, the legal fees.  Your donations helps pay for a lightning designer, set designers, costumes, props, promotional materials, rehearsal space, equiptment just to name a few.   If you can't come to Chicago to see the show, spend the $20 toward a donation and support an artistic endeavor that is near and dear to my heart and hopefully after this campaign...near and dear to yours. 

 I urge you to see why I am so excited to perform this piece.  It's a tour de force.  A one-man passion play.. I am passionate about this project not only because of the challenge it will pose for me as an actor but also because of the relevant material that even 20 years later is still important. But, beyond that, I think it is important to tell the story of this community and how we had people before us that fought to make life as easy, breezy and beautiful as it really is right now.  This play makes we want to make some noise.  Because, I truly believe, we still need to make some noise to keep on getting to where we are going. 

 If you choose to donate at $1, or $10, or $20  it doesn't matter, all is appreciated greatly.  If you choose to donate $100, or $500 or $1,000 we should talk about putting your name in the playbill, maybe even sponsorship.  Either way, I am reaching out now and will continue to reach out until June 19th when I need to shut down my indiegogo page and open the show for it's first preview performance  Consider it. Or just come see it.  June 20th thru July1st.  

I can't tell you how excited I am about this project.  It's a life altering risk, a life changing role, and life affirming choice!!! ACT UP!!!!

 Thanks and please don't hesitate to ask me more about it and reach out for details.....lots of love and thanks!!!

 

Here is the OFFICAL PRESS RELEASE

 

Glitterati Productions Presents

The Pride Films and Plays Production of David Drake's

The Night Larry Kramer Kissed Me

In A New 20th Anniversary Edition Featuring Chad Ryan

Please Be Our Guest for Opening Night, Thursday, June 21 at 7:30 pm.

Chicago, IL

- In June 1992, David Drake opened his one-man show The Night Larry Kramer Kissed Me, which went on to make theatrical history as one of the longest running one-man shows in New York. The New York Times called the writing "angry, occasionally ferocious... Every line is spare, quick, complex, as it chronicles an important time of change for gay men in America."

Now, 20 years later, Chicago actor Chad Ryan will perform a 20th anniversary edition with new material penned by David Drake. The Night Larry Kramer Kissed Me will be performed at Luna Central, 3914 North Clark Street.

There is one preview performance on Wednesday June 20th at 7:30; tickets for this preview are $15. Opening night is Thursday, June 21 at 7:30. Performances thereafter are Friday, June 22 at 7:30; Saturday, June 23 at 7:00 and 9:30; Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday, June 26 through 29 at 7:30; and Saturday, June 30 at 7:00 and 9:00. Tickets for all regular performances are $20. For tickets call 1 800 838 3006, or reserve on line at www.brownpapertickets.com.

Before moving to Chicago, Chad Ryan performed in dozens of off-Broadway productions as both an actor and director. He is an ensemble member of Pride Films and Plays, and has performed in their production of Love Sucks, as well as various screen and stage play "enhanced readings."

The Night Larry Kramer Kissed Meis directed by PFP Artistic Associate Andrew Souders. For PFP he has directed Some Men in last year's Terrence McNally series,Blowing Whistles, Easy On the Eyes, and Lost In History, the latter for the recent Gay Play Weekend at Center on Halsted. Other favorite directing jobs include A Midsummer Night's Dream, The Importance of Being Earnest, The Lady from Dubuque.

David Drake made his playwriting debut in June 1992 with the semi-autobiographical one-man play The Night Larry Kramer Kissed Me at New York's Perry Street Theater. Playing a year off-Broadway, it became one of the longest-running solos shows in New York theater history, and won David a Village Voice Obie award, two Dramalogue Awards, and a Lambda Literary Award nomination. To date, Larry Kramer has received nearly 100 independent productions worldwide in the USA, England, South Africa, Australia, Argentina, Brazil, France, New Zealand, as well as being translated into Greek, Spanish, Portuguese, and French. The 2000 film version of Larry Kramer aired on HERE TV and is available on DVD. Alternately as a performer, playwright, director, and teacher, David has continued to enjoy a prolific career in New York and abroad.

About Glitterati Productions

Glitterati Productions was founded by Artistic Director John Nasca and Artistic Associate Tiffany Nasca in 2005, and was later joined by ensemble members Christine Rivera and Michelle McKenzie-Voigt. Glitterati's first production, Moon Over Buffalo, played for three months at the Theatre Building Chicago. Together the company has also been involved in productions of Gypsy and No, No, Nanette.

John Nasca is also an Artistic Associate of Pride Films and Plays, for which he directed Love Sucks! His additional directing credits for PFP include Beautiful Thing, The Ritz, Save the Date, Maurice, and Hello Norma Jeane, all of which Michelle McKenzie-Voigt appeared in and to which Tiffany Nasca lent her graphic design and AD talents. Tiffany and Michelle are also proud ensemble members of PFP. John is also a 3-time Jeff-recommended costumer for Vampire Lesbians of Sodom, Anyone Can Whistle, and Die! Mommie, Die!, and the proud recipient of After Dark and Broadway World awards.

Up next for Glitterati is the Chicago premiere of Mr. Shaw Goes to Hollywood by Emmy Award-winning author Mark Saltzman.

About Pride Films and Plays

Pride Films and Plays, based in Chicago, links an international network of writers with professionals working in film and theater. PFP fosters excellent writing for the stage and screen that speaks not only to the LGBT community, but is essential viewing for our friends, family, and co-workers. Using stories with gay, lesbian, bisexual, and transgender characters or themes, Pride Films and Plays develops human stories that become a cultural bridge to understanding. Through readings, contests, classes, screenings, and full theater productions, PFP engages artists and audiences in the full developmental process needed to make great artistic experiences. For more information, visit www.pridefilmsandplays.com.

story:
What is Aries In Flight?

Aries in Flight is a theater dance company whose mission is to carryon the culture of theater dance by honoring past choreographers, creating new work, and educating theater dance patrons/supporters/artists.  We hope to instill historical and technical knowledge through education outreach student programs as well as intensive training programs.  Our goal is to pay homage to our past and carryon this tradition for years to come.

Aries in Flight is directed by founder Catherine Baggs.  Catherine received her BA in Music Theatre/Mathematics from American University and her MA in Dance Education from New York University.  She has worked as a performer, teacher and choreographer. Aries In Flight is the realization of a life long dream to promote theater dance as a distinct artform that can stand on its own.  

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to produce our inaugural performance through this indiegogo campaign.  Our producing costs total $3500.  All monies raised will be go towards the following:

  • Theater Rental
  • Stipends for 7 dancers
  • Advertising
  • Rehearsal Rental Costs
  • Costumes

This inaugural performance will feature an original story about relationships and young people's quest for love and attention.  The story will be told solely through dance; we believe that theater dance is strong enough to support and evolve a show.  We look forward to having you attend our inaugural performance!  If you have any questions feel free to email Catherine at catbaggs@gmail.com

The Impact

Aries In Flight's goal is to share theater dance with the NYC commnity as well as showcase theater dance as a valid and legitimate dance form.  Through sharing performances with the community, Aries In Flight will help theater dance reach new audiences as well as educate its patrons about the rich traditions of theater dance.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute monetarily at this time we ask for your support in the following ways:

  • Share this campaign on your twitter, blog, and facebook.
  • Email friends, family, and colleagues who are interested in supporting the arts.

Thank you in advance for your support!

story:
RESOBOX Presents

  Murakami Music: Stories of Loss and Nostalgia                                                               Saturday November 1st, 2014 at 8PM                                                               Engelman Recital Hall, Baruch Performing Arts Center

Created by pianist Eunbi Kim, in collaboration with actress Laura Yumi Snell, and director Kira Simring, Murakami Music is a performance piece inspired by the works of contemporary Japanese novelist Haruki Murakami, an author whose books have been translated into fifty languages, and sold millions of copies. His works reference classical music, as well as popular music, jazz and blues.

Murakami Music has been lauded and featured on Japanese television network, FujiTV, and most recently profiled in the documentary, "The World Reads Murakami," on NHK, Japan's national public broadcasting organization.

A dramatic work, this program includes performances of piano works with theatrical readings that explore the complexities of the lives behind the pianists in Murakami's books including Sputnik Sweetheart, Kafka on the Shore, and Norwegian Wood.

Summary

RESOBOX- "The place where people who are conversant with, dedicated to, and influenced by Japanese arts can gather, create innovative arts through the collaborative processand disseminate them to the world."

Due to popular demand (sold-out performances at Symphony Space and The Cell Theatre), Murakami Music is thrilled to work with RESOBOX, a Japanese cultural center based in Queens, NY, to present another special NYC performance in the beautiful Engelman Recital Hall at The Baruch Performing Arts Center. With excellent acoustics and a spectacular stage setting, it's sure to create another unique and unforgettable experience for audience members. Read a past review here. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising funds to offset production costs and to provide artist fees for all the hard-working, talented, and creative people involved in this passion project. Ticket sales alone rarely cover all the expenses for a performance, such as printing and designing programs and materials, the space rental, technical lighting, artist fees, etc. 

In return, we invite you to our VIP Reception Party, a RESOBOX cafe date complete with their famous matcha latte and sushi, backstage access and open rehearsals, and a private house concert for you and all your friends. 

    The Impact

    By contributing, you are making a major impact for-

    • The Arts (music, literature, theatre, Japanese culture)
    • Women and Minority Artists- it is rare to see an Asian-American female lead in a theatrical production that does not involve any racial stereotypes. 
    • Social Causes- We delve into one of the most universally taboo topics, mental illness. 
    • Writings of Haruki Murakami- Murakami writes about alienation, loss, nostalgia, and more themes that we hope to inspire audiences. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can’t contribute at this time, there are other ways to help. Please spread the word by using the Indiegogo share tools to post our campaign on Facebook and Twitter. We thank you so much!

story:
This is your chance to help FTE bring passion to the stage with the launch of "Reasons to be Pretty" written by Neil LaBute, directed by Elaine Previs, and staring Brandon Vipperman, Nicole Tourot, Damian Leone, and Katie Cummings. In this sizzling contemporary drama two young couples allow their passion to boil over, scalding their fragile egos and leaving permanent emotional scars beneath their otherwise beautiful young bodies. LaBute raises important questions about the role that beauty, both inner beauty and outer, plays in our lives and relationships.

Your donation today could be the roses that Greg buys in a desperate attempt to repair the damage he inflicted on the one he loves. It could be the bench where an old friendship finally comes to an end in a terrifying fist-fight. It could be trophies, taquitos, dresses, or baseball uniforms. Your donation will help us bring this fierce and fiery production to Fredericksburg, VA.

Any money raised beyond what is needed for "Reasons to be Pretty" will be used in future productions and to help FTE develop two exciting new programs -- the Stephen Brown New Play workshops, and the Young Directors Program -- so that we may continue to bring performing arts to the community and the community to the performing arts for many years to come.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Iyun Ashani Harrison and I am the artistic director of ASHANI DANCES. Throughout my education at the Juilliard School and Hollins University; my professional career with Dance Theatre of Harlem, Ailey II and Ballet Hispanico; and my teaching at Cornish College of the Arts and The Ailey School, I have developed a passion for choreography and assisting young dance artists launch their performance careers.

ASHANI DANCES provides a venue for gifted dancers to develop mentorships with established dance professionals whereby they can gain invaluable performance experience. 

In our third season, ASHANI DANCES will perform at The Broadway Performance Hall (Seattle, WA) from June 6 - 8, 2014. The company will present three new works - one in collaboration with Seattle Jazz singer and composers, Johnaye Kendrick. 

Contributing to ASHANI DANCES' campaign will help to underwrite the costs of the theater rental, rehearsal studio rental, advertising, production expenses: costume design and construction, musical commission fee, lighting design, technical staff fees and dancer honorariums.

What We Need & What You Get

ASHANI DANCES needs to raise $12,000 to cover our production expenses. This is how they break down:

Your gift of $400 will help provide an honorarium for one (1) of our eight (8) dancers who will perform in our third season.  

Your gift of $500 will help to underwrite the cost of costuming one (1) of our three (3) pieces this season.

Your gift of $1000 will help to underwrite the creation of an original musical scores by Johnaye Kendrick for the season. 

Your gift of $1000 or more will contribute to:

Broadway Performance Hall rental ($4,000)

Publicity: posters, postcards ($1,350)

Lighting Designer ($500)

Stage Manager ($650)

Photographer ($350)

Videographer ($550)


WHAT YOU GET!!!!!!!

Give $50 and you will receive a signed copy of the ASHANI DANCES' season poster. 

Give $100 and you will receive a season t-shirt, signed season poster, a reserved seat at the  opening night performance of ASHANI DANCES' third season and you will be listed as a "Friend" of ASHANI DANCES in the season program. 

Give $500 and you will receive a signed season poster and season t-shirt. Your name will be listed in the season program as: "Production made possible by a generous donation from (your name here)". Attend one rehearsal of your choosing and a reserved seat at the opening night performance of ASHANI DANCES' third season and you will be listed as a "Gold Donor" in the season program.

Give $1000 or more and you will receive a signed season poster, season t-shirt, attendance to any/all rehearsals and performances of your choosing, an invitation to the season cast party and your name will be listed in the season program as: "Platinum Donor for Ashani Dances" and you will be invited to join the advisory board of ASHANI DANCES!

The Impact

We would like to share some of the positive feedback about ASHANI DANCES' Second Season in June 2013.

Gabrielle Nomura of Seattle Dances Blog writes, 

"Harrison did a remarkable job showcasing the unique talents of his dancers, and telling a story with tenderness and intrigue." 

http://seattledances.blogspot.com/2013/06/spotlight-on-seattle-showcases-best-in.html


Dean Speer of  Critical Dance Forum writes, 

"Not only did Harrison show off what the dancers can do, the dancers showed off his truly excellent dances." 

http://www.ballet-dance.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=5&t=37023


Charlotte Hart of  Seattle Dances Blog writes,

" Harrison's choreography shined in the second movement. The use of stillness and slow progression as Ariana Bird, Christina Kennedy, and Thomas O'Neal drifted across the floor perfectly matched the atmospheric music of local composer William Hayes."  

http://seattledances.blogspot.com/2013/06/ashani-dances-promising-young-company.html


Michael Upchurch of the Seattle Times writes,

"Last weekend I described Ashani Dances as "a promising new local dance company." Scratch that. This troupe is exceptionally accomplished, and their showcase of three new works by artistic director Iyun Ashani Harrison is a knockout. Most of the dancers have an affiliation with Cornish College of the Arts where Harrison teaches (some are graduates, some still students). All have strong, agile ballet skills which are given an intoxicating Afro-Caribbean twist in "Artifact," a joyous, sassy, intricate homage to what Harrison calls "the beautiful traditional dances of my childhood in Jamaica." Local composer-percussionist Ben Morrow penned the dance-propulsive score. Sean Rosado and Sam Picart are reasons alone to catch this while you can."


'Men in Dance': Talent from Seattle and Beyond" 

Michael Upchurch of the  Seattle Times. 

http://seattletimes.com/html/thearts/2019422440_dr13menindance.html#.UHnxAyKctgE.facebook

"Iyun Harrison weighed in with the tightest, most impressive piece I've seen by him yet, "Tres Reyes," for three male dancers. Ohlberg, Timothy Lynch and Harrison were well up to the challenge of the piece, which blended balletic virtuosity with flavors more dervishlike and feral."

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to contribute financially but are still interested in helping, here is how you can do so:

Share our campaign on your social media pages.

Volunteer to help us in the front of house on the weekend of the performances by selling company merchandice and handing out programs. 

Volunteer to help us load into, and out of the theater.

Help us publicize our concert.
story_txt:
Short Summary
My name is Iyun Ashani Harrison and I am the artistic
director of ASHANI DANCES. Throughout my education at the Juilliard School and
Hollins University; my professional career with Dance Theatre of Harlem, Ailey
II and Ballet Hispanico; and my teaching at Cornish College of the Arts and The Ailey School, I have
developed a passion for choreography and assisting young dance artists launch
their performance careers.ASHANI DANCES provides a venue for gifted dancers to develop mentorships with established dance professionals whereby they can gain invaluable performance experience. 
In our third season, ASHANI DANCES will perform at The Broadway
Performance Hall (Seattle, WA) from June 6 - 8, 2014. The company will present
three new works - one in collaboration with Seattle Jazz singer and composers, Johnaye
Kendrick. 
Contributing to ASHANI DANCES' campaign will help to underwrite
the costs of the theater rental, rehearsal studio rental, advertising, production
expenses: costume design and construction, musical commission fee, lighting
design, technical staff fees and dancer honorariums.
What We Need & What You GetASHANI DANCES needs to raise $12,000 to cover our production expenses. This is how they break down:Your gift of $400 will help provide an honorarium for one (1) of our eight (8) dancers who will perform in our third season.  Your gift of $500 will help to underwrite the cost of costuming one (1) of our three (3) pieces this season.Your gift of $1000 will help to underwrite the creation of an original musical scores by Johnaye Kendrick for the season. Your gift of $1000 or more will contribute to:Broadway Performance Hall rental ($4,000)Publicity: posters, postcards ($1,350)Lighting Designer ($500)Stage Manager ($650)Photographer ($350)Videographer ($550)WHAT YOU GET!!!!!!!Give $50 and you will receive a signed copy of the ASHANI DANCES' season poster. Give $100 and you will receive a season t-shirt, signed season poster, a reserved seat at the  opening night performance of ASHANI DANCES' third season and you will be listed as a "Friend" of ASHANI DANCES in the season program. Give $500 and you will receive a signed season poster and season t-shirt. story:
Who We Are

Theatre After Secrets is a group of young theatre artists from Toronto, Canada with big imaginations. We are writers, actors, dancers, musicians, and designers - creators and interpretors. By exploring the relationship between text, movement and sound, we make original work, and adapt existing works; investigating the human condition to reveal truths and subvert assumptions.

We are gathering funding for our first project entitled Knuckle Down, which we have been working on over the passed year. Now we want to perform it! But we need your help.

What We Need

We are fundraising for a 5-night run in Toronto, as well as to cover our costs for production. Any amount is sincerely appreciated. Our goal for this online campaign is $500.

The Impact

Theatre After Secrets originated from a desire to tell poignant and essential stories that explore what it means to be human in social, cultural and personal contexts. We seek to reveal what lies at the core of each and every one of us; our desires, fears, dreams – by picking apart the exterior layers brought on by time and experience that cause a person to be the way that they are.

We go after the secrets hidden deep within that instigate a journey, not only for ourselves but for our audiences. Through the theatre we make, we encourage and challenge our audiences to think critically but also receive openly, and take their own journeys toward a deeper understanding of themselves and those around them.

Theatre After Secrets is: Suzanna Derewicz, Brendee Green, Brandon White, Derek Gingrich, Travis Lahay, Christina Del Monte, Alanna McConnell, Matthew Van Driel, Kathleen Hemsworth, and Sarah Barton.

story:
The Shakespeare Society of America (SSA) , a California nonprofit and 501(c)(3) since 1968/69, was forced to relocate in 2006 from the Globe Playhouse/Theatre in West Hollywood, California after founding President R. Thad Taylor passed away. 

The image above is one-of-a-kind:  The photo at the Globe Theatre in West Hollywood in April 1977, the play entitled "Good Knight Shakespeare", depicts the Knighting of Shakespeare. Thad asked Queen Elizabeth II to knight Shakespeare. Her office replied there is no posthumous knighting. That inspired Thad to write this play that showed Queen Elizabeth I actually Knight Shakespeare!

The SSA Collection, acquired over the past 40 years, is slowly being revealed as one of the most unique cultural collections on earth and includes thousands of items; graphics, books, photos, busts, memorabilia, swords, props, costumes and more . . . 

Our daily Public Benefit Programs make this collection accessible to youth, educators, seniors, local tourists and global travelers. 

Reality demands that we acquire modest funds to sustain these programs, while long term SSA projects require substantial funding to enhance our programs. 

The goal of this Indiegogo campaign 

is to help us stage a live fundraising event:

Saturday Knight Out 

Fundraising Gala

February 12th, 2011 

from 6pm to 9:30pm

@ the New Shakespeare Sanctuary in Moss Landing, California.

This Saturday Knight Out aims to unite elite cultural philanthropists, entertained by Shakespeare Superstars and local talent, to sustain long term SSA funding. If you would like an email invitation to this event please send a request to SatKnightOut@ShakespeareSocietyofAmerica.Org

We need your $$$ donations for this event to help us cover some basic costs: printing/mailing invitations, some volunteer travel costs, audio/visual equipment rentals and videography.

We expect to have food, beverages and door prizes donated by local stakeholders. 

The show must go on, the show will go on . . .

All Indiegogo contributors will be recognized in the program at the event. 

Right Now! Go to your rooftops and social media networks: compel your world to fund this campaign and;

Please contact us with your hot leads to develop our funding team . . .

Thank You for caring enough to donate today!

$ $ $ Thank You All $ $ $

story:
Our Story

After a successful reading The Workshop Theater Company, a legitimate Off-Off-Broadway company in its fifteenth season, decided to add Rumpelstiltskin to their 2012 season. This charming 55 minute childrenâ€™s musical marries a beautiful score by composer Steve Marzullo and lyricist Amelia Demayo with a witty book by Deb Roberts. Rumpelstiltskin retells the classic Grimm tale highlighting themes that are easily accessible to children in a way far more joyous then its darker counterpart. Our production is scheduled to run from February 11 till March 5. Additional information can be found at www.workshoptheater.org 


The Impact

Rumpelstiltskin will be the inaugural production of the Workshop Theater Companyâ€™s Youth Theater Wing, a department which aims to develop a full season of youth theater pieces to augment its existing programming, thus creating a performance home for professional children. It is our hope that the success of this production will spark other program development for other theaters as well creating numerous strongholds for child performers throughout the city.


What We Need & What You Get

The money raised through this campaign will be used to provide the best production we could hope to accomplish. Funds will be used not only for the design elements such as scenic construction and lighting, but also for renting rehearsal space that is safe and convenient for actors.


Other Ways You Can Help

We cannot accomplish this feat without your help. Please reach out to family and friends, post our campaign on facebook and twitter, and remember that every donation counts!

story:
It has been eight months since the COVID-19 crisis brought the curtain down on theatres across Canada. But as we look to the new year, The Howland Company is looking to connect and bring you lots of laughter from home! This #GivingTuesday please consider a donation to our new live-streamed adaptation of our "Best of Toronto Fringe" and Canadian Comedy Award nominated hit, Entrances and Exits (created by Ruth Goodwin and Liz Johnston) and help support Canadian theatre artists this winter. 

About Entrances and Exits:

“Some of the best actors and improvisers in the city make this made-up two-act farce look easy.”   -Now Magazine 

Entrances and Exits premiered in 2018 at the Toronto Fringe Festival, where it became an instant sold-out hit, winning "Best of Toronto Fringe". The show was subsequently remounted in 2019 at Bad Dog Theatre, and was invited to Toronto’s Sketch Fest--Canada’s premiere comedy showcase, before garnering a Canadian Comedy Award nomination. The show takes its nod from classic farces you already love as it follows a cast of incredible improvisers over the course of 60 minutes as they try to salvage a party gone awry.

...But a lot has changed since 2018. 

Now, as the theatres remain closed and social distancing lockdowns remain in effect, our goal is to adapt this joyful, unscripted comedy from stage to screen for an innovative digital performance, broadcast live from the The Guloien Stage at Crow's Theatre to you at home.

The Impact

Your donation will go directly towards providing meaningful employment this winter to a team of over 20 Canadian theatre artists, designers, and technicians after a year of unprecedented cancellations and postponements. By giving today, you’re giving us all the chance to do what we do best--create innovative art that celebrates laughter, joy and connection, and bring it LIVE to our audiences in a time when we all need it most.

Other Ways You Can Help

Of course, we understand the unprecedented financial burden COVID-19 has imposed on so many of us. If you want to support but are not in the position to donate at this time, please share our campaign on social media or by email and help us spread the word this Giving Season.  

Thank you for your continued support, 

The Howland Company

story:
Short Summary

My name is Collette Campbell and I am a New York based actor and performer. I was hired as an acting apprentice for Portland Playhouse in Portland, OR for the 2015-16 season. At the end of my apprenticeship I had the opportunity to create and perform a one person show about 10 minutes in length. Home, Sweet, _____ was born from the feeling of homesickness being so far from my home in New York for a year. I collaborated with Brooklyn musician Sean Skahill and he wrote an original score for the show and recorded it. It was been performed in New York twice since, at Dixon Place for the Bindlestiff Family Circus's Open Stage Variety Night and in the Emerging Artist Theater's New Works Spring Festival at Tada! Theater with Sean performing his music live by looping several instruments. 

It has always been my dream to bring my original one woman clown show that I love so dearly to fringe festivals across the nation and beyond. FringeNYC is one of the largest, most competitive, and most critically acclaimed fringe festivals in existence. To have been invited to perform this beautiful piece in my very own home, sweet, home is incredibly humbling. Participation fees for this festival have proven to be quite expensive and in the past artists have greatly benefited from the generosity of patron's donations. Your contribution would help my show be recognized in a huge way and help me as an artist finally break into the fringe world and be a part of a really special community. 

What We Need & What You Get

Participation, insurance, equipment, marketing materials, etc. are all a huge part of the cost of putting up Home, Sweet, _____ at FringeNYC. Any contribution you make will help defray the expense and make the show the best version it can be. I also have perks for you at all donation levels to say thank you for your generous contribution!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute, please help spread the word!

Home, Sweet, _____ will be performed at FringeNYC October 13-22. 

Tickets for the show  can be purchased at this link starting September 1st: http://www.fringenyc.org/basic_page.php?ltr=H#H...

You can use the Indiegogo share tools to help promote my campaign as well!

Thank you so much for your contribution! See you at FringeNYC 2018!

story:
Short Summary

Help us put on a great production of a brand new musical version of A Christmas Carol - but with a difference - set in current times, but with all the usual male roles in the Dickens tale now women - a female Scrooge named Carol, a female Tiny Tim named Trina, a female Jacob Marley and three female ghosts of Christmas Past, Present, and Future.  The book is by Doug Haverty, an  award-winning playwright, and the music and lyrics are by Bruce Kimmel, who also directs - he is an award-winning songwriter and director.  The show opens on November 16 and plays through the end of the year.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $10,000.  The Group Rep has been around for decades and done a lot of wonderful theatre.  Putting on a big new musical is beyond their usual means so we need this money to cover those extra costs that come with producing a musical, i.e. the musical director and most importantly a sound package for the theatre, which has nothing in terms of sound.  We are using orchestral tracks that are being created by our musical director Richard Allen, who is doing brilliant work on them.  The sound package includes a lot of rentals - mixing board, mics, speakers, etc. and it's a seven-week run - and we also have to pay a sound operator to actually run the show.  We are being given a great rate but we need the money to cover it.  Just to know how great a rate, the musical Bruce Kimmel directed last year, the world premiere of Levi by the Sherman Brothers, had a sound budget of $16,000 and that was only for a two-week run.

We've come up with some really fun perks - tickets to our opening weekend, which include a pre-show private reception and after-party - we're basically doing three opening nights and you can choose which performance you'd like to attend on the opening weekend.   There are also Group Rep season tickets at a considerable savings, you can be an associate producer or an above the title producer, you can get a special thank you in the program, and we have other fun and unique stuff - signed items, a cast album, a private coaching session with Bruce Kimmel, a personally designed Christmas card for you especially by Doug Haverty, and lots of other great stuff.

The first two days of any Indiegogo campaign are the key days and set the tone for the campaign.  Therefore it is very important we do really well on the first two days, so if you can contribute and choose your perk on those days that would be incredibly helpful.  Also, please spread the word to your nearest and dearest 10,000 friends on social media, especially musical theatre fans.  Let's make this thing trend!

If we do not reach our goal (although we hope we will!), all the money we do make goes directly to the musical and sound needs of the production.

The Impact

In these crazy times, having a positive, fun, and moving new musical that makes people feel good about life and decisions is so important.  The ultimate goal is to create a holiday show that can play all over the world - and having a show with so many great female roles is something we really wanted to do.

In the past, we've had great success funding campaigns for new musicals - last year it was Levi! A New Musical about Levi Strauss, written by the Sherman Brothers - we not only funded, we went considerably higher and we were able to do an amazing production of that show that is now leading to other productions.  The year before it was for a new musical revue about Los Angeles, L.A. Now and Then, and we funded considerably over our goal for that one, too.  In each of those cases, all the money went to the musical and sound needs of the show, just as it will here.

So, with your help, we want this show to have an amazing birth - all the people who contributed to our other campaigns loved their perks, loved being part of the birth of new musical theatre projects, and we simply try to make it fun and exciting for everyone.

Risks & Challenges

The challenges are, of course, budgetary.  Small 99-seat theaters are always struggling with budgets and making their seasons happen.  The Group Rep is an award-winning theatre company, one of the oldest in Los Angeles.  They have not done many musicals due to the cost factor, but the handful they've done have been very successful.  We're hoping this new feel-good holiday musical will get full houses and help their coffers for their future seasons.  The risks are easy - a new musical is always challenging, but we are up to those risks and challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that money can be tight so if you can't afford to contribute, please spread the word and share this campaign with all your nearest and dearest.
story_txt:
Short Summary
Help us put on a great production of a brand new musical version of A Christmas Carol - but with a difference - set in current times, but with all the usual male roles in the Dickens tale now women - a female Scrooge named Carol, a female Tiny Tim named Trina, a female Jacob Marley and three female ghosts of Christmas Past, Present, and Future.  The book is by Doug Haverty, an  award-winning playwright, and the music and lyrics are by Bruce Kimmel, who also directs - he is an award-winning songwriter and director.  The show opens on November 16 and plays through the end of the year.

What We Need & What You Get
We are looking to raise $10,000.  The Group Rep has been around for decades and done a lot of wonderful theatre.  Putting on a big new musical is beyond their usual means so we need this money to cover those extra costs that come with producing a musical, i.e. the musical director and most importantly a sound package for the theatre, which has nothing in terms of sound.  We are using orchestral tracks that are being created by our musical director Richard Allen, who is doing brilliant work on them.  The sound package includes a lot of rentals - mixing board, mics, speakers, etc. and it's a seven-week run - and we also have to pay a sound operator to actually run the show.  We are being given a great rate but we need the money to cover it.  Just to know how great a rate, the musical Bruce Kimmel directed last year, the world premiere of Levi by the Sherman Brothers, had a sound budget of $16,000 and that was only for a two-week run.
We've come up with some really fun perks - tickets to our opening weekend, which include a pre-show private reception and after-party - we're basically doing three opening nights and you can choose which performance you'd like to attend on the opening weekend.   There are also Group Rep season tickets at a considerable savings, you can be an associate producer or an above the title producer, you can get a special thank you in the program, and we have other fun and unique stuff - signed items, a cast album, a private coaching session with Bruce Kimmel, a personally designed Christmas card for you especially by Doug Haverty, and lots of other great stuff.
The first two days of any Indiegogo campaign are the key days and set the tone for the campaign.  Therefore it is very important we do really well on the first two days, so if you can contribute and choose your perk on those days that would be incredibly helpful.  Also, please spread the word to your nearest and dearest 10,000 friends on social media, especially musical theatre fans.  Let's make this thing trend!
If we do not reach our goal (although we hope we will!), all the money we do make goes directly to the musical and sound needs of the production.

The Impact
In these crazy times, having a positive, fun, and moving new musical that makes people feel good about life and decisions is so important.  The ultimate goal is to create a holiday show that can play all over the world - and having a show with so many great female roles is something we really wanted to do.
In the past, we've had great success funding campaigns for new musicals - last year it was Levi! A New Musical about Levi Strauss, written by the Sherman Brothers - we not only funded, we went considerably higher and we were able to do an amazing production of that show that is now leading to other productions.  The year before it was for a new musical revue about Los Angeles, L.A. Now and Then, and we funded considerably over our goal for that one, too.  In each of those cases, all the money went to the musical and sound needs of the show, just as it will here.
So, with your help, we want this show to have an amazing birth - all the people who contributed to our other campaigns loved their perks, loved being part of the birth of new musical theatre projects, and we simply try to make it fun and exciting for everyone.

Risks & Challenges
The challenges are, of course, budgetary.  Small 99-seat theaters are always struggling with budgets and making their seasons happen.  The Group Rep is an award-winning theatre company, one of the oldest in Los Angeles.  They have not done many musicals due to the cost factor, but the handful they've done have been very successful.  We're hoping this new feel-good holiday musical will get full houses and help their coffers for their future seasons.  The risks are easy - a new musical is always challenging, but we are up to those risks and challenges.
Other Ways You Can Help
We understand that money can be tight so if you can't afford to contribute, please spread the word and share this campaign with all your nearest and dearest.

story:
ThE PlaY

WHAT IS PANCAKE DAY? A messy, silly, honest, remarkably bare night shared between two best friends and a stranger. There is Hawaiian pizza. There is reality TV. There are dance routines. There are fireworks. 

Pancake Day is an explosive piece of new writing from innovative British playwright Miriam Battye, and we are thrilled to give it its American premiere! 

OR:

Ella and Zoe are best friends. Matty is a stranger they hire from Craigslist for the night. What ensues is a series of planned (and, eventually, unplanned) activities the girls have devised to digest and process a decision. They include role play, choreographed dance routines, and hawaiian pizza. And amidst all this is Matty. From Craigslist. 

Pancake day is a play about being young: the confusion, the loneliness, and the manifested sense of purpose. It’s hilarious. It’s heartbreaking. It has its finger completely on the pulse. It is a show that desperately needs to be seen. 

 

WhY Pancake Day

Pancake Day presents an honest look at our relationships in a way that is rarely given space onstage. It's ridiculous, funny, heartbreaking, and completely representative of how confusing it is to be a person. 

*******

We are an international company committed to exploring new work! As Pancake Day grapples with ideas of communication, we are excited to investigate how language changes across the Atlantic. Working closely with a dramaturge, we are adapting the text of Zoe and Matty to fit the landscape of New York without removing any of the punch and grit of the original dialogue. Through this, we can emphasize the themes of division and perspective that are at the heart of this compelling comedy.

*******

This is such an exciting opportunity to bring sizzling international work to the US. Writer Miriam Battye's new play will be premiering at The Royal Court in London next year, and we are thrilled to be the first American company to bring her characters to life. 

 

WhY Donate

We make theatre as a TEAM! That means we pay everyone equally, we work laterally rather than hierarchically, and we are as committed to working with new artists as we are with seasoned professionals. To do this -  we need your help!

Directed by Britt Berke, November Theatre is proud to present Nell Bailey, Yvonna Pearson, and Sky Nelson as Ella, Zoe, and Matty, alongside a wonderful creative team: Miriam Battye (Playwright) Caity Cook (Dramaturge); Lily Whiteman (Stage Management); Sio Hornbuckle (Assistant Director); Elizabeth Schweitzer (Lighting Design); Adjua Jones (Sound Design); Carina Goebelbecker (Choreography); and Kyiah Ashton (Photography).

^^This is how we plan to use your very generously donated $$$!

 

RiSKS & ChALLENGES

This is November Theatre's FIRST EVER production. We're throwing everything we've got at this fantastic play, and we invite you to jump with us. Making art is never certain; but the payoff is always incredible.

 

OtHER WaYS YoU CaN HeLP

If you're unable to donate, that's okay! You can also support the project by sharing our facebook page:https://www.facebook.com/events/2445666349014991/ and instagram: @novembertheatre with friends and family, and coming to see the show on December 20th and 21st! Tickets are available for purchase here: https://red.vendini.com/ticket-software.html?t=tix&e=ae733fb8136858767a30a01bec0d6c15

THaNK YoU for your help and support! See you there!

story:
Hello!! Our names are Lauren Coccaro, Mariah Elle Kane, and Dylan Bivings, and the three of us are artists; primarily actors, but we’re also singers, writers, dancers, etc. We have come together as the first students in a series of workshops by MTEAF’s and Triple Threat Theatre's very own industry professionals, Maria Torres and Dee Kanevsky, respectively. Part of our learning in this workshop is to produce. In the wake of Covid-19, Dee and Maria’s mission of this Creative Workshop is to provide equal prospects to artists who don’t have the advantage or opportunity to produce their own work.

                 We have a new drama called “The Crow” written by actor/playwright Dylan Bivings which tells the gripping tale of what it’s like for an individual to struggle with depression and anxiety with a hyper-realistic twist. Mariah Elle Kane, in conjunction with fellow Staten Island collaborators Omar and Omari De Jesus, will be showcasing their new music rife with evocative beats and a brilliant flow Staten Island hasn’t seen since its very own Wu-Tang Clan. And Lauren Coccaro will be debuting her poignant yet beautiful, never before seen poetry; honest words that evoke such a keen sense of the human condition. Unfortunately, money is no mere object when it comes to making art but with your help, these groundbreaking pieces of art will flourish at just $1800. There’s paying for the space and time spent there, plus investing in the people and equipment that provide necessary and often niche services for that specific project.

               In the Triple Threat Theatre Workshop, Dee provided her students the chance to learn from industry professionals currently working in the business of theatre so they can attain important, valuable bits of information. It’s through this that Triple Threat Theatre was able to connect us to Maria Torres, world-renowned director-choreographer, who worked with award-winning playwrights, actors, singers. Film, TV, Theatre, Music, you name it. Torres helped them bring their projects into the professional purview when they started at the ground floor. Some of which started in her own personal MTEAF workshop series. Together with Triple Threat Theatre and Maria Torres's MTEAF, they’re collaborating to bring a hands-on, educational experience to their students.

               Creative work has been shoved to the back burner, being labeled “non-essential”, it’s almost impossible for new artists to showcase their work. But that’s why this Creative Workshop is more important than ever! Given time, unique social distancing based staging, choreography and filming, and the proper resources, provided we reach our goal, we WILL Succeed. So we need your help. Please donate and spread the word to everyone you know and share it across all social media platforms. Art is essential. Dee and Maria, like many others, are working tirelessly to demonstrate that, while also providing those who can't the ability to do so. Your contributions will give us, and the many future artists who come after, this amazing opportunity that artists can’t get anywhere else.

story:
For the inaugural episode of our uniquely intimate Mobile Variety Freak Show series, Freaks With Lines will present two pieces from our repertoire and one, "work-in-progress" live concept, shown in an underground converted performance space in Santa Monica.  Artists in peak form will perform within the audience space, intriguing and challenging guests to observe The Freaks up close and question their own preconceived notions of classical dance and the art of movement.  

 An interactive Q&A with the company dancers and a casual reception will follow.

 

As you interact with us and observe our work, remember that Freaks With Lines isn't your average dance company. We are a vehicle for the evolution of ballet into the new millennium, and a platform for the unique and freakish talents that our dancers possess.  We are artists who create for ourselves first, calling into question the expectations of an antiquated art form and funding ourselves through creation and performances such as this to push our beloved art form into the post-postmodern world.

 

Watch us, see us, and if you believe in us, help us grow Freaks With Lines from a company into a community of freaks who train, teach, and support each other in the unflinching pursuit of a more modern art.  

 

~Susy

 

Our exceptional dancers grace some of the finest stages in the business of ballet including the Los Angeles Ballet, San Diego Ballet, Pennsylvania Ballet, Ballet West, Barak Ballet, Texas Ballet Theatre, Kansas City Ballet, San Diego Opera and Santa Fe Opera. They are working, dancing and teaching among you... 

-------------------------------------

Our goal is $2,500 for this campaign. ALL PROCEEDS go directly towards the production costs associated with thi event including dancer salaries, lighting, sound and furniture rental. Any additional funds directly fuel the continuation of our Mobile Variety Freak Show Series.

------------------------------------

Our Perk Supporters will be notified w/details of the event!

-------------------------------------

Currently a shift is occurring on the Los Angeles dance scene. Seize the excitement and be a part of a movement that will essentially propel the art of classical ballet into today's post-post modern world!

 

First  15 Contributors at $40 Gets You: Exclusive and Guaranteed Entry to the Event

First 15 Contributors at $50 Gets You: Exclusive and Guaranteed Entry to the Event and a FWL Printed Image

First 15 Contributors at $60 Gets you Exclusive and Guaranteed Entry to the Event, a FWL Printed Image and a FWL T-shirt.

 

While a contribution in any amount is greatly appreciated we understand that it is not a possibility for everyone. There are other ways to get involved and help support Freaks With Lines. Please spread the work of the Freaks using the Indiegogo tools to any and all voyeurs who have an affinity for the beauty and intrigue of classical ballet.

story:
WHO WE ARE: COMMON PEOPLE

We are two emerging dance artists, Andrew Hartley and Emma Kerson, who have come together to create Common People, a collective to support our creative voices.  We are looking to create work that is relevant to our artistic community as well as society at large.  We are asking ourselves questions about identity.  Who are we as individuals?  Who are we together?  What is the role of an artist within society?  We believe that we have a responsibility to be honest: to use our voices to accurately reflect who we are.

 

OUR SHOW: BLUE VALENTINE
 

We are raising money to produce Blue Valentine as part of Coleman Lemieux & Compagnie’s Bright Nights series.  This show is the culmination of three years of focused work. 
 

We began by commissioning talented young choreographer, Simon Renaud.  We chose Simon because he possesses an articulate and personal voice; his work is unlike anything else being presented in Toronto.  He is a creator with a vivid imagination and the skill to bring his vision to life.  He has a keen eye for detail; every moment of his choreography is thoughtfully considered.  His duet, l’inanité des bibelots / love would only slow me down, is slow, simple, and visually striking with a deeply emotional undercurrent.
 

The second duet on the program, Songs and Tarps, comes from Tedd Robinson who has mentored Simon’s choreographic work for the better part of a decade.  Simon’s choreography has evolved from Tedd’s mentorship and shares the same trademark visual strangeness.  We asked Tedd to create a piece in response to Simon’s in order to create an evening where the audience will gain a stronger appreciation of each piece when viewed one after the other.  Tedd chose to create a duet much more tangled with song and sound, physical contact, and yet similar questions of identity.

 

WHAT YOU'LL BE SUPPORTING

We have been very fortunate to receive strong support in each of the three years of this show’s life from both the Toronto Arts Council and the Ontario Arts Council, but we still need to raise $2000 in order to produce a show of this scale with integrity.  Expenses for a production like this include: rehearsal space, theatre rental, costumes and props, sound and lighting equipment, documentation, as well as artistic fees for the choreographers, rehearsal directors, sound and lighting designers, and us, the dancers.  It is an expensive venture, but we feel the work of these two choreographers deserves to be highlighted in a professional capacity.  Every little bit will help us achieve our goal.

 

OTHER WAYS TO BE INVOLVED

If you're unable to contribute financially, here’s how you can still make a meaningful contribution to support our initiative:

  • Help get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!  You can easily share a link to this page with friends and fellow dance and art lovers from your Facebook / Twitter accounts or in a personal email. 
  • Follow our journey on social media and by signing up for our Newsletter via our Website, so you can stay up-to-date with all of our activity leading up to the show. 
  • Come to our show and bring your friends.  We have spent three years carefully crafting the evening, and we'd love to see you in our audience!

 

Sincerely,

        Andrew & Emma

Sincerely,

story:
Friends, we need your help:

Want It needs your help to get out of debt! We took last year off from the playa and, after careful consideration, realize we are not going back to BRC again anytime soon. With that being said, we still have intentions to throw more of the great events that you’ve known us for (i.e. campouts, undergrounds, renegades, etc..) However, before we can move forward with planning future events, we need to pay off our debt and bring our Burning Man containers home from storage in Gerlach. We need to raise about $6,000 to cover our storage debt ($2,500), container transport ($1,500), and debt owed for emergency transportation after one of our trucks broke down on the way to playa in 2013 ($2,000). 

Here's the deal....

We’ve done some amazing things over the past 15 years. Want It started from humble beginnings at Burning Man as a tiny camp on the outskirts of the city. We grew our BM camp with hard work, perseverance, and love to become a favorite playa destination where we served the masses delicious music, sushi, and cocktails. Over the past dozen+ years, we also started a radio show, threw unforgettable undergrounds/fundraisers, and hosted three campouts. 

This is the point where most camps break up. They thank each other for a good run and move on with their lives. Not us. We are fucking solid. And we're committed to rocking together as a community. But we can’t move forward with more awesome things until we resolve our debts. We want nice things. You want nice things. Will you help Want It bring back nice things??....

A little trip down memory lane

2003

"You're in the right place"


2004


2005

Voted best shade


From the camp application letter to "the Organization":
We provide a display of binaural and bivisual frequencies aimed at awakening the subconscious locked inside. Coupled with innovative DJ’s we are sure to make your genitals throb. Imagine Corey Haim and Corey Feldman reunited for another great film. Don’t miss out on our sushi feed extravaganza Wednesday evening. Explore the subconscious while conscious and hopefully after a night of revelry... become unconscious.


2006

The Fuck Mat


2007


2008



2009



2010



2011

Shock Collar Competition

2012


2013

transport ($1,500), and debt owed for emergency transportation after one of our
trucks broke down on the way to playa in 2013 ($2,000). Here's the deal....We’ve done some amazing things over the past 15 years. Want
It started from humble beginnings at Burning Man as a tiny camp on the outskirts
of the city. We
grew our BM camp with hard work, perseverance, and love to become a favorite
playa destination where we served the masses delicious music, sushi, and
cocktails. Over the past dozen+ years, we also started a radio show, threw
unforgettable undergrounds/fundraisers, and hosted three campouts. This is the point where most camps break up. They thank each other for a good run and move on with their lives. Not us. We are fucking solid. And we're committed to rocking together as a community. But we can’t move forward with more awesome things until we resolve our debts. We want nice things. You want nice things. Will you help Want It bring back nice things??....
A little trip down memory lane
2003

"You're in the right place"


2004




2005

Voted best shade
From the camp application letter to "the Organization":
We provide a display of binaural and bivisual frequencies aimed at awakening the subconscious locked inside. Coupled with innovative DJ’s we are sure to make your genitals throb. Imagine Corey Haim and Corey Feldman reunited for another great film. Don’t miss out on our sushi feed extravaganza Wednesday evening. Explore the subconscious while conscious and hopefully after a night of revelry... become unconscious.



2006

The Fuck Mat


2007






2008



2009






2010

2011




Shock Collar Competition

2012

2013

story:
Our Project

Life/Art Dance Ensemble is a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization that strives to collaborate with other artists and artistic mediums. This year, we are teaming up once again with composer Russell Podgorsek to create our first dance film. Songs for the Sane 3.0 is a composition for viola and voice that is based on poems written by individuals suffering from paranoid schizophrenia. The addition of dance and video is an extension of the use of the viola and voice of one performer to dramatize the parallel and often conflicting existences of a person's inner and outer realities.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $1,300 for this project. Funds will be used for the following:

  • Hiring of a videographer and film editor
  • Dancer compensation
  • Airline ticket to fly Russell from Austin to Denver for this project

The perks for donating are:

  • A DVD including both the finished short film, Songs for the Sane 3.0, and a video of Error Message, the dance concert in which Songs for the Sane 3.0 will be performed live.
  • A complimentary ticket for Error Message, our contemporary dance performance at Crossroads Theater in Denver. You choose the date: August 22nd, 23rd or 30th. 
  • A framed photo autographed by all the performers. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Help us get the word out about this project!

story:
Scene One! 

We are Scene One Theatre, located in Athens, Ohio. We're really just a passionate group of theatre nutcases who love putting on family-friendly musicals and plays. This August, we are doing the hit Off-Broadway production, Frankenstein: A New Musical, directed by Matthew Johnson, and we need your help! 

What is this show about? 

Frankenstein! This is a powerhouse musical that very closely follows the classic novel by Mary Shelley, yet remains fantastically innovative. Victor Frankenstein is a brilliant young scientist who embarks on a quest to discover the secret of life, creating a human of his own design that turns out instead to be a horrifying creature. This is no 'Hollywood monster,' but a flesh and blood man who, while terrifying in appearance, grows to become articulate, cunning, and thirsting for revenge upon the creator who abandoned him. It is a tragic love story, an exploration of humanity, and a thrilling tale of man and creator pitted against one another in epic battle. 

What do we need?

All of the money we raise goes toward things we need for the show, like costumes, props, set materials, etc. We don't pay our staff or actors, so any money made is funneled into the show. This campaign is set up with a goal to raise at least half of expenses. With your help, we can present the awesomest (that's right...I said awesomest) production of Frankenstein, A New Musical! Our breakdown of total expenses is as follows: 
  • Scripts/Vocal Books:  $400
  • Royalties:  $500
  • Venue Rental:  $1800
  • Costumes:  $400
  • Set Materials: $800
  • Props:  $100

  • TOTAL:  $4000
And are there perks to donating? Oh my goodness, yes. We love and appreciate every single person that supports us. And we will let the world know as well (and we'll give you stuff! See 'perks') Aside from the warm, fuzzy feeling you get in your heart by supporting the Arts, we want to make sure that all of our supporters are recognized, that is unless you'd prefer to remain in the shadows. 

The Impact

Scene One is completely dedicated to furthering the existence of quality theatre in the Athens area. We strive to bring entertaining and thought-provoking productions to the stage, and Frankenstein is a wonderful opportunity for that. The cast and crew has worked and continues to work incredibly hard on this show and it is shaping up to be something really special. We are a young company, in only our fourth season, but we are passionate about theatre and our company mission reflects that. By helping us raise the money we need to produce the show, you are helping to validate the existence of the theatre and to ensure its continued existence in the Athens area. At Scene One, we aim to inspire, to teach, to challenge, to entertain.....and we need your help to do it. Community Theatre is both for and by the community. 


    Other Ways You Can Help

    We know that sometimes donating is just not feasible. If you want to donate, but can't, we understand. But that doesn't mean you can't help! Share our campaign with your family and friends, post it on facebook, and of course, come see the show! 
    We love and appreciate everyone who stands in our corner. Whoo! 

    So...when is the show? 

    I'm so glad you asked! Here is the show info:
    Dates:        August 15th-17th and 22nd-24th
    Times:       Fridays and Saturdays at 7:00pm and Sundays at 2:00pm
    Location:  ARTS/West, 152 West State Street, Athens, OH
    Tickets:     $11 for adults (13+) and $8 for children


    No matter what you do to help, we love you and appreciate you. Thank you so much!!!
