story:
Yup, we’re taking on the big one!

Our rather unorthodox production of the Bard’s masterpiece will re-imagine Hamlet as a young female royal in a modern world.

Hamlet will be female played by a female actor.

Staying true to the original dialogue, the intention is that our contemporary take will not skew the heart of this iconic tale, but rather help awaken and refresh the character dynamics, struggles, and poetry that have made this piece the timeless classic it is today.


So shall you hear of carnal, bloody, and unnatural acts, of accidental judgements, casual slaughters, of deaths put on by cunning and forc'd cause, and in this upshot, purposes mistook fall'n on th'inventors' heads.

All this can we truly deliver.


What kind of a world would a popular young Prince grow up in today?

A key force that drives our new interpretation of the play will be the influence of fame. The power that our royalty have, the power that Claudius kills for, is the power that comes from fame or celebrity status (think an amped up version of Will & Kate). We will flash newspaper articles, magazine covers, and twitter updates to give the audience additional information about the world the characters are living in and how they are viewed by the public. Hamlet has been in this place of fame since birth. Everything she does is scrutinized. When she puts on an “antic disposition”, or plays mad, she will be clearly playing this to the public.

Right out of the gate Hamlet brings into question the difference between what “is” and what “seems”. In our modern western culture, a culture obsessed with beauty and power, we are often encouraged to believe that what is seen on the surface is what matters most. Hamlet challenges this idea of superficial reality and digs to discover the truth.


Check out the Gallery for our cast bios :)

An obvious change from the classic play is that our Hamlet will be… a woman.  We believe this keeps integrity with the original message and plot of the play. It will inevitably charge the character relationships with a different kind of energy and context allowing the audience to experience the character, and the characters around her, in a fresh light.

In addition to changing Hamlet’s gender, we will also be gender swapping Laertes, Rosencrantz and Marcello (now Marcella).

We are fiercely committed as a company to expanding and exploring the voices of females in the arts and in our society. We feel that allowing the audience to view a woman navigating Hamlet’s famous struggle will not only be an enjoyable and exciting experience to witness, but will be ultimately be a positive and valuable exercise for all involved.





In order to realize this ambitious production, we need to raise $20 000. This will go into the cost of supplies for set construction, wardrobe, makeup (and makeup artist), props, lighting (and lighting technician), sound design (and sound mixer), projection equipment, video production costs, printing of scripts and posters, and cast/crew honorariums. This is our estimation for a low budget production. If we exceed this goal, there are many items we left out of our budget that we would be able to include.

We will be working with a co-op agreement between all the cast and crew. Each person will keep track of their hours and we’ll divide any profit depending on hours put in. If we exceed our goal we will be able to better compensate our talented team! This is one of the reasons your contribution would be so greatly appreciated!

If you are unable to donate money, here are other great ways in which you can support our production:


                                                                                                                Facebook
                                                                                     Twitter:  @KaileySpear @SamSSpear

Thank you so much!! Any support will be hugely appreciated!



              Wednesday October 29 - preview 7pm
              Thursday October 30 - 7pm
               Friday October 31 - Halloween special :) 7pm
               Saturday November 1 - 7pm
               Sunday November 2 - Matinee 2pm (for Bowen crowd)

              


                                                                                    Thursday November 6th - 7pm
                                                                                           Friday November 7th - 7pm
                                                                                     Saturday November 8th - 7pm
                                                                                        Sunday November 9th - 7pm




                                           


From 2008-2012, we went to SFU and completed degrees in film (both receiving honours). We work together as directors on our films. Although our careers are pointed in the film direction, we are taking this time to go back to our roots and direct a stage production. In the future, we hope to complete a film adaptation of Hamlet as well.

Raised in a household where his plays were used as bedtime stories, we have grown up to be strong believers in Shakespeare’s ability to timelessly explore the delicacies of the human condition. From age five (when we first allowed our dad to read us A Midsummer Night’s Dream because there were fairies in it) we have been fans of Shakespeare. We started acting in Grade 2 and attended Tir-na-nOg Theatre School on Bowen Island for many years. It was at that school when we got our first introduction to Hamlet. Amazingly, at thirteen, we and other students in Grade 8/9 were given the opportunity to perform the entire play. Being exposed to the play at a young age made us realize that Shakespeare’s Hamlet is not meant to be placed on a pedestal to be kept out of reach. The themes it addresses and the situations the characters are faced with are universal.

The more time we spend with this play the more we are taken by it’s profound contemporary relevance. Hamlet is a young person, isolated by fame and responsibility, seeking the best possible path to justice and redemption while grappling with themes of love, family, loyalty, good and evil, revenge, death, and well… everything that makes life such a crazy trip.

For years now we have been nurturing and developing our dream to mount a version of Hamlet in Vancouver. We are so excited that our dream has now been set in motion!

Thank You Bill. We endeavour to make you proud.

And thank you all for your support! Our gratitude is beyond words.

                                                                                                   -Kailey and Sam Spear, Directors
                                                                                                                 & Libby Osler, Hamlet


Where is this sight?
What is it you would see? If aught of woe, cease your search.



So shall you hear of carnal, bloody, and unnatural acts, of accidental judgements, casual slaughters, of deaths put on by cunning and forc'd cause, and in this upshot, purposes mistook fall'n on th'inventors' heads.

* Any additional funding that we receive - this made possible by IndieGoGo's "Forever Funding" pilot program- will be put towards the development of our film adaptation. *

story:
DECLASSIFIED!


ABOUT WedRepCo

We are a dynamic group of actors, writers, and directors, making our home in NYC. We are dedicated to exploring the role and limits of narrative theatre in today's society. Over the last five years, WedRepCo has introduced over 50 new plays to the New York Theatre scene. With "DECLASSIFIED!" we look forward to continuing our mission. To accomplish this, we need assistance from you-- our audience. It doesn't take a lot to support our efforts, but in return, we promise we will continue to entertain you, challenge you, and experience, with you, the joy of contemporary theatre!

Thank you for your contribution!

--

Performance dates & times: (Shows begin on November 12th and end on the 23rd.)

Wednesdays - Fridays: 8PM

Saturdays: 2PM & 8PM

Sundays: 5PM

We look forward to seeing you at the show!

story:
What we’re doing

The Satori Group is making Returning to Albert Joseph in Williamstown this September! We're partnering with the '62 Center and Williams College to build a new production on the Adams Memorial Stage on September 18 and 19. We’re so excited about pursuing a production of this show outside of Seattle, where it can reach a new audience, be built to tour, and be exposed to presenters.


Why this play

Returning to Albert Joseph is a story about love, loss, and what remains when our words are gone.

Other things it’s about: family, survival, knowing, caring, scarcity, abundance, bread, beans, BOATS. 

It’s about what we remember and why we forget. It’s about trying to create a new world in another person, and the question of whether we can save each other. The play examines the cost of maintaining the structures that are given to us and the price we pay when we resist.

In a society where rational thinkers are heroes and those who don’t fit are forgotten, Andrea and Leo are two strangers brought together under extraordinary circumstances. After witnessing an unspeakable act of violence, Leo’s mind goes blank. Alone in a long abandoned schoolhouse, Andrea attempts to fix him. Together the two dive into their memories, but in trying to save each other they risk destroying themselves.

This is a play about losing nouns, losing the plot, and more generally loss. Which sounds like a bummer in a way that this play isn’t a bummer. Because it’s also a dystopian adventure with comedic schoolhouse elements!


Why now

After five years of development, including a first full iteration in Seattle last year, we are now ready to fully realize this play. We learned that people are as intrigued as we are by this story. And we learned that we need to do it again.

The Satori Group was founded in 2007 by a group of graduates from Williams College and UC’s College Conservatory of Music (CCM). The company has been based in Seattle since 2008 and continues its relationship with Williams College through artistic residencies, alumni events, and through Caitlin’s work as Artistic Director of the Summer Theatre Lab. Satori is thrilled to have the opportunity to bring a full production to the Purple Valley.


How you can help

In the same way we need our community’s voice and input to grow our work, we need its support now to help us take it to the next level. While Williams College and the '62 Center are providing us with incredible production and marketing support, we'll need to bring a full team out to help build our first touring production.

$10,000 gets this show to Williamstown and allows us to build it right, to invest in the future of this piece, and to develop the work and reach of the Satori Group.

It breaks down like this

$4,500 to artist salaries for 11 people

$2,400 to travel & housing for 11 people

$1,300 to production materials

$1,000 to capturing the work & the tools we need to take it further

$800 to administrative expenses


Our Williamstown Team (full of Ephs!)

Playwright - Spike Friedman (Williams ‘07)
Director - Caitlin Sullivan (Williams ‘07)
Leo - Quinn Franzen (Williams ‘09)
Andrea - Alex Highsmith
Design Dramaturg and PSM - Clare Strasser
Scenic Designer - Cate McCrea (Williams ‘13)
Costume Designer - Doreen Sayegh & Greta Wilson (Williams '07)
Lighting Designer - Isabella Byrd
Sound Designer - Eben Hoffer (Williams ‘10)
Technical Director - Carl Whipple (Williams ‘12)


The Satori Group

Ensemble
Adam Standley, Alex Matthews (Williams ‘07), Caitlin Sullivan (Williams ‘07), Clare Strasser, Greta Wilson (Williams ‘07), Kate Sumpter, Lauren Hester (Williams ‘07), Liza Curtiss (Williams ‘09), LoraBeth Barr, Quinn Franzen (Williams ‘09), Spike Friedman (Williams ‘07)

Associate Artists
Antoinette Bianco, Carol Thompson, Doreen Sayegh, John Leith, Kristyne A. Hughes, Lindsey Valitchka, Martyna Majok, Montana Tippett, Monty Taylor, Nathan Sorseth

The Satori Group is an ensemble of theatremakers generating new work with an eye toward audience experience. Through an intensely collaborative process, we build detailed theatrical worlds that viscerally embody our questions about where the small, the domestic, the personal meet the large, the political, the collective. Our work approaches uncertainty as a positive, as the place where change happens. We look at the cracking of facades and the crumbling of structures with compassion and humor, so that we may sincerely attempt something new. Satori productions are designed to speak intimately to the individual with moments of collective resonance.

The play examines the cost of maintaining the structures that are given to us and the price we pay when we resist. In a society where rational thinkers are heroes and those who don’t fit are forgotten, Andrea and Leo are two strangers brought together under extraordinary circumstances. After witnessing an unspeakable act of violence, Leo’s mind goes blank. Alone in a long abandoned schoolhouse, Andrea attempts to fix him. Together the two dive into their memories, but in trying to save each other they risk destroying themselves. This is a play about losing nouns, losing the plot, and more generally loss. Which sounds like a bummer in a way that this play isn’t a bummer. Because it’s also a dystopian adventure with comedic schoolhouse elements!Why now After five years of development, including a first full iteration in Seattle last year, we are now ready to fully realize this play. We learned that people are as intrigued as we are by this story. And we learned that we need to do it again. The Satori Group was founded in 2007 by a group of graduates from Williams College and UC’s College Conservatory of Music (CCM). The company has been based in Seattle since 2008 and continues its relationship with Williams College through artistic residencies, alumni events, and through Caitlin’s work as Artistic Director of the Summer Theatre Lab. Satori is thrilled to have the opportunity to bring a full production to the Purple Valley. How you can helpIn the same way we need our community’s voice and input to grow our work, we need its support now to help us take it to the next level. While Williams College and the '62 Center are providing us with incredible production and marketing support, we'll need to bring a full team out to help build our first touring production.$10,000 gets this show to Williamstown and allows us to build it right, to invest in the future of this piece, and to develop the work and reach of the Satori Group. It breaks down like this$4,500 to artist salaries for 11 people$2,400 to travel & housing for 11 people$1,300 to production materials$1,000 to capturing the work & the tools we need to take it further$800 to administrative expensesOur Williamstown Team (full of Ephs!)Playwright - Spike Friedman (Williams ‘07)Director - Caitlin Sullivan (Williams ‘07)Leo - Quinn Franzen (Williams ‘09)Andrea - Alex HighsmithDesign Dramaturg and PSM - Clare StrasserScenic Designer - Cate McCrea (Williams ‘13)Costume Designer - Doreen Sayegh & Greta Wilson (Williams '07)Lighting Designer - Isabella ByrdSound Designer - Eben Hoffer (Williams ‘10)Technical Director - Carl Whipple (Williams ‘12)The Satori GroupEnsembleAdam Standley, Alex Matthews (Williams ‘07), Caitlin Sullivan (Williams ‘07), Clare Strasser, Greta Wilson (Williams ‘07), Kate Sumpter, Lauren Hester (Williams ‘07), Liza Curtiss (Williams ‘09), LoraBeth Barr, Quinn Franzen (Williams ‘09), Spike Friedman (Williams ‘07)Associate ArtistsAntoinette Bianco, Carol Thompson, Doreen Sayegh, John Leith, Kristyne A. Hughes, Lindsey Valitchka, Martyna Majok, Montana Tippett, Monty Taylor, Nathan SorsethThe Satori Group is an ensemble of theatremakers generating new work with an eye toward audience experience. Through an intensely collaborative process, we build detailed theatrical worlds that viscerally embody our questions about where the small, the domestic, the personal meet the large, the political, the collective. Our work approaches uncertainty as a positive, as the place where change happens. We look at the cracking of facades and the crumbling of structures with compassion and humor, so that we may sincerely attempt something new. Satori productions are designed to speak intimately to the individual with moments of collective resonance.

story:
Have you ever looked at your life and felt that something was missing? Like your friends are moving on, moving out, getting married or having kids, and you're just... stuck?

That is how our heroine feels when she turns 30, still lives in her parents' house and has no job, never mind career. That is, until she develops magical powers and goes on an odyssey of her own. Join Laurentina on an adventure that might just awaken your own magical abilities.


Acclaimed performer, playwright, and improv extraordinaire Lauren Stein is taking her latest play, Laurentina's Oddyssey, on the road (well, actually, to the skies) to Australia and New Zealand. This trip is two-fold: she is spreading her message of personal empowerment to other parts of the world, while at the same time walking the walk of fulfilling her dreams, performing on the other side of the world.

Yes, but what does this have to do with me?

Everything! You now have the opportunity not only to see this famous play in action, but also to be a part of that dream. By contributing to this campaign, whether seeing the show, making a donation, or telling everyone you know about it, you are part of the truth that dreams do come true and everything is possible.

How can I, a humble Torontonian, see this play?

Fear not, fellow city-dwellers! For one night only, Laurentina will debut her dazzling new play, Laurentina's Oddyssey, here in Kensington Market, before our funny-accented friends* get their chance!

*If you are Australian and this offends you, I didn't mean you. I meant the New Zealanders.

When: Thursday, February 16, 7:00 - 10:00 pm
Where: Waterfalls Indian Tapas Bar & Grill, 303 Augusta Avenue
Cost: $15 via this page / $20 at the door

Schedule of Events
7:00 - 7:45   - Musical Acts: Elio Miranda, Naomi Benoist, Annie Gilbert, Marni Levitt
8:00 - 9:00   - Laurentina's Oddyssey
9:00 - 9:30   - Q&A with Lauren â€“ you may ask her anything you wish!
9:30 - 9:45   - Raffle winners will be announced.
9:45 - 11:00 - You may head home and get a good night's sleep, or stay and socialise!
                       THE CHOICE IS YOURS!

There will also be raffle prizes and door prizes. With every raffle ticket, you can select a different prize. Prizes that will be raffled include:

  • Tickets to the AGO and their upcoming Picasso exhibit
  • Gift certificates to Akram's Shoppe (Authentic Middle Eastern Foods)
  • Emotional Intelligence prize pack: EQ Edge and EI for Dummies books
  • Gift Basket from The Fairies Pyjamas
  • Gift Basket from Geri's Eatin' Centre
  • Free improv workshops from Laurentina's Improv Club
  • Steam Whistle Brewing tour (and beer!) for you and your friends
  • Tea and Coffee band t-shirts
  • Gift Basket from Tribal Eye, at 73 Kensington Avenue
  • $50 gift certificate to Waterfalls Indian Tapas and Bar
  • Studio portrait session and 5x7 print from Who Do You Love? Photography
  • and more -- including a surprise MYSTERY PACKAGE!!

AND, as if all that weren't enough, admission to the evening gets you 10% off your delicious food orders at Waterfalls!

Can I show up without reserving a ticket?

The restaurant needs to know how many people will be coming for the show. If we are at capacity, they will turn down reservations from people who just want to eat and make noise. If we sell above our expectations (which, quite frankly, I am expecting), they will set up space to accommodate more butts than tables.

ALSO -

Indiegogo takes a percentage of the money raised online, and that percentage is higher if I do not reach my goal. Therefore, it is in our best interest to support the campaign via this website. See what I'm saying?

And yes, there is limited seating at the restaurant. You may want to reserve your seat in case the show sells out.

When you purchase a ticket, your name will be on the guest list. You will not need to bring anything. Except the memory of what your name is, because without that... we won't know how to help you.

And don't be afraid to come alone! You can choose to sit at a table with other people -- which is a great way to make friends!

How do I buy more than one ticket?

When you make your contribution, you can buy as many tickets as you want by entering a dollar amount equivalent to $15 x the number of tickets. So, if you are buying tickets for your dodgeball team of 9, click the ball next to "See the Show in Toronto!" and enter your total contribution amount as ($15 x 9 =) $135. But if you know that Andy wants the opportunity to win cool stuff like gift certificates, and obviously you do too, then click the ball next to "See the Show + 5 Raffle Tix!" and add 5 raffle tickets for each of you, which is 2 x $10 = $20. Add that to $135 and contribute $155.

Or, if all of this confuses you, just type in a really big number like $300 and you can't lose.

At Step 3 -- Comment, write the names of everybody attending, and write the number of raffle tickets each person wants. Then when you show up, you will get the red-carpet treatment. Your names will be on the guest list, you will be handed raffle tickets with your name on them, and you get to sit in any vacant seat you want.

Questions? Comments? You can e-mail me at me@Laurentina.me

What if I can't make that date?

There are so many other ways to contribute to this campaign! There are tons of perks in store, including raffle tickets, an original story written for you, a walking tour of any area in downtown Toronto, and a souvenir from Down Under! See the list on the right for more possibilities.

Or, if you would like to contribute without rewards, simply click "Contribute Now" and enter an amount, such as $25 or $40.

Where is my hard-earned money going?

Well, certainly not towards buying purses, as anyone who's ever met me can attest.

While it costs $2500 to fly Down Under, I have applied for a Canada Council for the Arts grant for $2500 (wish me luck!) Also, as perhaps the thriftiest person you know, I am not spending any money on props, costume, rehearsal space (using only what I have), sets, special effects, or tech people (using only what's available), hotels (thank you, couchsurfing.org), entertainment visa (thank you, Adelaide Fringe), or many of the things that a perfectly reasonable person might spend travel dollars on.

However, I still have costs!!

Entry in the Adelaide Fringe Festival, renting performance space, and placing one ad in a local paper costs.
Entry in the Dunedin Fringe Festival costs.
I will have to pay for flights to get between cities; transportation within cities; food (which I hear is expensive down there -- unless some kind locals buy me a meal. I'm just sayin'), health insurance, and other travel-related costs. (Like sky-diving. I can admit to that, right?)

In addition, a portion of the proceeds will be donated to Patch Adams-led groups of humanitarian clowns providing Gesundheit Global Outreach. So, the more you give, the more people in developing parts of the world will have their souls uplifted through the gift of laughter. As anyone who has ever suffered trauma or depression can tell you, mental health is an integral part of overall health and quality of life.

Where else can I see the Laurentina in action?


Every Monday night, Ms. L conducts improv workshops in her home studio. Learn what this improv craze is all about, why businesses are recommending it for staff in any field, and why it will make you a better person.


When: Every Monday, 7:30-9:30 pm.
Where: 51 Kensington Avenue (near Dundas and Spadina)
Cost: $20
Web: LaurentinasImprovClub.info


Laurentina's "Down Under" Tour


Adelaide Fringe Festival


Sunday, February 26 - 3:00 pm

Sunday, February 26 - 9:00 pm

Sunday, March 4        - 3:00 pm


Queen's Theatre 3, Corner Gilles Arcade & Playhouse Lane

Link: http://www.adelaidefringe.com.au/fringetix/laur...


Guest at On the Fly's first night of A Hat Full of Arm Pits


Saturday, February 25 - 7:00 pm


The Worldsend Hotel, 208 Hindley Street

Link: http://onthefly.org.au/index.php?option=com_con...


On the Fly Improvisation Workshop, Adelaide


Monday, February 27 - 6:30 pm

Box Factory Community Centre

Link: http://onthefly.org.au/index.php?option=com_con...


Storytelling Workshop, Dunedin


Tuesday, March 20 - 6-10 pm

Allen Hall Theatre, at the University of Otago, Department of Theatre Studies


Dunedin Fringe Festival


Thursday, March 22 - 8:00 pm

The Church - Restaurant, Bar & Cinema, 50 Dundas St.


Who is this Lauren Stein?


Trained in the arts of improvisation, drama, public speaking, and clowning, Lauren Stein is an all-around threat. She has been teaching weekly drop-in improv classes for three years under her company Laurentina's Improv Club.

At the Toronto Fringe Festival 2011, Lauren created and starred in the improvised and interactive Laurentina's Funhouse, a walking tour of the home of a circus performer who always wanted to run away and become an accountant. After that, she led Superhero Tours of 401 Richmond for Nuit Blanche 2011, Toronto's "all-night contemporary art thing."

Lauren has spent a month on a circus farm, co-produced two webseries, and produced a theatre festival. She has completed the Summer Improv Intensive at Impatient Theatre Company, the Improvisation Program at Second City, and trained under Michael Gellman, Gary Austin, and Kevin Frank, among others, at the Artistic New Directions improv intensive programs in the Catskills. She received her BA in Drama from the University of Guelph, and is completing two LTCL certifications with Trinity Guildhall, a division of Oxford University, in Communication Skills and in Speech and Drama.

story:
OzCabaret ...our story

Chapter I

Once upon a time, back in 2007, three lovely ladies and one tall young man packed up their lives and headed to the humble seaside city of Mackay in QLD to seek their fortunes and study the craft of performing arts at the Central Queensland Conservatorium of Music.

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
It was here that the four became friends and after three years of honing their skills they each left to find their way in the big wide world. Then something miraculous happened..

 

Chapter II

In 2012 the four found themselves in the same corner of Europe (the Netherlands to be exact) and, while sampling some vino one evening, decided that they should combine their passions (vino+theatre+music) and create something that the world had never seen before.

And so it came to be that vino + theatre + music + eachother =

Chapter III

The four worked hard on creating their very own spicy brand of interactive wine-tasting entertainment. They showcased their work in the Netherlands before moving to the UK and testing it out on the English crowd, all the while working hard to improve and learn and be the best that they could be.

They even flew their old CQCM singing teacher, Kim Kirkman, over to add his famed spit and polish to their work.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Chapter IV

As fate would have it, Mark Fawcett from the MECC stepped up and offered the troupe an amazing opportunity to help celebrate the centres 25th Jubilee birthday by presenting the Australian premier of the Champagne Cabaret.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

The night was a great success with fun and bubbles enjoyed by all.

The troupe then went on to perform an incredible sell-out season at the Adelaide Fringe Festival, receiving love from audiences and rave reviews from critics.

"GRIPPING AND EMOTIONAL IN ITS DRAMATIC HIGHS AND LOWS, THE MESSAGE BEING THAT CHAMPAGNE IS FOR ALL OF LIFE, HAPPY AND SAD. THERE'S A CHARM AND PERSONAL SPACE ENTERED THAT GIVE THIS DRAWING ROOM EXPERIENCE GENUINE HEART AND SOUL.” Adelaide Now

“THE BLEND OF VIOLIN, ACCORDION AND PIANO AND POLISHED VOCAL HARMONIES BRINGS THIS SHOW TO LIFE…IF YOU ARE LOOKING FOR A TASTEFUL TASTE OF WINE AND SONG LOOK NO FURTHER.” All About Entertainment

 

Chapter V

Here's where you come in...

We have a tour of Europe in the pipeworks, starting with the world renowned Edinburgh Fringe Festival.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

We will then be heading to the Netherlands where we have been selected to be a part of the Amsterdam Fringe Festival and also the Best of the Fest in Eindhoven before making our way to England for the London Wine & Cheese Festival. We have also been invited to perform at the Macau Fringe Festival, but we have to get through this bumper schedule before we can even start thinking about taking up this great opportunity.

 

 

 

 

 

 

We're very excited to be making our debut at these wonderful festivals and to be spreading a little Aussie culture around the globe. It has been predicted by the Scotsman of the Edinburgh Evening Times that OzCabaret will be one of the top 10 picks of the Edinburgh Fringe this year: http://www.scotsman.com/edinburgh-evening-news/latest-news/edinburgh-festival-fringe-top-10-picks-1-2994355

Not bad out of over 3000 other shows presenting at Edinburgh this year!

 

Chapter VI

...is yet to be written because we need your help!

We promise to keep up the hard work and represent Aussies in the only way we know how, but we need some financial support to make it happen.

It is every young performers dream to play at the Edinburgh Fringe, the worlds biggest and most renowned arts festival, and with your help our dreams can come true.

The costs of getting us through this tour are unspeakable, but just to give you an idea of where it all goes here's a snapshot:

€2000 - Festival applications and licensing

€3660 - Accommodation

€2500 - Production costs

€5000 - Contractor fees

€6000 - Travel

€4000 - Promotions and PR

= a grand total of a house deposit and then some!

 

But as the great Ella Fitzgerald said, "don’t give up trying to do what you really want to do. Where there is love and inspiration, you can't go wrong".

No donation is too small, it all counts!

If you are unable to contribute financially...FEAR NOT!

You can help spread the word far and wide of our mission you will still be helping us on our way to acheiving our dreams!


Simply put a link to this page and 'friend' us on Facebook or Twitter or whatever your social network!

Our website www.ozcabaret.com

Our facebook page www.facebook.com/ozcabaret

Our twitter www.twitter.com/OzCabaret

Tickets for the show, at the Hispaniola between 31st July - 25th August are now available to purchase:

https://www.edfringe.com/whats-on/cabaret/champagne-cabaret

From the bottom of our hearts, thank you so much for visiting our page and helping us to live our dream!

Much love,

the OzCabaret troupe xx

€3660 - Accommodation 
€2500 - Production costs
 €5000 - Contractor fees
€6000 - Travel 
€4000 - Promotions and PR 
= a grand total of a house deposit and then some! 
 
But as the great Ella Fitzgerald said, "don’t give up trying to do what you really want to do. Where there is love and inspiration, you can't go wrong".
No donation is too small, it all counts!
If you are unable to contribute financially...FEAR NOT!  You can help spread the word far and wide of our mission you will still be helping us on our way to acheiving our dreams! 
 Simply put a link to this page and 'friend' us on Facebook or Twitter or whatever your social network!
Our website www.ozcabaret.com  Our facebook page  www.facebook.com/ozcabaret Our twitter  www.twitter.com/OzCabaret Tickets for the show, at the Hispaniola between 31st July - 25th August are now available to purchase: https://www.edfringe.com/whats-on/cabaret/champagne-cabaret From the bottom of our hearts, thank you so much for visiting our page and helping us to live our dream!  Much love, the OzCabaret troupe xx

story:
Our Story

Art is about risk-taking.  Art forces us to look inside ourselves and evaluate how we feel about the world.  Art can make you smile.  And Art programs in schools are disturbingly underfunded (1/3 of Bay Area schools don't offer music classes, and 1/2 of Bay Area schools don't offer visual arts classes).  With all of this in mind, the staff of Young Audiences has accepted an art-making challenge that includes lots of risk-taking, a considerable amount of internal evaluation, and, in all likelihood, a fair share of smiles.  And we are doing it to support Arts in schools. 

Can four non-profit professional women learn Hip Hop in 3 months?! Without pulling any ligaments? And while paying due respect to an art form that is demanding, disciplined, and focused?  That’s our goal!

Professional dancer and Young Audiences teaching artist, Jason “Spidey” Ferguson, has accepted the Herculean challenge of teaching his dope moves to four ladies who are determined to raise money for Arts Education.  Our friends think we’re crazy.  And we are---crazy about making a difference to Bay Area children.

All four of us--Kris, Emily, Lilia & Jill--work for Young Audiences of Northern California, a premiere provider of Arts Education in the Bay Area.  Together, our crew is 3MD, and our goal is to learn and do justice to hip hop dance.  We will then publicly perform our routine at Ethno-Noh-Tec’s “Salon You’re On!’ event, coming up on January 28th. You are officially invited to watch our premiere.  We will also record this performance and upload it for your viewing pleasure (?).  But you only get to see the video if you sponsor our effort. 

Any amount is helpful, from $5 to $500.  We ask you to consider the risks we are taking (bodily injury, public humiliation, and potential alienation of the entire community of Hip Hop artists and performers).  And we ask you to pledge your support toward our efforts.  It's not a half-marathon.  It's not an all night walk.  But it is hard and risky and a significant challenge for all four of us.  We hope that you will support our artistic risk-taking with a pledge toward our $2,000 goal.  All funds raised will go to Young Audiences of Northern California.

So help us with a donation.  Help us spread the word.  This project is the first of what we hope will be many projects in the ongoing Young Audience's Create-a-Thon--a fundraising campaign in which we challenge our community to join us in taking art-making risks and to raise money for arts programs in Bay Area schools.  

The Impact

All funds raised will go to support Young Audiences of Northern California, which provides a wide spectrum of arts education to school children in the Bay Area. Young Audiences works with professional, world-class artists to bring high-quality arts education to schools that are in desperate need of arts education.  For more than 50 years, Young Audiences has been a key partner of Bay Area schools, and we have never been a more necessary partner than we are in today's school funding climate.  By supporting Young Audiences, you will be providing children in the Bay Area with an opportunity to experience, discover, create, and connect with world-class music, dance, theater & visual arts.

Other Ways You Can Help

Join us and bring your friends to our performance on January 28th at 977 South Van Ness Avenue.  Get your friends to support our efforts.  And check out our Young Audiences website--www.ya-nc.org.  And consider joining us with your own creative challenge.  What have you always wanted to do?  What scares you?  Take a risk, and join our Create-a-thon!  We'll support you with outreach and publicity and deep appreciation.

story:
Short Summary

The Brelby Theatre Company is a grassroots theatre troupe, founded by Northern Arizona University alumnae, Brian & Shelby Maticic. We recently signed the lease on a stellar storefront in Historical Downtown Glendale, AZ. We look forward to providing intimate theatre to the West Valley, including new works from local playwrights.

The costs of opening a small business can be daunting, but we believe in our company and the quality of theatre that we produce. We’re looking for help from our wonderful community to light the way, and aid us in raising the funds to purchase our own lighting and sound board to outfit the studio.

Covering the costs of this equipment will help us to shift our current funds towards several other needs for the space that we must fulfill in order to open our location. (ie: construction, new ac unit, etc.)

We are working to raise $3500 to cover the costs of the equipment, including a lighting board, lighting instruments and additional lighting accessories.

The Impact

We’re excited to bring quality theatre to the Downtown Glendale community, and your contribution will help make it a possibility. Once open, the Brelby studio will not only offer a season of mainstage productions, but also a variety of original plays, classes and workshops for the West Valley community.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that times are tough, and some people aren’t in a position to contribute financially, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help.

Word of mouth is the most valuable marketing tool out there. Help us to spread word about our campaign, our 2012 season, and our new Glendale location. Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Help Produce This Play!

He Ate Quietly into the Wall 

It cannot go on without you!

He Ate Quietly into the Wall has been given a two-week run at Page 22 in Chelsea, NYC, in September.

THE SPACE:

Page 22 is a performance space and classroom on West 22nd Street in Manhattan dedicated to furthering the legacy of Geraldine Page by creating a vibrant environment for emerging and established writers, directors and actors in the performing arts. Page 22 occupies the Chelsea townhouse where Ms. Page and her husband and partner Rip Torn lived and worked beginning in 1964. Currently managed by Tony Torn, Page 22 is the home of Presence 929, a professional film actors training program lead by Actor/Director Clark Middleton.

We have a talented group of artists working on this project for very small stipends. 

Your donation will pay for:

  • rehearsal space
  • stipends for the actors, sound designers, and props/set/costume designer
  • building lighting tools
  • costumes
  • materials for building props
  • boxed wine for the performances
  • a photographer to document the play
  • a filmmaker to document the play

THE PLAY:

He Ate Quietly into the Wall features Noel Joseph Allain, Jocelyn Kuritsky, Mary Rasmussen, and Alexander Wright. 

Written + Directed by Ariel Stess

Technical Direction + Design by Samuel Stonefield

Sound, Music, and Recordings by Jon Berstein and Deepthi Welaratna

Scenic Design by Abigail Lloyd

Photo by Winston Mason Riley

Poster by Walter Green

Promo Video by Maxwell Cosmo Cramer and Monroe Street

Performances on Sept. 7th, 8th, 14th, and 15th

This will be the premier of He Ate Quietly into the Wall and the first of Ariel's plays to have a two-week run. These plays need to be seen in full dimension to resonate. And in this theatrical climate and as a young and "emerging" NYC artist, it is incredibly rare to be supported with space --- Page 22 --- and time. So, this is a critical moment for the play, for Ariel's growth as producer, director, and playwright, and for nurturing the collaborative relationships that make a three-dimensional play palpable.

A donation of any size is invaluable!

It also really helps to get the word out by sharing this link with friends who enjoy and believe in these projects.

Thank you so much for helping to support the show at this crucial moment. 

He Ate Quietly into the Wall attempts to get at: what it feels like to grow up and the things we played with when we were young. 

 

**More info on the artists**

Ariel Stess is a playwright, director, and performer. She received her MFA in Playwriting from Brooklyn College where she studied under Erin Courtney and Mac Wellman. She holds a BA from Bard College where she studied under Chiori Miyagawa and Dominic Taylor. She's shown work at Dixon Place, East 13th Street Theatre, The Observatory Room, Uncanny Valley, the Geraldine Page Salon, the Bushwick Starr, and Bard College. Plays include: The Waiter, Prowlers in the Night (premiered at Bard College), Mother Milk, The Lock and Door, and The Only Girl in the Hot Tub. She's collaborated with Jon Bernstein, Maxwell Cosmo Cramer, LaShea Delaney, Nora Deveau-Rosen, Meghan Finn, Barbara Harrison, Claire Moodey, Samuel Stonefield, and Deepthi Welaratna. She's currently working on Larger Objects, a new play about a woman held captive by her high school sweethearts; You Didn't See Her Alone, a new play about a working family man held hostage by his obligations; and an as-yet-untitled play charting the long and liberating drive between Santa Fe and Taos, New Mexico, as undertaken by three high school students ditching Pre-Cal. Ariel teaches English composition at Brooklyn College and BMCC.

Samuel Stonefield was born in Tokyo, Japan. He makes theater and films. He has worked with luminaries such as JoAnne Akalaitis, Daniel Fish, and Theodora Skipitares. He recently assisted the visual artist Daniel Arsham on the set for the final performances of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company at the Park Avenue Armory. His short film RIVER'S HOUSE will debut in August. Also in development are video works for musicians Andrea Schiavelli and Chris Garneau. BA Bard College '09. 

Jon Bernstein is a composer and sound designer living in Brooklyn, New York and originally from San Francisco, California.  He has composed four albums of ambient music and has been doing sound design for the theater since 2005.  He works in digital marketing at a book publisher during the daylight hours.

Deepthi Welaratna lives in Brooklyn. She creates videos and writes stories. She also makes music under the name Saxxe. Her short experimental video "Wood," created in collaboration with Jon Bernstein, won an honorable mention in 2011's Mixed Messages show at The New School. In 2010, she served as a judge for Growing Up Asian in America, an annual art and essay competition for Bay Area k-12 students. Currently at a startup in NYC, she has worked in radio and TV broadcasting and authored an arts and culture review column for KQED in San Francisco covering music, theatre and film. She received her MA in Media Studies from The New School in 2010.

Abigail Lloyd is a builder and illustrator living in Brooklyn.  She is interested in exploring subtle intimacy, the American gothic and comfort/discomfort in her work variously with metal, video, pen+paper and found materials.  Ongoing projects include a monthly installment of an illustrated calendar, digital monoprints and surface-heavy minimal welded sculpture.  In the last year, Abigail has built theater sets for plays at the Observatory in Brooklyn and Dixon Place in Manhattan, had a series of digital prints at a show in Oakland, CA, and had an illustration published in an online fiction review.  Abigail teaches art classes at public elementary schools in New York City.  She received her B.A. from Bard College in 2007.

Stay tuned for more artist bios and info on the play's progress.

SHOWTIMES: September 7, 8, 14, 15 at 7:30 pm and 9:00 pm. E-mail heatequietlyintothewall@gmail.com to reserve seats.

story:
Who and What is Canary?


CANARY is a new musical that fuses blues to bluegrass to rock'n'roll, with a few stops in between. Set in the heartland of America and seen through the eyes of four lonely teenagers, it traces the generation and regeneration of our country's music. A band might form. A banjo might break. And a young girl will hear an electric guitar for the first time. 


CANARY is for anyone who ever was or dreamed of being a part of a band, for anyone who remembers listening to Led Zeppelin for the first time, and for anyone wondering what the sound pulsing at the center of our great American mess sounds like.


CANARY was first conceived in 2007 by Obie Award-winning director Rachel Chavkin (Three Pianos, Artistic Director of The TEAM), playwright/ musician Molly Rice (The Saints Tour, Don't Stop, book for Futurity, a Musical by the Lisps), and musician Ray Rizzo (Adam Rapp's Finer Noble Gases, Shakespeare in the Park's Twelfth Night and bands Less the Band, Corporal, Dawn Landes and the Hounds, Days of the New). After several rounds of development, it's ready for its final shaping and presentation in a workshop supported by Off-Broadway's New York Theater Workshop in May. NYTW's generously providing space and time to work through their Production Assistance Grant; but the Canary team needs your help in paying the actors and musicians for their work on this quirky, offbeat new play. 


The artists' collaboration began with a quick coffeehouse meeting that expanded into an hours-long, amped-up conversation about 60's girl bands, ambient composition, high schools, Led Zeppelin, ghosts, Rush and the High Lonesome of bluegrass music. Unlike most musicals, Rice and Rizzo wrote the songs first, and in winter of '07, they played a concert in lieu of a play reading at the Lower East Side bar Jimmy 43. Rattlestick Playwrights Theater attended and offered them a workshop in the Summer of '08, which was a well-received jump-start. In December, Playwrights Horizons invited them to do a workshop, and since then it's been through several self-supported rounds of musical and text development. 


After 3 years, we believe we are entering the final leg of development-- a vital time for a new musical. We're counting on you guys to make this final step possible. Our NYTW workshop will be an opportunity to introduce this special piece to the theater community at large, and hopefully garner support for a long-awaited New York production.

Why do we need your help?

We have an amazing cast, including Jane Pfitch, Charise Greene, Carlo Alban, Rebecca Henderson, and Dale Soules, along with fantastic musicians like Rizzo and Don Piper.  They love the play and are willing to work for the barest minimum, but they can't work for nothing. That's where you come in!


What We Need & What You Get


Although a lot of volunteer hours go into the making of great art, our artists have to support themselves one way or another.  Our overhead for this project is low due to the generous support of NYTW; we just need to provide fair stipends to our performers for their time and work.  Any money we bring in over the actors' and musicians' stipends we will put into paying for the recording sessions for the show's demo CD-- an important tool for shopping the show around-- which you can obtain a copy of as a perk (see below).


What are our potential funding sources? You're looking at it! Our fundraising efforts are focused entirely on this on-line campaign.  We don't have a sponsor (although there's a perk for that, too; see below).  So if we don't raise the money we need now, we will have to somehow make up the difference out of pocket.  Please give what you can, and know that by doing so you are helping birth a fantastic new work of musical theater.


We are offering some great incentives as perks, so along with the knowledge you are helping us create great art, you could also get CD's of some of the artists' work, dinner with the creators, or even a song written specifically for you or a loved one!


NOTE: Your donation will be processed through Fractured Atlas, via our producing partner Motherlodge (www.motherlodge.com).


Please spread the word

If you caught Canary in one of its earlier incarnations and liked it, here is your chance to spread the word about it.  Share the info with your friends on facebook, twitter, and all those other social media thingies.  Email folks. Pick up the phone.  Come to the presentation!

story:
We are the Bearded Men

We've spent the past six years doing what we love. One big thing we've realized is that sometimes doing what you love does not always make you the money you need to support that passion.

That's where you come in. 

We are asking that you donate any amount that is right for you to support our past, present and especially our future projects. 

What's this all going to?

Let us break it down for you:

2011 Festivals (Gas, Lodging, Workshops)

  • Spontaeneous Compbustion Atlanta, Chicago Improv Festival, Twin Cities Improv Festival, Spontaneous Combustion Motor City, Kansas City Improv Festival, Toronto Improv Festival

2012 Festivals (Gas, Lodging, Workshops)

  • Spontaneous Combustion Atlanta, Twin Cities Improv Festival, and more that we've submitted to but can't reveal their names just yet. :)

Advertising

  • Print
  • Online and Video Production

Costumes (Some of our themed shows need a bit more flair)

  • Clothing from thrift stores is cheap, but can add up.
  • Make-up for our Grannies set... those old ladies are particular. ;)
Upcoming Projects
  • "Beards on the High Seas: A Pirates Life"
  • Re-Launch of our currently popular, "D&D: The Improvised Campaign"
  • Re-Launch of the popular "Bearded Men: Post-Apocalyptic"
  • "Bearded Holiday Spectacular 2012"

The Impact

Your donation means more than we can even tell you. It will keep us ahead of the game instead of behind.

In particular, festivals have been one of the most exciting things for us because of the exposure, recognition and workshops we've been able to be a part of, but many times they are the most expensive thing we do. They have also introduced us to many of the people that have shaped who we are as a group today. As well as spreading the wonderfulness of the Minneapolis improv scene to the rest of the nation.

The more shows, no matter where, we are able to do, the more likely we are to be seen by someone who might actually want to pay us for this stuff.

You are funding the rocket ship, Bearded; and we're ready to blast off to the planet, MakeMoneyDoingWhatWeLove. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not all of you can donate, so here are some other ways you can help:

  • Help make some noise about our fundraiser on Facebook, Twitter, etc.
  • Come to our shows regularly
  • Encourage other people to come to our shows regularly
  • Tell people about us regularly
  • Write Bearded Men Improv on napkins or newspapers and leave them around town regularly
  • Scream, "I LOVE BEARDED MEN IMPROV" in a public space... regularly

 

Finally, and we can't say it enough,

THANK YOU FROM THE BOTTOM OF OUR BEARDED HEARTS
story_txt:
We are the Bearded Men
We've spent the past six years doing what we love. One big thing we've realized is that sometimes doing what you love does not always make you the money you need to support that passion.
That's where you come in. 
We are asking that you donate any amount that is right for you to support our past, present and especially our future projects. 
What's this all going to?


Let us break it down for you:
2011 Festivals (Gas, Lodging, Workshops)

Spontaeneous Compbustion Atlanta, Chicago Improv Festival, Twin Cities Improv Festival, Spontaneous Combustion Motor City, Kansas City Improv Festival, Toronto Improv Festival

2012 Festivals (Gas, Lodging, Workshops)

Spontaneous Combustion Atlanta, Twin Cities Improv Festival, and more that we've submitted to but can't reveal their names just yet. :)



Advertising

Online and Video Production

story:
What is TheaterFest?

Each year, for one weekend only, UCLA's School of Theater, Film, and Television opens their doors to a series of performances created entirely by the undergraduate theater students. 

These projects are the undergraduate opportunity to bring to life the work we have been dreaming about for the last year or maybe even four. 

At its core, TheaterFest is a love letter to the UCLA TFT community— it is a response to all the things our teachers, parents and classmates have taught us.

What We Need

Money is one of the biggest obstacles for our TheaterFest directors. Often the director (and their parents) end up paying for their production entirely out of pocket. Between rights and other production values, this can cost upwards of $500.

The ‘money factor’ limits which students can afford to participate in TheaterFest and we want to change that!

This year we want to raise $2000 for the festival. This money will be divided equally between each show to pay for:  

              1)    The rights

              2)    The production elements (lights, costumes, set, etc.)

AND financing productions next year!

What You Get

$10: THEATER IS YOUR PARTY. You’re a theater person through and through! Two reserved seats for any show of your choice.

$25: THE DRAMATIC TENSION CLUB. You have given us the glue of every scene—the dramatic tension! Two reserved seats for every production.

$50: THE POETS SOCIETY. You are the original thespians, the first storytellers! Special thanks in the program and on our website. All previous prizes also included.

$100: MUSES CIRCLE. You are the reason for every actor’s best performances! A producer credit in the program and on our website. A signed program from the creative teams and casts of TF. All previous prizes also included.

$250: DIONYSUS AND COMPANY. You are a god of the theater! A video from the creative teams and casts of TF to thank you for your help. All previous prizes also included.

$500: YOU ARE ASTONISHING. You have received the highest praise of TFT: you have astonished us! Theaters will be built in your name, legends will be formed about your work! You will receive a book of original rehearsal plans and notes, costume/set/ lighting sketches, notes from production and artistic meetings AND TheaterFest’s five-year plan.

The Impact

By contributing to this campaign, you are making theater happen and that matters. Please show your support and tell everyone that this is an art form that is alive and well in Los Angeles (despite what Vanity Fair seems to think). This is work is for you and all the inspiration that you (our teachers, parents, friends, fellow Angelinos and citizens of the planet) bring us.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  •     Share this campaign with your community and encourage them to support our mission!
  •     Come and see TheaterFest AND bring you friends with you!
  •     Post about us on your Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Snapchat etc. with the hastags #theaterfest2014 #astonishme

story:
Synopsis:

Michael Lear, a Wall Street mogul, is dying in his opulent Upper East Side penthouse. In their lavish apartments on the floor below, Meryl and Rae, two of his daughters, and Alan and Cody, their hotshot beaus, are vying for the lion’s share of the inheritance. The daughters are married (or, at least, miserably affianced) to their father’s senior executives. As they count down the hours 

until the ensuing free-for-all, we are exposed to a world of post-coital strategizing, pill popping, and backroom dealing. Someone’s going to get burned, but who? A contemporary spin on King Lear, brimming with deceit, savagery, and foie gras. 


The Creative Team:

Director/Producer: Marc Eardley has been a freelance producer and director for over a decade. He got his start doing a fair amount of AEA Stage Managing. Selected NYC directing credits: Death Party, the first metro area revival of Hedwig and the Angry Inch, The Affair in 22B Off-Broadway, Get GOT, Standby at Fringe and Fringe Encores, Really Bad Things  at NYMF and Women and Guns which won best new play at the Midtown Festival. Upcoming: Sex, Lies and Earl Grey at Fringe, Roman Fever at the West Village Musical Theater Festival. Regionally he has directed All Shook Up, Nine, South Pacific, Neil Simon's Fools and Harvey. Marc created and is producing the concert Epic Fail: Where the Future of Broadway meets Broadway's Future Flops. A night of songs from movies that should never become musicals! As a Stage Manager he's proud to have worked at The New Group, The Public Theater, Off-Broadway for From My Hometown and The God Committee and more and most recently PSM for Thankskilling: The Musical. He has several directing projects currently in various stages of development: The Son of Captain Blood, an epic musical based on the extraordinary life of Errol Flynn's son Sean; Fat Kid Rules the World: A New Musical based on the book by K.L. Going and movie by Matthew Lillard with music/lyrics by Rob Rokicki; Terms of Dismemberment by Dorothy Marcic and more.www.marceardley.com

Playwright: James Presson writing credits include LITTLE MAC, LITTLE MAC, YOU'RE THE VERY MAN (co-written with Sean Patrick Monahan), WORDS, RAZORS, AND THE WOUNDED HEART (Less Than Rent/Horse Trade), MONEY$HOT(premiering at Orlando Rep in May), LITTLE TOWN BLUES (The Wild Project), VOICES IN CONFLICT (Vineyard Theatre, collaboration with Bonnie Dickinson), and FRIENDS DON’T LET FRIENDS (Walkerspace). In 2010, he was awarded the FringeNYC Outstanding Director award for his musical adaptation of Richard III at the age of 19. He is the recipient of the 2013/14 Dramatists Guild Fellowship (with partner Alexander Sage Oyen) for Musical Theatre writing for their musical OUTLAWS, which will continue its development at the 2014 ASCAP workshop. James is the founder and co-artistic director of Less Than Rent Theatre.

Set Designer: Daniel Geggatt is a New York based scenic designer working primarily in theatre and event design. He is a graduate of Fordham University where he studied theatrical design and production with a concentration in scenic design. He has also studied at the Moscow Art Theatre School (MXAT). He is grateful to be a part of this exciting new work, and thrilled that we have the chance to share it with an audience. Some of Daniel’s previous designs include: 23 Year Old Myth (Theatre For The New City), Beckett In Benghazi (Under St. Mark’s), Horse Girls (Ars Nova), Antigone (Fordham), Reckless (Fordham). Daniel is also an active company member of Less Than Rent Theatre. Many of his previous designs can be viewed online at danielgeggatt.foliohd.com.

General Manager: Evan Bernardin has spent the last four years working as a producer and general manager while pursuing a theatre arts degree from Marymount Manhattan College. Upon graduation, Evan was offered a position working as an Assistant General Manager with Leonard Soloway Productions where he aids in the development of projects headed both on and off Broadway. Evan has produced for The Workshop Theatre Company, The Broadway Youth Ensemble, Born for Broadway, and his independent company, JEM Theatricals. Additionally, Evan has collaborated on projects including performances at Lincoln Center, The United Nations, The Harvard Club, Georgetown's Gaston Hall, The Culture Project, The Ohio Theatre, and The Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Stage Manager: Hannah Brooks is currently enrolled at Fordham University pursuing Stage Management. Professional Credits: Our Town (Green-Wood, Assistant Stage Manager), Twelfth Night, Salamanticus (Ziggurat Theatre Ensemble, Production Stage Manager). Fordham Credits: God’s Ear (Assistant Stage Manager), Crossing Vines and Everything Else Under the Stars and Over the Moon (Assistant Stage Manager). 

Assistant Director/Producer: Richard Grasso is a 2012 graduate of the University of Michigan where he received a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree in Theatre Directing. He was the Assistant Director for the 2012 Pittsburgh CLO summer stock season which included A Chorus Line (Director Baayork Lee), Annie (Director Charles Repole and starring Sally Struthers), Fiddler on the Roof (Director Jack Allison) and Sunset Boulevard (Director Barry Ivan and starring Liz Callaway). Richard is actively pursuing a directing career in the New York City area where he recently asst. directed the Transport Group's latest off-broadway musical The Memory Show starring Leslie Kritzer and Catherine Cox under the direction of Joe Calarco.  For more information, please visit www.richardfgrasso.com

Producer: Anne Ciarlone is a recent graduate of Marymount Manhattan College where she received her BA in Theatre Arts. Her recent directing credits include Woyzeck and David Ives' Long Ago and Far Away. In addition to directing, Anne is passionate about arts administration, having completed internships with Signature Theatre and Primary Stages. anneciarlone.com

The Cast:

Zak Risinger has done a lot plays all across this great land of ours.  He's played Pirates, Paupers, Parrots, Bikers, Punk Rockers, Poets, Foreigners, Stoners, Presidents,  and everything in between. He has appeared coast to coast in over a dozen states and loved working on Reefer Madness, Fiddler on the Roof, Little Shop of Horrors, Julius Caesar, HONK!, Man of La Mancha, Metamorphoses, The Tempest and the world premiere of Drive-In America at The Kennedy Center.  BFA University of Oklahoma.  

Emily Tarpay is thrilled to help create the role of Corie in this amazing new play! NY/Regional credits include:Awesome 80’s Prom (Webster Hall), Yeast Nation (La Mama), Kerrigan & Lowdermilk’s Party Worth Crashing (WPPAC),Much Ado About Nothing (Player’s Theater), Silence (Theater for the New City), Edges (WPPAC), Fiddler on the Roof(Yorktown Stage), Into the Woods (Yorktown Stage). TV/Film: The Funtastix!, Siskeletta & Ebertetta, Shadows of Life(Face to Face Films), I’m Drowning, Inner Circle, and the new pilot, 86 My Life. Emily is a Fordham University alum, a graduate of the Michael Howard Studios Conservatory, and co-founder of Ooooh Yeah Productions, the team behind Gentrified.

Rachel B. Joyce New York Theatre: Our Town (Green-Wood Cemetery), Turn of the Screw (Lincoln Center Rubenstein Atrium, wksp); Anthropology of a Book Club (New Georges, wksp); Desire! A Varsouviana (Under St. Marks/Less Than Rent); Little Town Blues (Wild Project/Less Than Rent); Richard 3 (FringeNYC/Less Than Rent); Ravishing Carlos/Ravishing Christina (Hot! Festival); Miss Hope’s (Nylon Fusion Collective). She has performed regionally at the Williamstown Theatre Festival. She can also be seen in many short films and web series produced by College Humor, Dark Knites Entertainment, and more. She is the co-artistic director of Less Than Rent Theatre and a graduate of Fordham College at Lincoln Center. rachelbjoyce.com

Ben Diserens is an actor and playwright based in New York City. Ben is originally from San Francisco, but has lived in Australia, taught at the Australian Theatre for Young People and studied at the Moscow Art Theatre in Russia. Acting credits include Our Town (dir. James Presson),The Crucible, Mrs. Packard (dir. May Adrales), The Marriage of Figaro (dir. Matthew Maguire), The Good Person of Szechwan & Sticks and Bones. Ben is a company member of Less Than Rent. www.bendiserens.com


What We Need

Producing a fantastic show like this only comes with help from kind people like all of you! 

We are attempting to raise $6,000 for this festival production and at least half (or more..??) through Indiegogo.

Please consider making a donation and help us produce this piece of theatre for our NYC audiences. 

No donation is too small! Getting a great team like this together, along with costumes, props, scenery, rehearsal space fee’s, etc. all adds up and we need as much support as we can. 

The Impact

Your assistance will take us far:

  • We'll be able to market the show better!
  • Every show Marc has put into this festival has won best play, hopefully the track record continues and you'll have helped get us there.
  • We'll be able to pay the actors and designers a better, well deserved stipend.
  • We'll be able to design better costumes. An important piece of the puzzle for a play about 5 wealthy youths.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you just can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Spread the word! Use social media platforms like Facebook, twitter, and of course, word of mouth to help let everyone know to come and see this groundbreaking new work! Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

Thanks so much!

story:
Our Story

Help our merry band of actors and creative team bring our one-act comedy Petra to the stage, as we go pen-to-pen and word-to-word with 30 other plays in the Manhattan Repertory Theatre's One-Act Play Competition.

What happens when a couple can't agree on whether they once went to Petra? That's the question our dark comedy tries to answer.

How Your Support Will Help

Your generous donation will go directly toward paying for audition and rehearsal space, costumes and props, marketing and promotion, program bills, office supplies, competition fees, and more. Any amount will be greatly appreciated!


Our Cast

LARRY GUTMAN as Conrad. Larry is excited to be back at the Manhattan Repertory Theatre, playing one of the leads in Petra. Trained at HB Studio, some of his favorite roles include Elwood P. Dowd in Harvey, Robert in Proof, Firs in The Cherry Orchard, Otto Frank in The Diary of Anne Frank, George Tesman in Hedda Gabler, the Old Man in Fool For Love, Oscar Wolfe in The Royal Family, Moe Axelrod in Awake and Sing!, Captain Taylor in A Soldier's Play, and Dr. Einstein in Arsenic and Old Lace.


YVONNE "BONNIE" COLE as Janice. An actor and director, her favorite productions include Love's Labour's Lost and The Beaux' Stratagem (Kings County Shakespeare), Mornings at Seven (San Miguel Repertory) and The 4th Zoa (Charles Scott Jones). Favorite roles include The Diary of Anne Frank (Mrs. Van Daan), The Foreigner (Catherine), Small Craft Warnings (Leona Dawson), and  several nefarious characters on Investigation Discovery and A&E TV. It 's a great pleasure for her to be cast in Petra at the Manhattan Repertory Theatre.


OLIVIA MELL as Avery.  Olivia is thrilled to be a part of Petra and to be working in association with Manhattan Repertory Theatre.  Born in New York City and raised in Los Angeles by two marvelous actor parents, her NYC theater credits include Love's Labour's Lost and No Reservations at the Michael Chekhov Theatre Co., and two runs of her original cabaret Perfectly Complicated at both the Laurie Beechman Theatre and Stage 72, which she co-created and produced. Most recently she  starred in the MITF runaway hit Cover at the Abingdon Theatre.  


MICHAEL GIBSON as David. Michael is delighted to be a part of Petra and return to the Manhattan Repertory Theatre, where he recently performed in Disconnected at  Summerfest. He played the role of Flemming in Line at the 13th Street Repertory Theater, and has studied at Second City in Chicago, Upright Citizens Brigade, and The Peoples Improv in NYC. He has appeared on Saturday Night Live, Blue Bloods, and The Knick, as well as in The Secret Life of Walter Mitty and A Beautiful Mind. He is a graduate of the Michael Howard Conservatory.

 

Our Creative Team

JESSE MICHAEL MOTHERSHED (Director) is excited to be working with John Yarbrough again after a successful collaboration on John’s delightful screenplay, Not My Beautiful Wife, for the SAG Foundation as part of their inaugural staged reading series. Other directing credits include: Cosi, the inaugural production of Australian Made Entertainment and Lost Wisdom with the Short Play Lab (NY); as well as Safe Sex, with the University of Arizona's One-Act Play Festival, for which he won the prestigious “Alphie” award for Best Director, as well as Best Overall Production. He is an Artistic Associate with the acclaimed Titan Theatre Company and serves as their resident text coach, having coached Romeo & Juliet, A Midsummer Night’s Dream and King Lear. To those who can make it to a performance, he says: "Enjoy the show!"

JOHN YARBROUGH (Playwright) is thrilled to be working with an amazing cast in the debut of Petra.  His screenplay, Not My Beautiful Wife, was chosen for the Screen Actors Guild Foundation as part of their inaugural staged reading series, as well as for the Writers Guild of America East's staged screenwriting series. A former Artist-in-Residence with the Hudson Warehouse Theatre Company, in his previous work as a journalist he was a writer and producer at ABC News World News Tonight and CNN, and has written for the New York Times, Washington Post and elsewhere.


    A Sneak Peek at the Script

    Here's a glimpse at a page from Petra:


      Other Ways You Can Help Promote PETRA

      Help us get the word out -- post and send this campaign page to your friends and colleagues, friend us on Facebook, tweet and blog about the show, and spread the word. And if you're in the NYC area, come see the show and VOTE FOR PETRA!


      Dedication

      Petra is dedicated to Fletcher and Suzy Yarbrough ... who once went to Petra?
story_txt:
Our Story
Help our merry band of actors and creative team bring our one-act comedy Petra to the stage, as we go pen-to-pen and word-to-word with 30 other plays in the Manhattan Repertory Theatre's One-Act Play Competition.
What happens when a couple can't agree on whether they once went to Petra? That's the question our dark comedy tries to answer.
How Your Support Will Help
Your generous donation will go directly toward paying for audition and rehearsal space, costumes and props, marketing and promotion, program bills, office supplies, competition fees, and more. Any amount will be greatly appreciated!




Our Cast

LARRY GUTMAN as Conrad. Larry is excited to be back at the Manhattan Repertory Theatre, playing one of the leads in Petra. Trained at HB Studio, some of his favorite roles include Elwood P. Dowd in
Harvey, Robert in Proof, Firs in The Cherry Orchard, Otto Frank in The Diary of Anne Frank, George Tesman
in Hedda Gabler, the Old Man in Fool For Love, Oscar Wolfe in The Royal Family, Moe Axelrod in Awake and Sing!, Captain Taylor in A Soldier's Play, and Dr. Einstein in Arsenic and Old Lace.



YVONNE "BONNIE" COLE as Janice. An actor and director, her favorite productions include Love's Labour's Lost and The Beaux' Stratagem (Kings County Shakespeare), Mornings at Seven (San Miguel Repertory) and The 4th Zoa (Charles Scott Jones). story:
OUR MISSION STATEMENT

Fantastic.Z Theatre Company is an artist run, LGBTQ, nonprofit theater company focusing on new and under produced works.

MORE ABOUT FANTASTIC.Z

Fantastic.Z Theatre Company was founded by a few of Seattle’s LGBTQ artists who strived to bring queer arts and artists to the foreground.  They started out ensembly generating one production per year taking source material and focusing it through their queer lens. 
During the four years of this process their ensemble’s vision grew, leading them away from only generating their own new work and toward producing full seasons focused on both new and under produced works and reaching out to their LGBTQ and theatre community alike.
Fantastic.Z Theatre Company continually strives to amuse, amaze, entertain and inspire their community.  
    

What We Need 

Theater is Expensive!

  • One of our biggest needs are funds for rehearsal/performance space.  If you live in Seattle, you know how much it costs to keep your place.  An average production's rehearsal and performance rental can cost up to three times your monthly rent! Not to mention buying props, costumes, and sets etc.
  • Our actors, designers, and crew work hard to bring you the theatrical cocktails you've come to savor and enjoy. Your donation will help us validate their efforts.
  • All funds raised go to Fantastic Z's 2014/2015 season see detailed season info below.

What You Get

We have great perks at varied donation levels that bring you closer to Fantastic.Z Theatre Company and our art.  You also get the joy of supporting the theatre arts and joining the elite group of our contributors!

The Impact

Because of you...

  • Members of the LGBTQ and Greater Seattle Community alike will learn and grow in a venue of mutual respect and interest.
  • We will deliver another year of engaging theater, education, and enrichment focused through our queer lens.
  • Your generous donation supports the growth of Fantastic Z Theatre Company and queer arts in the city of Seattle.

Today, theater cannot survive without the reinforcement of its champions - benevolent people like you!  It takes a predetermined enterprise of many individuals to make a season happen.

  • Every year Fantastic Z develops its resources, this is your opportunity to add to the value of Seattle's Premier LGBTQ Theatre Company. 

Here is what's in store for our 2nd season!


First Main-Stage Show


In December, we present Reckless by Craig Lucas at The Annex Theater.

Performance dates are Thursday - Saturday December 4th - December 20th 2014.


THE STORY: At home on Christmas Eve, Rachel is informed by her guilty husband that he has hired a hit man to kill her, and she must flee for her life—which she does by scrambling out the kitchen window and into the snowy night. She meets and joins up with Lloyd Bophtelophti, a true "original" who has changed his name to avoid alimony payments and who now lives with a paraplegic named Pootie (who also pretends to be deaf in order to get double disability). Rachel then wins $100,000 on a TV game show and begins a series of picaresque escapades involving numerous psychiatrists and, eventually, an ill-fated reunion with her husband. In the end, Rachel becomes a therapist herself, treating her own child (who fails to recognize her) and is led more and more to ponder whether the modern world might not be a vast conspiracy designed to systematically undermine her own increasingly shaky sanity.




3rd Annual New Works Festival


This year's title is Truth & Consequences and will be performed at Rendezvous' JewelBox Theater February 24th - 28th 2015.


THE STORY:  Each year Z reaches out to local, young, up and coming playwrights and curates a show from these submissions that speaks to the overall theme of our season.  This process takes several directors working on a few short pieces pulling from a larger ensemble of actors playing multiple roles to bring these new works to life.  



Second Main-Stage Show


Our spring show in May of 2015 is Sidewinders by Basil Kreimendahl. 

Location:TBD


THE STORY:  The winner of the 2013 Rella Lossy Award for Playwrighting, this quick and witty new work is a transgender western in the style of "Waiting for Godot".  Z loves it.  And you will too!


Sidewinders received its world premiere at The Cutting Ball Theater, Rob Melrose, Artistic Director.


“The world premiere of Sidewinders owes as much to Samuel Beckett’s Waiting for Godot as it does to SF Pride. In this absurdist-Western romp through gender queerness, Dakota and Bailey are new friends who find themselves lost, possibly upside down, on a vast frontier. Their journey to getting right side up provokes questions of sex anatomy, transgenderism, and who we really are from the inside out.”


Other Ways You Can Help!

We rely on not only your interest and help but that of your friends, family, neighbors, and co-workers. Please share in our quest by bringing your loved ones closer to our campaign!

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign! You can use the Indiegogo share tools!
