story:
LCTC Summary

Left Coast Theatre Co. is San Francisco's home for ORIGINAL LGBT theatre. 

It was formed in the Spring of 2012 by a group of gay writers with a dream and a flair for comedy.  We couldn't have imagined that only 2 years later we would be nominated for our first TBA Award!  We are a San Francisco-based theater company that focuses on producing queer-themed plays written by local and national playwrights. Each year, we develop two original shows that promote diversity and encourage community involvement.

Our newest show is "Shock & Awww", an evening of short comedic plays on love, dating & other hazards. It explores the trials, tribulations and occasional land mines of relationships and dating. This project is so important because it shows the lives of LGBT people in ways that you haven't seen before. 

Without you, we wouldn't be able to get this show on its feet. Without you, we wouldn't be able to start the dialog needed to tackle the issues that gay people are still facing today. Without you, there would be a little less laughter in the world.  

By giving from your heart, you are giving gay artists across the nation a voice.

SHOCK & AWWW Summary

"SNIP"

Ben, a middle-age man who has sworn off drunken hook-ups with young hotties wakes up to find he has done it again. The afterglow of lovemaking is soon eclipsed by the arrival of the fabulously frightening hulk in heels Ben hired to deal out serious consequences should he break his pledge.

"ROMEO & JULES"

Romeo (yes, that Romeo) makes a wrong turn on his way to woo Juliet and instead ends up having a less-than-poetic encounter with her neighbor Jules.

"MANGINA"

After months of prodding by best friend Oscar, Benji finally musters the nerve to ask out rugby teammate, Jackson. Only a crucial detail is revealed and Benji is left to ponder the complicated landmines of attraction and what does/doesn’t matter in a relationship. 

"FLOODING"

Two women try to come to grips with their various phobias while trying to go for a cup of coffee. Now if only they can only face their fears and actually start the car...

"JIM AT MY DOOR"

What do you do when you’re locked out of a stranger’s apartment…middle of the night…naked? A good Samaritan neighbor and a denuded rubber tree plant help Jim recover his clothes, as well as his sense of adventure.

"FANNY PACKS & HANKY CODES"

Through flashbacks, interludes and a run-in with an eccentric old party monster, we learn the relationship histories/challenges of a 20-something gay man and his straight best friend.

Show opens Friday, October 31st and runs through Saturday, November 22nd.

Thursday-Saturday nights at 8pm at the Shelton Theater (533 Sutter, SF)

MATURE AUDIENCES ONLY

HOW YOU CAN HELP

Have you ever thought of trying your hand as a Producer? Well, if you make a donation of at least $50, that's how you will be listed in our playbill!  

In the Bay Area and looking for a great evening out? We have several tiers of ticket options available.

Out of town but still looking to make a donation? Don't worry. We even have several options that include a DVD copy of the show! 

Our goal is $2,500 to pay for the theatre rental, sets, props, costumes, and talent. If you have ever tried to put up a play, you know how expensive it can be. Now imagine trying to put up 6 short plays in one night! And while $2,500 is only a small chunk of what is needed, it is certainly a great start.

    THE IMPACT

    Left Coast Theatre Co. isn't afraid to push the envelope, to hold a mirror up to society and reflect the world as it truly is. While we do it in a comedic way, the issues remain very real. Our successful shows have garnered tremendous positive feedback and have attracted audiences from across the globe.

    Your support means we can continue to entertain, enlighten and educate audiences...but on a grander scale. The more minds we challenge, the more hearts we touch, the more change we see.

      ONE LAST THING...

      Small theatre companies like ours thrive on word of mouth. If you like what Left Coast Theatre Co. has to offer, please share this information with your family and friends.  If you don't, share it with your enemies.  :)

      Left Coast Theatre Co. is sponsored by a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization which means that your contributions are tax-deductible!

        And don't forget to use the IndieGoGo share tools!

        From the bottom of our hearts, thank you in advance from the entire LCTC family.

        Laugh on!

        We are a Member of the Intersection Incubator, a program of Intersection for the Arts, a non-profit organization providing fiscal sponsorship, incubation and consulting services to artists.

story:
The Who, What, and Why

We're the Old Mill High School Drama Patrons, supporting the Patriot Player Theater Company (PPTC), the student drama troupe at OMHS. PPTC has a 40-year history of terrific musicals, and we need your assistance to help make their spring musical, "Once Upon A Mattress", the best show it can be. 

How Your Contribution Helps

We're supporting an incredibly talented group of young people who deliver amazing performances on a shoestring budget. Our goal is to raise $2000 to cover some of the up-front expenses such as script fees, set construction materials, costumes, and the other necessities of putting on a high-quality theatrical production. 

Every dollar we raise will go towards the production or to fulfilling the contributor perks - which we've deliberately kept inexpensive to maximize the dollars that will go to support the kids.

Even if we don't reach our goal, every dollar we raise will help us better support this wonderful cast and crew.

What do I get if I contribute?

While the goal is to maximize the funding for the show, we do want to recognize and thank our contributors. Contributor "perks" range from a ticket to the performance of your choice at $25 to your name hidden on the set as an "Easter Egg" to limited-run backer T-shirts. See the perk levels for more details.

When is all this happening?

The crowdfunding campaign here on Indiegogo will run from January 28th through February 27th, and the money will be put to work right away. There will be six performances over two weekends:
  • Friday, April 10th, 7 PM
  • Saturday, April 11th, 7 PM
  • Sunday, April 12th, 2 PM
  • Friday, April 17th, 7 PM
  • Saturday, April 18th, 2 PM and 7 PM

What happens if we raise more than $2000?

We don't have any specific "stretch goals" for this campaign, but every dollar raised will go directly to making the show even better - like renting additional lighting, or to create special effects.

How can I pay?

Through the Indiegogo campaign, you can contribute either by credit/debit card, or via PayPal. To contribute directly, please contact us through the site and we will direct you appropriately.

But what if I can't contribute money?

There's still ways you can help! Spread the word by sharing our campaign in Facebook or other social media, or e-mail, or whatever way you can! 

I'd like to help, but would rather contribute directly and not through Indiegogo.

Thank you! If you'd like to make a direct contribution, please contact us through the site and we'll direct you appropriately.

Risks & Challenges

The show is already cast and the rights secured. The Patriot Players have a 40-year history of putting on their productions despite a variety of setbacks, and they truly exemplify the old saying, "The show must go on." Barring something truly disastrous or bizarre, the production will go forward!

story:
Project Summary

Body & Soul Dance Theatre is the longest running modern dance company in Broward County.  We have a history of innovative choreography and community outreach with emphasis on educating “the community through the art of theatre and dance”.  Originally a for-profit entity, Body & Soul went on a brief hiatus and re-emerged as a non-profit that reaffirmed its commitment to the community.

Each season, the company offers classes in the community, gives pop up performances all over the county and hires local dancers to participate in our annual production.  The annual production is a collaborative affair that continually pushes choreographers and dancers to explore different aspects of dance through storytelling and the use of different genres.

In our production of Dance through the Ages, Body & Soul will explore the evolution of dance from the birth of ballet in 1489 to what we imagine dance will look like in the future.  Along the way, we will use different dance milestones to anchor the performance in time: the Victorian court dances, the introduction of square dancing and salsa in the 1700s, the first musicals featuring dance in the late 1800s, and the modern versions of ballet and its offshoots (i.e. modern, lyrical, contemporary and jazz) as they appeared in the 1900s and the 2000s.  These pieces will be structured and staged using written accounts of the styles from archives as well as featuring original choreography.  The music will be researched to depict the era that is being featured.  The intent is to take audience members on a journey through time that sparks an awareness of dance and its evolution as a reflection of the cultures and history that developed it.

Since this production covers the better part of a millennium’s worth of dance, the only way to accomplish that feat with the appropriate level of consideration and finesse is to enlist help.  Our help comes in the form of a number of partnerships with some dynamic visual artists: Nicole Kent of Nicole Kent, Inc (photography/videography), Donna Haynes (original costume design), Beth K Amato (digital animation) and Renan Machado (graphic design).  With their assistance, we will span decades and at times, centuries, through the use of photography, animation and film.  Dancers will jump off the screen, transported from one time period to another as the world is torn apart and reassembled with words, sounds, gestures and interactions shared between dancers, audience members and visual artists.

The visual art component is a vital part of this experience.  They will bring the palatial majesty of the Victorian court and the steamy intimacy of a Latin nightclub, the lights and sounds of Broadway and the raw silence of a black box theater during performance art.  Body and Soul will provide dancers with the appropriate background and training to people the worlds created by these artists. 

It is not simply the removal of the boundaries often erected between visual and performance art that we seek to explore, but also the idea that in looking at the history of dance, we are looking at the history of self-expression. Victorian court dances established a common ground where courtiers of both sexes could show off their skill in a time where men and women were chaperoned and kept apart, less their carnal desires overcome them.  Burlesque was a provocative attempt to re-establish a sense of self and the joys of carnal knowledge to a society awakening from a decade of censorship and social standards that restricted self-expression.  Modern dance grew directly out of a need to break with the rigidity of balletic technique.  Jazz expressed the pain and excitement of a people finding their voice. 

Dance through the Ages will give a variety of genres a historical context.  This context will be created by using movement that is true to the time period being depicted since the movement and style of a technique are a direct reflection of the contexts that created them.  The authenticity of the dance will be further enhanced by original costume designs.  Animation, film and photography will also be used to create a clear sense of place and time for each piece.

What We Need & What You Get

Dance Through The Ages

For each donation we receive toward this project you can receive a benefit.

Diamond :priority seating at event, admittance to private cast party, donor recognition in program, T-shirt, and photo, and DVD copy of DTTA

$201 -more

Platinum : admittance to private cast party, donor recognition in program, free Body & Soul T-shirt, and 8x10 photo

$151 - 200

Gold : admittance to private cast party, donor recognition in program, free Body & Soul T-Shirt, and 5x7 photo 

$101 - 150

Silver : donor recognition in program, free Body & Soul T-Shirt, and 4x6 photo

$51-100

Friend : donor recognition in program, free Body & Soul T-Shirt

$26- 50

Supporter :donor recognition in program and free Body & Soul Dance Theatre Vinyl Sticker

$0 - 25

The Impact

Body & Soul Dance Theatre has been creating projects for the community since 1982. As we embark on our 33rd season we continue to need the support of our donors. 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge we face is not meeting full funding. If we are unable to meet full funding we will look at what aspects can be changed and modified to not limit the quality of the production. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Want to be a part of the action? We are always looking for motivated individuals to assist us in the theater as ushers, back stage assistants, social media guru's, and bloggers. Pass along this opportunity to your friends and neighbors by sharing this project. Our deepest thanks!

story:
Bref résumé

Ça t'enrage de voir des décorations de Noël dans les vitrines, dès le lendemain de l'Halloween?
Ça te donne des envies sadiques?
Tu sens que tu vas en avoir pour un mois et demie à vouloir tuer quiconque chantonnera "Vive le vent" avant le 24 décembre?

Nous aussi!!

Alors, viens satisfaire ton besoin de défoulement dans la comédie satirique du temps des Fêtes par excellence!

Le Père Noël est une ordure, présenté dans la salle le Ring, du Théâtre aux Écuries, le 11, 12, 13 décembre 2014 à 19h30.

Dans une mise en scène de Philippe Boutin                                                                   Direction de production: Christine Filteau

Avec : Marilyn Bastien, Stanley Hilaire, Frédéric Khawam, Catherine Rochefort, Rémy Savard, Carl Veilleux

Votre contribution

Nous tentons présentement de récolter une somme de 1000$ pour payer la conception des décors et costumes ainsi que la main d’œuvre technique.

L'impact

En aidant Acte 1 productions à réaliser ce spectacle, ce sont des artistes de la relève théâtrale Montréalaise que vous encouragez. En effet, depuis sa fondation, Acte 1 productions a la mission de promouvoir le talent des jeunes créateurs en offrant, en plus de spectacles professionnels de qualité, des formations professionnelles, tant pour le théâtre que la caméra. 

D'autres façons d'aider

Venez voir notre spectacle au Théâtre aux Écuries du 11 au 13 décembre 2014 et venez aimer la page Facebook d'Acte 1 productions à l’adresse suivante: 

www.facebook.com/acte1productions?fref=ts

Vous pouvez également nous suivre et acheter vos billets via notre page web à l'adresse suivante:
productions.acte1.ca/billeterie

story:
Leslie Parker Dance Projects is collaborating with organizations based in Brooklyn and New Jersey that empower women and their families. Moving Dialogue for Non-Violence provides for a period an experience for women survivors of domestic violence to act as artists by participating in workshops tailored for non-dancers that cultivate interdependence, creative experimentation, and freedom of self-expression. Acting for a period as artists is a means to further awareness and challenge the boundaries that may exist between audience and artist as well as individual and community.  This project is the first of its kind to engage these communities as creators and makers of dance culminating into a final public performance that we will co-create. The moving dialogue emphasizes a collective responsibility advocating for peace using dance art.

What We Need & What You Get

Your donation contributes to paying the deposit needed for securing the space that will host our residency to conduct workshops, education & training, and creative explorations as well as present our final culminating performance on the evening of May 2, 2015.

As a donor you will have an inside look  into Leslie Parker Dance Projects by receiving updates on how your funds are furthering the cause to use dance as a catalyst for social change. You will  receive invitations to participate in our moving dialogue as our vision continues to manifest and to unfold.

Moving Dialogue for Non-Violence relies on the support of individuals and community. Join us by making a donation and by moving this dialogue in solidarity.  

If you are unable to contribute funds at this time, please spread the word and share this campaign with your social networks.

Thank you for your support!

story:
The Loyalists

                                directed by Karen Knox and Jonathan Langley

Prepare yourself for an immersive and interactive experience unlike any other. This June, the Single Thread Theatre Company has constructed a little world for visitors to enter and explore. It is the world of York 1813. The Americans have occupied the town. The people of York must choose to remain loyal to Great Britain or embrace the American conqueror. 

Developed in residence at Canadian Stage for the Festival of Ideas and Creation, The Loyalists focuses on concepts of domesticity, loyalty and above all, the decision to remain a distinct people.

The town of York consists of fifteen wood-frame ‘stations’ designed by architect Jay Pooley. A cast of fifteen actors populate the town.  A team of fifteen artists, including composers, carpenters, weavers, props experts, and installation artists have collaborated to create the sound, feel and texture of the world.

The Loyalists will be produced in Victoria Memorial Square, Toronto, Ontario located near Fort York on the corner of Portland and Wellington. The Loyalists opens on June 7th, with shows at 7 & 9 pm daily Tuesday-Sunday and additional 5 pm matinee performances on Saturdays. Visitors will ‘check-in’ to a welcome station and are given a tag to mark their involvement in the show. Victoria Memorial Square will remain open to the public for the duration of the performance and casual observers are welcome.

Your fiscal support will allow us to make the town of The Loyalists larger, deeper and more interesting, as all donations will go directly to increasing the production values of the project.

The Single Thread Theatre Company is a collection of artists with a proven record of creating dynamic, site specific, theatrical installations. We are currently the resident company in Canadian Stage's GYM Program.

Please visit www.singlethread.ca for more details about the company, The Loyalists, and the participating artists. Information regarding rehearsals, rain plan and ticket information can be found on our Facebook page, as well as our twitter feed. Tickets for The Loyalists can be purchased from Eventbrite.

Thank you for visiting our Indiegogo page. We look forward to seeing you in June.

story:
Irina’s Name Day Party is an all-new adaptation of Anton Chekhov’s Three Sisters by Conni’s Avant Garde Restaurant.  With your help, it will be presented August 14-18 at the Clemente Soto Velez Cultural & Educational Center in lower Manhattan.

In the production, Miss Conni presents the female devotees of the company (namely Goodi, Muffin, and Sue) with a copy of Anton Chekhov’s Three Sisters and the directive to “find the play!”   The party in the opening scene comes to life as audience members become invited guests and are treated to a meal of borscht, beer, and birthday cake.  Meanwhile, Goodi, Muffin, and Sue grapple with Chekhov’s great female roles. With the soul-wrenching assistance of the Violent Femmes, Frank Sinatra, and Bonnie Tyler, among others, they explode the sibling-like entanglements of Miss Conni’s ensemble.

This new show was originally developed in five days at North American Cultural Laboratory’s retreat space in Highland Lake, NY.  It is currently undergoing a second phase of development as part of the Motherlodge festival in Louisville, KY.  With your support, we can bring the final production back to New York.

 

What will my donation support?

Artists fees

Food costs

Rehearsal & performance space

Design materials & transport

 

Why are you raising this much right now?

We need to put down a deposit on the space in April, and our indiegogo goal will ensure we can book it!  The costs of developing the production are five times this goal and are not covered by ticket sales.  Our hope is exceed!


Please help us spread the word-share on facebook and twitter!

story:
Our Official Trailer

Learn more about the characters here:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FrimdBsssG4

Summary & History of the Show

Mahmoud is an irreverent & hilarious one-woman show about an aging Iranian engineer-cum-taxi driver, a fabulously gay Spaniard, and a young Iranian-Canadian girl, all trying to get by the day-to-day grind in the city they call home: Toronto.

Their stories come together over the course of an hour, and through their connections with the audience, themselves and each other, they explore the themes of displacement, immigration, home, and culture.

Performed by Tara Grammy, Mahmoud is co-written by Grammy and director Tom Arthur Davis, who have been developing the project since 2009. It has seen developmental help from Chalmers Winner Leah Cherniak and Dora Winner Soheil Parsa, who acted as the consulting director for the March 2011 production.

For more on the project visit: www.mahmoudtaxi.com

Reviews

"Dazzlingly Good! A Tour-De-Force Performance!"
-Woody Harrelson
Oscar Nominated Actor

"Mahmoud is a refreshingly honest andpersonal take on how a young generation of Iranian-Canadians experience the uprising in our native homeland. This is life and politics as only a twenty year old can tell it, unabashed and irreverent, free of dogma and indoctrination."
- Sima Sahar Zerehi
Shahrvand, the largest Farsi newspaper in North America

Mahmoud is "a telling picture of immigrant experience. Tara Grammy deserves a nod for creating a piece of theatre that successfully leaps a few cultural hurdles.... Grammy has a definite facility with character roles."
- John Coulbourn
Toronto Sun

"Grammy has incredible talent and charisma as a performer."
-George Perry
Mooney On Theatre

How You Can Help

Mahmoud was recently accepted into the New York International Fringe Festival. 

Your contribution to our $6500 goal will help fund our expenses:

Visa Application Fee - $600.00
Festival Fee - $600.00
Adverstising (postcards) - $500.00
Accomodations in New York for a Month - $4,000.00
Travel Expenses (for 3 people - including Stage Manager Jenna) - $1,500.00

Total: $7,200.00
 

Now what can you get out of all of this? In addition to our undying gratitude, you can get signed merchandise, personalized videos from the characters, or even a credit as a part of our team.

The Impact of Mahmoud

This show comes at a very turbulent time in Iranian politics. We began Mahmoud, three years ago during the calm before the storm that turned out to be the 2009 presidential elections in Tara's home country of Iran. A lot has happened since then, and we all live under the shadow of a possible war. How Iranians are seen on a global scale is important at this time. Iranians worldwide have made a voice for themselves, particularly in the art world, and we hope to join them with this show. 

This show helps give a voice to highly educated immigrants (like Mahmoud) who find themselves at a disadvantage because of a flawed system. It addresses the oppression of the Iranian homosexual community, and the hardships of growing up as a first generation immigrant. We hope with this show, we can help break some of the stigmas floating around about Iranians and share with you a part of Iranian culture inside and outside of Iran. In the media, the only things people hear about Iranians have to do with either Ahmadinejad or the recent reality TV show, Shahs of Sunset. Fanatical Islam or Insane Materialism. There is far more to us than that. By helping Mahmoud make its international debut, you are helping us to show people some of our rich culture and history. You are showing them that there is more to our culture than Islam, that we do not all drive BMWs, and that although we are proud of our culture and history, we recognise our flaws, and our huge generation of young people aim to fix them. 

This show is not just for Iranians. It is for everyone who has ever faced racism and oppression, all immigrants and those who live alongside them. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share our campaign with fellow theaterlovers! We'd appreciate if you could post to your Facebook, Twitter, Google+, and/or e-mail our campaign to that rich Persian uncle of yours who can't wait to help some eager young artists.

The sharing tools just below our campaign video make speading the word easy! 


Thank you for helping us send our show to NYC!

Tara & Tom
story_txt:
Our Official Trailer
Learn more about the characters here:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FrimdBsssG4
Summary & History of the Show
Mahmoud is an irreverent & hilarious one-woman show about an aging Iranian engineer-cum-taxi driver, a fabulously gay Spaniard, and a young Iranian-Canadian girl, all trying to get by the day-to-day grind in the city they call home: Toronto.
Their stories come together over the course of an hour, and through their connections with the audience, themselves and each other, they explore the themes of displacement, immigration, home, and culture.
Performed by Tara Grammy, Mahmoud is co-written by Grammy and director Tom Arthur Davis, who have been developing the project since 2009. It has seen developmental help from Chalmers Winner Leah Cherniak and Dora Winner Soheil Parsa, who acted as the consulting director for the March 2011 production.
For more on the project visit: www.mahmoudtaxi.com

Reviews
"Dazzlingly Good! A Tour-De-Force Performance!"-Woody HarrelsonOscar Nominated Actor"Mahmoud is a refreshingly honest andpersonal take on how a young generation of Iranian-Canadians experience the uprising in our native homeland. This is life and politics as only a twenty year old can tell it, unabashed and irreverent, free of dogma and indoctrination."- Sima Sahar ZerehiShahrvand, the largest Farsi newspaper in North AmericaMahmoud is "a telling picture of immigrant experience. Tara Grammy deserves a nod for creating a piece of theatre that successfully leaps a few cultural hurdles.... Grammy has a definite facility with character roles."- John CoulbournToronto Sun"Grammy has incredible talent and charisma as a performer."-George PerryMooney On Theatre


How You Can Help
Mahmoud was recently accepted into the New York International Fringe Festival. 
Your contribution to our $6500 goal will help fund our expenses:
Visa Application Fee - $600.00Festival Fee - $600.00Adverstising (postcards) - $500.00Accomodations in New York for a Month - $4,000.00Travel Expenses (for 3 people - including Stage Manager Jenna) - $1,500.00
Total: $7,200.00

story:
Summary

A bit about me and how my project came into fruition:

 

My name is G.J. Dowding and I am a writer, director, and performer living in Brooklyn, New York. I have attended both Wagner College and New York University where I studied everything from vocal performance, music theory, acting, journalism, and fiction/poetry writing. Most of my training has been rooted in acting and I think of it as the foundation and skeleton for my new artistic directions. I am currently exploring what physical theater can do and how I can express my own experiences andartistic point of view through the medium of performance art. I am interested in traversing through the many vignettes of art; being open minded and encompassing an amalgam of themes by infusing different art forms. Collaboration is important to me. By collaborating we are able to expand in new directions through the format of an artistic conversation. Collaboration creates the platform to learn from someone else and in exchange gift them with the exposure and knowledge of your own artistic medium.

My project, Quizically Quimsical: An Exploration of Exploitation, is an original multi-media performance piece based on my poetry and prose that I am directing and self producing. The campaign is a very intimate and personal labor of love. I have always loved the idea of being an actor; a vessel that portrays a form of art. In my exploration of this I have discovered a passion for creating my own art.Throughout my life I have always enjoyed writing and kept it as a pastime for many years. But over the past two years I have become more serious about writing and I have developed clearer opinions on my perspective and interpretation of art.

I feel as though fate has brought me to this project. As a gay male, I have been exploring queer identity, persona, and art over the past year. In conjunction with that, I have been writing a lot on queer theory and my personal upbringing in a queer lifestyle. My performance piece is essentially a queer solo performance piece with a supporting ensemble. It is autobiographical, filled in with splendid fiction of course :) As I said before, I love bringing various art forms together within one context, so I decided to present my writing in collaboration with music and movement. This is where the ensemble comes in; to aid in the telling of a personal queer story, to bring the psyche and subconscious to life. This project is not only based on my career goals as an artist but is also meant to serve as a therapeutic conversation with people. I want to hear as many people’s stories in the world as possible in my lifetime and this is my contribution to the conversation.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need a total of $7,500 to make this thing happen by September 2012. Our biggest expense is performance space. We want to make the many months of hard work in rehearsals pay off for all of our beautiful actors by performing the piece at least five times. There are of course many other expenses that come into play, no pun intended, as well. Here's a break down of all the things we (broke students and recent college grads) need your help with:

  • Rehearsal space - BAX (Brooklyn Arts Exchange)
  • Performance space - Gene Frankel Theatre and House of Yes
  • Concessions
  • Costume designer and constume material 
  • Set designer and set material
  • Artist compensation
  • AV technition(s) (lights and sound)
  • Advertising/promotional material 

In return for your most generous contribution we will repay you with a variety of unique perks! These include tickets to the show, Q&As with the cast, dance lessons, personalized poetry by G.J. and song recordings by Hillary... and much more! You can check out the full list of rewards on the righthand side of the page.

If for some reason we do not reach our entire goal, all of the funds will still be used towards the performance piece. This would mean only perfoming the work once or twice, and downsizing on cosume/set design and promotional material.

 

The Impact

By donating to this project, you are not only helping me begin what I hope to be my work for the rest of my life, but you will also give exposure to some deeply talented fellow artists as well. I am working with a blossoming singer/songwriter, Hillary Capps, an extremely talented and smart choreographer, Jillene Johnson, a visionary costume and set designer, Diego Montoya, and eight incredibly eager, enthusiastic, unique, and talented actors: Aidan Davis, Jamarr John Johnson, Elisa Marti, Alesandra Nahodil, Shlomit Oren, Laura Riveros, Yael Shavitt and J.R. Yussuf. These artists all have their own individual messages they want to spread out to the New York City art scene and the world. Their voices are so beautiful and deserved to be heard.

Campaigns such as this one have the potential to be extremely successful and important. A few months ago Hillary Capps did a campaign to fund her first EP of original music on a similar website, Kickstarter, and received overwhelming support, making her goal of $3,500 with ten days to spare. Choreographer Jillene Johnson did an Indiegogo campaign this past spring along with the other graduating Dance majors to help fund their Senior Dance Show. They went well over their $4,000 goal. The point is, these campaigns have successful track records and truly do make a difference.

Even if you aren't able to donate, there are many other ways to contribute to the campaign. Spread the word my talking to friends, forwarding the link to the campaign to contacts via email, or sharing the Indiegogo page on Facebook and other social network sites. 

 

Thank you thank you thank you! Your support means the world to us!

story:
DUi Origin Story

Dead Unicorn Ink, is an Ottawa based theatre company that specializes in bringing design and concepts usually reserved for film to the stage. Founded in 2011 by Patrice Forbes, Sylvie Recoskie and Mike Doiron, DUi premiered Playing Dead, a zombie puppet show. Playing Dead went on to win the 2011 Outstanding Design Award from the Ottawa Fringe Festival for it's creative use of slayable puppets. In 2012 DUi traveled to outer space with the Fan Favourite Award winner Space Mystery From Outer Space. In this adventure we brought giant tentacles, a lizard monster big enough to eat whole actors, and the front end of a Camaro with working headlights to the stage. Since then we have used our shows to push the boundaries of technical aspects of stage (a three-seat couch puppet in Chesterfield, a beating heart in Scars and tentacle hands in Mermaids). 
We employ local artists of all sorts and each show features new casts. From mechanics in far off Smiths Falls to Ottawa central graphic designers we work with a large variety of technical talents. We strive to support new and young artists and continue to recommend them to other Ottawa companies after our time with them. And we pay! We always provide a set rate for artists, and then a profit share on top to ensure that everyone is appreciated. 
Our most recent show, Kavalier's Kuriosities, is our first step into the darker side of theatre. A mixture of side-show curiosity and dramatic family crisis, Kavalier's shows us the world from the perspective of the outcast of society. 
"[Kavalier's] is a cool piece and a good show from a theatre company that is maturing before our eyes," -Kevin Reid Visitorium
"The shadow puppets themselves are absolutely beautiful in design... The shocking events at the plays end will give you something to talk about," -Brianna McFarlane                                                                                                                       New Ottawa Critics

"The performance itself and acting displayed were outstanding," -Jean McLernon                                                                                                                               Apt 613


Why Are We Asking For Your Money?

Like most young theatre companies we believed in the concept of letting our work support itself. Again, like most companies, we began to realize the importance of grants, government support and blessed donors such as yourselves. We strive to ensure that each of our artists are compensated for their work and receive the opportunity to present their hard efforts to audiences.
We are looking for your support to send our company to the Atlantic Fringe Festival. The money we raise will go entirely to the tour and its costs:
- $580 Entrance fee to the Atlantic Fringe Festival. A total of eight shows at the Bus Stop Theatre
- $600 in travel costs (gas, expensive, expensive gas)
- $320 Accommodations, with a cast and crew of eight, touring seemed impossible. However we've been able to beg and borrow sleeping spaces and narrowed down our cost to a fraction of what it could have been.
- $250 Rehearsal rental! We should probably practice the show.
- $250 Prop, set and costume costs. Mainly blood, the high cost of fake blood, also cleaning said blood out of the costumes and repeat.
What if we raise money and make money off the show?
- Then we pay our artists. We have a full team including a sound designer, set/prop/light designer, actors, puppeteers, make-up designer, writers and producers that often make less then their work deserves. 
- As well any money the company makes is used to develop new works and future projects.
What if we don't make enough money?
- As often has to happen the producers will absorb the costs of the show and cuts will have to be made.
- No costumes for the next show! This could be good, could be bad. Want to chance it, or donate and ensure a fully clothed cast?
- Sock puppets for remaining shows, made from the sad holey socks of desperate actors. You can smell the sweat for Sally Sock Head and see the taught, tired toes of Tony Two Heels.
- Our next show will consist fully of actors sitting on chairs (naked?) staring at the audience and crying. Artistic choice or desperation? We'll let the critics decide.

The Future!

By helping us now, not only are you helping DUi expand and take it's work to new places and audiences but your also ensuring the future of the company to continue to expand their technical skills and experiment with new forms of puppetry.

Most notable is our next show, Under Derek's Bed. A show produced during the TACTICS series at Ottawa Arts Court April 2014, UDB will feature mask, puppets and fantasy styled stage design. Written by Sylvie Recoskie and directed by Martin Glassford, UDB will be a return to the DUi style of B movies brought to stage. Love the Dark Crystal, Labyrinth or Neverending Story? Under Derek's Bed holds all the same whimsy with a fraction of the production budget!


Other Ways You Can Help

We are a troupe of young professional theatre artists, so we understand being broke. Can't contribute today? Show your support by sharing this campaign! Pass it along to friends or family who you think might be interested in supporting the arts. Have a rich, seclusive Uncle, with hobbies that include re-animating corpses, wandering parapets of an ancient castle or training small mammals to do his bidding? I'm sure he'd love to hear about us!

Under Derek's Bed holds all the same whimsy with a fraction of the production budget!

  Other Ways You Can Help

story:
Do you remember your first experience in a theater?

Do you remember the feeling of amazement at what live performers could do, and laughing with the actors, and the emotion you felt responding to music and dance? Do you remember wishing that you could do that and asking your parents to sign you up for dance classes, or trying out for a school play, or taking up a musical instrument? If so, you can help us give that same experience to today's school children by donating to Dasher's Magical Gift, a show for children and families.

We at CNY Arts have been providing these arts experiences for Central New York schoolchildren for 35 years. If you were a young student here during that time, the chances are good that your first time in a theater was CNY Arts' presentation of The Adventures of Rudolph. After 35 years, The Adventures of Rudolph has been retired by its creators, and Dasher's Magical Gift is taking its place with a new story, new costumes, new sets, and new choreography, all designed with 21st century educational standard and tailored to today's youth. But we can't do it without your help.

Why We Are Asking YOU for Help

The creation of this educational, narrated ballet will cost about $60,000 more than the usual costs associated with presenting an existing ballet. We are building this show to last, recruiting nationally-recognized, but locally-based, creative talent. CNY Arts has a $15,000 grant to build off of and is fundraising an additional $45,000. We're approaching corporate sponsors and  we're applying to foundations... already raising over $13,000. We are incredibly grateful for the support we've received from the Central New York Community Foundation, Bond, Schoeneck & King, the Gifford Foundation, Pathfinder Bank, and Gannon's Ice Cream. Now we're hoping at least $10,000 of that can come from individuals like you. 

Dasher's Magical Gift will be a gift from the community to its children.

We have some fun perks for you including merchandise celebrating Dasher's world premiere and exclusive items for supporters and contributor's to Dasher's Scholarship Fund (see below). You and your family can even meet Dasher, Pepper, the penguins, and Santa on stage at the Crouse Hinds Theater after the public premiere!

    Why Dasher's Magical Gift is So Important

    Arts education has well documented benefits for young people. Through long experience, CNY Arts has learned that an entertaining offering like Dasher's Magical Gift, that incorporates dance, theater, and  music, and that is supported by educational materials, is the best way to foster an appreciation for the arts at an early age. 

    Pre-K and elementary schools in the region are hard-pressed to create arts opportunities of this scale, and CNY Arts works hard to keep ticket prices affordable for budget-conscious schools. We expect roughly 4000 children (plus 500 parents and teachers) at this year's four educational performances. That's 4000 chances to inspire the next generation of young artists and audience.

    We expect about 1500 children and their families to attend the public premiere on December 13. The CNY Arts holiday ballet is an annual tradition for many families, and we want to continue that tradition with as fantastic an entertainment as we can create, while keeping costs low so all families, including those on a budget, can participate.

      Where the Money Will Go

      All money we raise will go the creation of the new show so that CNY Arts will be able to produce it every year, to inspire the kids of today and their kids 25 or 30 years from now. By creating an original show instead of renting, CNY Arts will ensure that those ticket costs stay low, and the show can be updated to keep pace with changing times. 

      Any donations above $15,000 will be contributed directly to the Dasher Scholarship Fund, which CNY Arts sets aside to offer free or reduced-price tickets to those students that need a little extra support to get to the show.

        Other Ways You Can Help Dasher Fly!

          Theater magic runs on more than just financial contributions. If the timing just isn't right for you to give this year, here are some other ways you can help:

          • Help us spread the word! Share this campaign on Facebook and Twitter. Or give them a call!
          • Do you have a child in pre-K through 4th grade? Their class might be interested in taking a field trip to see Dasher's Magical Gift. Have them give us a call at 315-435-2155.
          • Come see the show! Dasher's Magical Gift will have its public premiere on Saturday, December 13. Tickets are available now!
          • Go to other events, event if they're not Dasher. You can inspire a child in your life to love and appreciate art. We always list great arts events for families on gotocnyarts.org. See what else is out there!
          Visit Dasher's page on cnyarts.org to learn all about Dasher's Magical Gift

Do you remember your first experience in a theater?
Do you remember the feeling of amazement at what live performers could do, and laughing with the actors, and the emotion you felt responding to music and dance? Do you remember wishing that you could do that and asking your parents to sign you up for dance classes, or trying out for a school play, or taking up a musical instrument? If so, you can help us give that same experience to today's school children by donating to Dasher's Magical Gift, a show for children and families.
We at CNY Arts have been providing these arts experiences for Central New York schoolchildren for 35 years. If you were a young student here during that time, the chances are good that your first time in a theater was CNY Arts' presentation of The Adventures of Rudolph. After 35 years, The Adventures of Rudolph has been retired by its creators, and Dasher's Magical Gift is taking its place with a new story, new costumes, new sets, and new choreography, all designed with 21st century educational standard and tailored to today's youth. But we can't do it without your help.
   Why We Are Asking YOU for Help The creation of this educational, narrated ballet will cost about $60,000 more than the usual costs associated with presenting an existing ballet. We are building this show to last, recruiting nationally-recognized, but locally-based, creative talent. CNY Arts has a $15,000 grant to build off of and is fundraising an additional $45,000. We're approaching corporate sponsors and  we're applying to foundations... already raising over $13,000. We are incredibly grateful for the support we've received from the Central New York Community Foundation, Bond, Schoeneck & King, the Gifford Foundation, Pathfinder Bank, and Gannon's Ice Cream. Now we're hoping at least $10,000 of that can come from individuals like you. 
Dasher's Magical Gift will be a gift from the community to its children.
We have some fun perks for you including merchandise celebrating Dasher's world premiere and exclusive items for supporters and contributor's to Dasher's Scholarship Fund (see below). You and your family can even meet Dasher, Pepper, the penguins, and Santa on stage at the Crouse Hinds Theater after the public premiere!

  Why Dasher's Magical Gift is So Important Arts education has well documented benefits for young people. Through long experience, CNY Arts has learned that an entertaining offering like Dasher's Magical Gift, that incorporates dance, theater, and  music, and that is supported by educational materials, is the best way to foster an appreciation for the arts at an early age. 
Pre-K and elementary schools in the region are hard-pressed to create arts opportunities of this scale, and CNY Arts works hard to keep ticket prices affordable for budget-conscious schools. We expect roughly 4000 children (plus 500 parents and teachers) at this year's four educational performances. That's 4000 chances to inspire the next generation of young artists and audience.
We expect about 1500 children and their families to attend the public premiere on December 13. The CNY Arts holiday ballet is an annual tradition for many families, and we want to continue that tradition with as fantastic an entertainment as we can create, while keeping costs low so all families, including those on a budget, can participate.

  Where the Money Will Go
All money we raise will go the creation of the new show so that CNY Arts will be able to produce it every year, to inspire the kids of today and their kids 25 or 30 years from now. By creating an original show instead of renting, CNY Arts will ensure that those ticket costs stay low, and the show can be updated to keep pace with changing times. 
Any donations above $15,000 will be contributed directly to the Dasher Scholarship Fund, which CNY Arts sets aside to offer free or reduced-price tickets to those students that need a little extra support to get to the show.

  Other Ways You Can Help Dasher Fly!

 Theater magic runs on more than just financial contributions. If the timing just isn't right for you to give this year, here are some other ways you can help:
Help us spread the word! Share this campaign on Facebook and Twitter. Or give them a call!
Do you have a child in pre-K through 4th grade? Their class might be interested in taking a field trip to see Dasher's Magical Gift. Have them give us a call at 315-435-2155.
Come see the show! Dasher's Magical Gift will have its public premiere on Saturday, December 13. Tickets are available now!

Go to other events, event if they're not Dasher. You can inspire a child in your life to love and appreciate art. We always list great arts events for families on gotocnyarts.org. See what else is out there!
Visit Dasher's page on cnyarts.org to learn all about Dasher's Magical Gift

story:
The Pulp Stage is a non-profit in Portland, Oregon. We offer easy tools for staging and savoring live theatre.

Our latest labor of love has been Storytelling Karaoke; a book of short stories meant for party gatherings. All you need to do is gather friends, download the book, choose your roles and read out loud. It's a bottle of theatre delight that you open up in your living room. Participants have described the experience as fun, addictive and empowering. 

The first volume of the book is out and we are at work creating the second volume for 2018; an adaptation of A Christmas Carol. This next book will be a perfect tool to unite community with convenience; a holiday treat that inspires gatherings.

The Karaoke project is the culmination of our company operations which include:

*maintaining basic needs such as insurance, printing supplies, accounting preparation, etc.

*expanding our touring program, serving communities asking for more live theatre.

*giving a small first-time stipend to the company leader!

Your tax-deductible donation keeps the company functioning... and gives us much-needed breathing room to create the best books. We believe that when moments of live delight are created the world has hope. You will be generating hope with us as we unite good things: the escape of great stories and the nourishment of group play.

PAUSE... No donation cash on hand? No problem. We can be supported at no cost to you every time you shop at Amazon or Fred Meyer. Click on the links below and type "The Pulp Stage" as your charitable organization.

https://smile.amazon.com/ch/38-3880484

https://tinyurl.com/fredpulp

 

OUR CURRENT EBOOK   Cover design by Alec Lugo Graphics

 

JUST READ AND SEE WHAT COMES OUT  Image by Nicolette Coiner-Winn and Matt Haynes

 

ANOTHER BOARD MEETING  Image by Nicolette Coiner-Winn and Matt Haynes

 

EARLY ADVERTISING AND PROOF OF CONCEPT   Image by Nicolette Coiner-Winn and Matt Haynes

 

WE MAKE IT A CHALLENGE TO HAVE A CHALLENGING LOAD-IN    Image by Nicolette Coiner-Winn

 

BRINGING IT ALL BACK HOME   Image by Nicolette Coiner-Winn

story:
To make "In Here" happen, I'm raising 2,000$ to cover a gap in funding.  All the money will support the project directly by contributing to performer pay, set materials, and labor to build the set.  This campaign is a raffle!!!  There are three donation levels and at each level contributors have the chance to win a piece of original soft sculpture!!  Names will be drawn at random at the conclusion of the campaign.

At the 20-39$ level FIVE folks will win mounted yellow or green soft sculpture genitals.  You choose the sex.  The pieces are 7"x7" and ready to hang.  Pieces will ship by June 2018.

At the 40-69$ level THREE folks will win a boob throw pillow!  The pillows are roughly 15"x15".  Fabric pattern and boob size and shape will be a surprise!  Pillows will ship by June 2018.

At the 70$ and up level ONE lucky person will win this large hanging soft sculpture piece that is currently in progress.  It is 33"x49", will be ready to hang, and will ship by July 2018.

story:
Performing October 31-November 2 in Shanley Pavilion


Soul Conductor Plot Description 

Maude is the lone employee in the Afterlife. Her routine of tending to The Ghosts and watching souls dissipate is disrupted when a suspicious spirit named Woman appears in Maude’s office. After Woman doesn’t disappear like the other ghosts, Maude discovers that Woman is still living, and has come to the Afterlife to retrieve her late husband. As Woman’s prolonged presence in the afterlife threatens to rupture the fabric of reality, Maude has to confront Woman and the rebelling Ghosts in order to save all planes of existence from destruction. Soul Conductor is an ectoplasmic romp about what happens when the things we're haunted by get out of hand.

Cast

  • Maude: Alison Mahoney
  • Woman: Michelle Schechter 
  • Ms. Ghost: Katherine Seldin
  • Mr. Ghost: Nick Lehmann 

The Production Team

  • Producer: Russell Kahn
  • Assistant Producer: Maddi Ginsberg
  • Director:  Pernell Van Myers
  • Assistant Director: Shaina Wagner
  • Writer: Scott Egleston 

Rehearsal Team 

  • Stage Manager: Courtney Quinn
  • Assistant Stage Manager: Sam Shankman

Artistic Team

  • Set Designer: Nikolaj Sorensen
  • Assistant Set: Ethan Robinson 
  • Scenic Paint: Sarah Sherman and Jacob Trauberman
  • Costume Designer: Michele Moses
  • Costume Mentor: Melanie Vitaterna
  • Props Design: Caitlin Kelley 
  • Props Assistant: Kyle Jaeger
  • Sound Designer: Sammy Zeisel
  • Lighting Designer: Dan Rufolo
  • Lighting Mentor: Alison Mahoney 
  • Technical Director: Wyatt Fair

Operators

  • Lighting: Alex Hagen
  • Sound: Tessa Dettman

Business Team

Publicity Team

  • Graphic Designer:`Josh Aronson
  • Publicity Director: Becca Wu
  • Public Team: Michelle Levin, Samantha Rosenthal, David Olodort, Emma Cadd, Austin Glass, and Lauren Feld

Fundraising Team

  • Fundraising Director: Anna Civik
  • Fundraising Team: Ari Yanes, Caitlin Medina, Mallory Harrington, Frank Ungerer, and Janie Dickerson

Other

  • Social Chair: Juanita Anderson
  • Dramaturgy by Erin Holiday

The Impact

By supporting Soul Conductor you are encouraging the creativity of today's youth and helping young artists to have a voice in the world. This new work has been created completely by students but needs your help to realize its full potential.

  • Every year Vertigo, a northwestern theatre board, showcases many new voices through their commitment to student written work.
  • These types of projects have gone onto be showcased at theatres in Chicago and New York
  • We want Soul Conductor to make a difference, to portray a new world, and give the audience a new perspective.


WE NEED YOU!

Any little contribution will help. This production will not be possible without you. Thank you so much!

story:
What is a Tetralogy?   

   A  Tetralogy  is a body of work/art composed of four pieces or elements (such as the four operas which make up Richard Wagner's Der Ring des Nibelungen).  Our use of the term is with reference to the tetralogies of ancient Greece, where each chosen playwright at the festival of Dionysus presented three tragedies followed by a satyr play, all shown in one sitting.

    The Ccollanan Pachacamac Tetralogy is composed of three tragedies:  Ccollanan Pachacamac, Ricuy Auccacunac, & Yahuarniy , with the satyr play Hichascancuta. Each is a truly silent film with no dialogue where all elements of the musical and visual creation have been subjected to the surrealist principles of automatism and objective chance.

    We have been given special permission by the Warner Grand Theatre and the city of Los Angeles to have a one night only production of all four films of the Ccollanan Pachacamac Tetralogy complete with a three dimensional musical and theatrical component.  This screening and theatre presentation will take place on Wednesday May 29 2013 at the Warner Grand Theatre in San Pedro and will end with the world premiere of Hichascancuta.

     

$1800 ---  our  fundraising goal?!

      The LA Opera has an annual budget of $60 million. Yuyanapaq has, well, less than that.  Much less.

      In an effort, though, to offer a presentation on that same level (albeit in a different realm of artistic language), Yuyanapaq hopes to raise $1800 to cover partial production costs (set design, costumes, stage lighting) as well as theatre rental and technical costs. Any funds raised over this amount will go towards the remaining costs of the production. 

      Yuyanapaq wishes to thank all those who donate, whether $9 or $584,  for helping to stage this unique multimedia event.  As bonuses for those who donate, Yuyanapaq is pressing a limited edition run of 13 copies of the satyr play Hichascancuta on gold dvd; this will be the ONLY pressing of this fourth and final film.  In addition, Yuyanapaq is offering four unique and one of a kind artpieces that were used in the filming of the tetralogy.

Yuyanapaq????

     The word  "yuyanapaq"  comes from the Quechua language of ancient Peru and means  "to remember".

      The titles of each film in the Ccollanan Pachacamac tetralogy come from the last sentence spoken by the Inca Tupac Amaru before he was beheaded in 1572.  This tetralogy references not only the ancient american symbology and knowledge of plants and celestial bodies, but the functioning of thought itself as "pure psychic automatism" amidst the world of dreams and the subconscious.

      Musically, Yuyanapaq is composed of Chaupituta (on drums/percussion/mallets), Hurinpacha (on bowed guitar, bass, concertina), and Yuyanapaq (on keyboards/samples/theremin), along with guest performers.

 

The Warner Grand Theatre

      Yuyanapaq wishes to thank Lee Sweet of the Warner Grand Theatre for the opportunity to perform in this historic venue.  The Warner Brothers  (of Warner Bros. films fame) had three "cinema palaces" constructed in the early 1930s --  one in beverly hills, one in huntington park, and one in san pedro.  The Warner Grand Theatre in San Pedro is the only one of the three still standing in her original glory, and is one of the only LA area theatres with a true orchestra pit.

       Please join Yuyanapaq for this ONE NIGHT ONLY screening and multimedia production, which will occur one hundred years exactly, (to the night) of the premiere of Stravinsky's Le Sacre du Printemps (in Paris on may 29 1913).

story:
What Is This?

'The Set Of Sun' is a reinvention of Shakespeare's classic Romeo and Juliet. When Lady Macbeth, Tamora and Rosalind discover a lovesick Juliet, the witches decide to recunstruct this classic love story into a story befitting of realistic love.

Every theatre artist has an ultimate goal of working in New York. This fall, that becomes a reality for 7 Chicago-based theatre artists.

We've been invited to participate at the Manhattan Rep Play Festival on the corner of 42nd and 8th Ave in Manhattan

'The Set Of Sun' will give six actors, one playwright/director and one costume designer a chance at their Off-Broadway debut.

 

The Nitty Gritty

We're looking to raise $3,500 for travel, housing, and production expenses like costumes!

When you donate, you can recieve anything from a social media shoutout to credit as an executive producer!

If we don't reach our goal, the funds we do raise will go to travel expenses

Learn More!

To learn more about Manhattan Repertory Theatre, visit http://manhattanrep.com/
To learn more about the playwright, visit http://artemisfreeman.wix.com/artemisfreeman
 
More information about the company members coming soon!

 

We live in an interactive world, so lets use it! Share this page on facebook, google +, myspace...anywhere we can get the word out!

story:
Claire Berry and Tressa Wilson

CLAIRE BERRY

Artistic Director of Connect Dance


Claire is a dance teacher and choreographer.  Born and raised in Ottawa, she began her earliest dance training in the city.  She performed twice in Les Grands Ballet Canadien’s production of The Nutcracker at the National Arts Centre.  She completed all of her Royal Academy of Dance examinations and competed as a semi finalist in the 2008 Genee International Ballet Competition.  Claire moved to Toronto to attend Ryerson University’s dance program under the direction of Nadia Potts.  She obtained her Bachelor of Fine Arts in Dance.  During her studies she had the opportunity to work with many Canadian dance artists.  She was also given guidance as she started to develop her body of work as a dance choreographer.

TRESSA WILSON

ADV. A.D.A.P.T

Artistic Director of Exordium Collective

Tressa is an accomplished choreographer and teacher in the Ottawa area. Her performing credits include Revenue Canada Gala, Snow Queen and Sugar Plum Fairy in The Nutcracker, Moulin Rouge Gala at The NAC, Brandi Disterheft’s “Pow Pow” music video and various charity events. As a choreographer Tressa has done work for Revenue Canada Galas, Ottawa’s Got Talent Gala for Ottawa Food Bank and various charity events. Her most recent project was the video for Ian Keteku’s “Kay” recounting the story of one of the world’s deadliest forces: A journey of pain and passion through metaphor.

A respected teacher and choreographer in the competitive world, Tressa has won many overall high score awards and numerous judges’ special awards for her work.

           On November 28th, 2013 Intertwined will be staged at Centrepointe Theatre.  In Intertwined, we invite you on a journey through the human condition. We offer a glimpse into personal moments of time, moving snapshots of life. View intimate moments of laughter, humour, the outrageous, the inquisitive, the grieving and the longing. Eavesdrop on conversations behind closed doors. Open your mind and your heart to the possibilities of what we can be and where we are headed. As we track our own journeys, we will inevitably be tangled within the journeys of others. We are connected. We are Intertwined.

          Promoting and growing a professional dance industry in Ottawa is a goal we all want to see succeed. The arts needs its audience. And the audience needs its artists. Your donation not only helps support arts in our community, but it pays a dancer's salary. It buys rehearsal space and costumes, and theatre rentals and promotional material and the millions of other details that go into creating a show. It's allowing someone to earn their living and create something unique. By donating, you become a part of that creation. 

What We Need 

Our fundraising goal is $7000.00. This money will help pay for the theatre rental, costumes, promotional materials and most importantly-DANCER SALARIES. This last point is important. Dancers and artists deserve to make their living. We are trying to create a self-sustaining professional industry and allow dancers to be compensated in the way that they deserve. These artists work harder than anyone, long physical hours in the studio to bring something beautiful and moving to the stage. 


What You Get

We have so much in store for you! Dear contributors, we want to thank you in every way we can. There's a wide variety of perks for those who donate to the success of Intertwined. Everything from a poster signed by the cast, all the way up to an invite to rehearsal and complimentary tickets! Take a scroll through the perks and learn all about what you'll receive when you support Intertwined. Every dollar helps. Every cent makes a difference. If we all pitch in, this goal will be reached. 

You're Changing Lives

Here's the thing... Artists live a precarious existence. Pay cheques are not always reliable, arts funding hard to come by, life gets in the way. This project is bringing hope. Hope for a larger professional dance industry in our Nation's Capital. Hope for bringing about a change in how we view the payment of dancers. It's opportunity. Opportunity for growth and new enterprise. Let's all get involved and bring it to life. 

   Both Tressa and Claire have been working in the dance industry for years. They are respected teachers, award-winning choreographers and well-known within the dance community. We want to bring all the experience and knowledge to creating a show that moves and breathes and allows all of us to experience the new. It's a journey and we're all on it. 

 

What Else Can You Do?

There's more to being a contributor than just donating money. Want to help out? SPREAD THE WORD! Information is currency. Tell your friends. Tell strangers. Email links. Volunteer to put up posters in your neighbourhood and community centres. There is so much work to be done and many ways to contribute and help that aren't monetary. Please contact us if you'd like to help out in any other way at either:

www.ccdo.org

www.exordiumcollective.com

Let's make this a whole community project. By donating or volunteering or even spreading the word, it has become your project too, and it's outcome as much you're doing as ours. 


Tressa Wilson and Claire Berry
story_txt:
Claire Berry and Tressa Wilson
CLAIRE BERRY
Artistic Director of Connect Dance

Claire is a dance teacher and choreographer.  Born and raised in Ottawa, she began her earliest dance training in the city.  She performed twice in Les Grands Ballet Canadien’s production of The Nutcracker at the National Arts Centre.  She completed all of her Royal Academy of Dance examinations and competed as a semi finalist in the 2008 Genee International Ballet Competition.  Claire moved to Toronto to attend Ryerson University’s dance program under the direction of Nadia Potts.  She obtained her Bachelor of Fine Arts in Dance.  During her studies she had the opportunity to work with many Canadian dance artists.  She was also given guidance as she started to develop her body of work as a dance choreographer.

TRESSA WILSON
ADV. A.D.A.P.T
Artistic Director of Exordium Collective
Tressa is an accomplished choreographer and teacher in the Ottawa area. Her performing credits include Revenue Canada Gala, Snow Queen and Sugar Plum Fairy in The Nutcracker, Moulin Rouge Gala at The NAC, Brandi Disterheft’s “Pow Pow” music video and various charity events. As a choreographer Tressa has done work for Revenue Canada Galas, Ottawa’s Got Talent Gala for Ottawa Food Bank and various charity events. Her most recent project was the video for Ian Keteku’s “Kay” recounting the story of one of the world’s deadliest forces: A journey of pain and passion through metaphor.
A respected teacher and choreographer in the competitive world, Tressa has won many overall high score awards and numerous judges’ special awards for her work.

           On November 28th, 2013 Intertwined will be staged at Centrepointe Theatre.  In Intertwined, we invite you on a journey through the human condition. We offer a glimpse into personal moments of time, moving snapshots of life. View intimate moments of laughter, humour, the outrageous, the inquisitive, the grieving and the longing. Eavesdrop on conversations behind closed doors. Open your mind and your heart to the possibilities of what we can be and where we are headed. As we track our own journeys, we will inevitably be tangled within the journeys of others. We are connected. We are Intertwined.
          Promoting and growing a professional dance industry in Ottawa is a goal we all want to see succeed. The arts needs its audience. And the audience needs its artists. Your donation not only helps support arts in our community, but it pays a dancer's salary. It buys rehearsal space and costumes, and theatre rentals and promotional material and the millions of other details that go into creating a show. It's allowing someone to earn their living and create something unique. By donating, you become a part of that creation. 


What We Need 
Our fundraising goal is $7000.00. This money will help pay for the theatre rental, costumes, promotional materials and most importantly-DANCER SALARIES. This last point is important. Dancers and artists deserve to make their living. We are trying to create a self-sustaining professional industry and allow dancers to be compensated in the way that they deserve. These artists work harder than anyone, long physical hours in the studio to bring something beautiful and moving to the stage. 

What You Get
We have so much in store for you! Dear contributors, we want to thank you in every way we can. There's a wide variety of perks for those who donate to the success of Intertwined. Everything from a poster signed by the cast, all the way up to an invite to rehearsal and complimentary tickets! Take a scroll through the perks and learn all about what you'll receive when you support Intertwined. Every dollar helps. Every cent makes a difference. If we all pitch in, this goal will be reached. 
You're Changing Lives
Here's the thing... Artists live a precarious existence. Pay cheques are not always reliable, arts funding hard to come by, life gets in the way. This project is bringing hope. Hope for a larger professional dance industry in our Nation's Capital. Hope for bringing about a change in how we view the payment of dancers. It's opportunity. Opportunity for growth and new enterprise. Let's all get involved and bring it to life. 
   Both Tressa and Claire have been working in the dance industry for years. They are respected teachers, award-winning choreographers and well-known within the dance community. We want to bring all the experience and knowledge to creating a show that moves and breathes and allows all of us to experience the new. It's a journey and we're all on it. 
 


What Else Can You Do?
There's more to being a contributor than just donating money. Want to help out? SPREAD THE WORD! Information is currency. Tell your friends. Tell strangers. Email links. Volunteer to put up posters in your neighbourhood and community centres. There is so much work to be done and many ways to contribute and help that aren't monetary. Please contact us if you'd like to help out in any other way at either:
www.ccdo.org
www.exordiumcollective.com
Let's make this a whole community project. By donating or volunteering or even spreading the word, it has become your project too, and it's outcome as much you're doing as ours. 

Tressa Wilson and Claire Berry

story:
Hi My name Is Fehinti Balogun , I am 19 years old  and I'm from a Hemel Hempstead Hertfordshire. last year after four long rounds of auditioning ,I was given a place at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art on the BA Acting course.

My budgeting skills show me that even with student finance I will be £1000 under budget  for the year, and to qualify for any help from RADA I must do my own fundraising , this is where I need YOUR help.

Any donations  will go towards  :

 

  • Flat depost ( 680£)
  • Books
  • Rent
  • Food
  • and anything else the course requires for the whole year.

 

Every donation Big or small is appreciated!

 

 A little About me

I have been working with the National Youth Theatre for 3 years doing projects all over the UK ,for example  I performed at the London 2012 Olympic and Paralympic games in what was called the 'Welcoming ceremonies'- A performance to welcome each country into the Olympic park and games. The welcoming Ceremonies were first ceremonies of them all and the athletes first real feel for the buzz of the games, needless to say this made me extremely proud to be working with the National Youth Theatre and in Theatre. i the worked with the  National Youth Theatre in Saudi Arabia facilitating acting courses in Al Hasa.

story:
Dear Cabrillo College Dance Supporters,

I am reaching out to you because I believe you care about dance at Cabrillo College. We are currently rehearsing for the Spring Dance Concert. We had 67 students audition to dance in the show last week. It was an amazing feeling to have so much creative energy on the Crocker Theater stage.

Next month we are taking nine Cabrillo dancers to the American College Dance Festival (ACDF), which is being held this year at Arizona State University in Tempe. ACDF is the nation’s premiere college dance event. It’s a place where students come together to exchange ideas, see performances, and take classes. The faculty who teach come from all over the Western Region – so this is an ideal opportunity for our students to see what is going on in dance on a national level, and to consider what four year university program to transfer to. 

The location of the ACDF Western Region Conference changes from year to year. The last time I took dancers it was held in Modesto, so we drove and that kept the expenses down. This year we have the additional cost of flying to Tempe for the four days of the conference. The price of the nine plane tickets is $2,799. The students have already paid for their registration ($120), and the Cabrillo Student Senate has given us $2000 towards hotel costs and small portion of the travel.

As you know, many of our students are working their way through school, and don’t have a lot of extra money. All nine of them have committed to paying the remaining expenses, but we know that for some of them this a bit of a stretch. That’s why we need your help.

Our goal is to raise a minimum of $2000 in the next two weeks to cover the majority of the remaining travel costs. The Cabrillo dancers who are going to the American College Dance Festival this year are:

Alyssa Krauter

Daniella Nasello

Tamara Nelson

Alyssa Jenkins

Julia Daniel

Charley Fierro

Jessica Laufer

Megan Fultz

Chelsea Zamora

I will be going with them as their faculty representative, but all of the proceeds from this campaign will go to the students’ expenses. This is a "fixed funding" campaign which means if we don't reach our goal we don't receive any of the funds. If we raise more than $2000, additional contributions will go to covering dancers' meals and local transportation.

I hope you are as excited about this opportunity for our students as I am. These young dancers continue to inspire me and I believe that they deserve the best educational opportunities we can provide them with.

Please make a contribution towards taking our students to ACDF 2014 if you can, and help spread the word. And we hope to see you at the Cabrillo Spring Dance Concert, May 9-11, at the Crocker Theater.

Best regards,

David King

Co-Chair

Cabrillo Dance Department

**Please note that your contribution is not tax deductible.**

Photos: Beau Saunders, rainbeaupictures.com

story:
Shared joy. Flights of fancy.

This summer, Midsommer Flight will present Romeo and Juliet at two Chicago Park District locations in July and August.  We are thrilled and excited to present this Shakespeare in the park experience for FREE to our audiences - but that means we need your help to make it happen.

This is the second production for Midsommer Flight, after A Midsummer Night's Dream last summer.  Last year, we reached an audience of close to 300 people over four performances at one park.  This year, we are doubling our performances, with eight shows over four weekends at two parks.  It was thrilling last summer to reach out into the neighborhood and see the kids who hang out at the park get excited about Shakespeare. We can't wait to do it again this summer!

When the show ended last summer, we were surprised and delighted to be honored with a resolution from the Chicago City Council, co-signed by Mayer Rahm Emanuel and City Clerk Susana Mendoza, which stated, "Be it resolved, That we, the Mayor and the members of the Chicago City Council, assembled this twelfth day of September, 2012, do hereby honor the Midsommer Flight theater troupe on their dedication to bringing the arts to underserved communities."

We are so excited to get out in the parks and do it again this year.  And we need your help to do it!  Please consider donating the cost of an average theatre ticket (anywhere from $50 to $20) to help us reach our $1,500 goal.

The play is directed by Midsommer Flight founder and Producing Artistic Director, Beth Wolf. The cast features Ashlee Edgemon, Nick Ferrin, John Ham, Brendan Hutt, Kanome' Jones, Nyle Kenning, Molly Lyons, Mason Pain, J. Preddie Predmore, Rachael Proulx, Brian Scannell, Chris Smith, Julian Stroop, Adam Welsh, and Sheila Willis. Additional production staff includes Beth Laske-Miller, Ross Lemmon, Dylan Roberts, and David Yondorf.

Midsommer Flight is a Chicago theatre collective dedicated to producing outdoor performances of Shakespeare’s plays. Our goal is to share our passion for Shakespeare and theatre with our community. Shakespeare is cool. The plays are beautiful and exciting, full of love, lust, sorrow, revenge, magic and joy. Performing these amazing works under the open sky only heightens the emotion and the sense of adventure shared by the actors and audiences during a performance.

We envision local residents, families, Shakespeare lovers, and those new to Shakespeare's work all to come out for a picnic and to enjoy a free performance in the fresh air of a Chicago summer. Creating and sharing this experience sounds like a wonderful way to spend our summer. If you agree, please support the production and come check out the show in July and August!

Please visit www.midsommerflight.com for performance details, rehearsal notes, and artist biographies.

Thank you for supporting Midsommer Flight!
